talk.start.para: - I direct a question to the Minister for Labour and National Service. Is it true, as stated in the editorial of this morning's Melbourne " Age ", that the Minister "has made it clear in Parliament that the Federal Government is anxious to see a fight to the finish" in the present dispute at the plants of General Motors-Holden's Pty. Ltd.? Has the Minister any power to summon the parties together in open conference? Does he propose to take action in any way in order to arrange such a conference?

talker.role: Minister for Labour and National Service
talker.name: MCMAHON, William
Mr McMAHON

talk.start.para: - I have read the article in the Melbourne " Age " to which the honorable gentleman has referred. It is not correct to say that I would like to see a fight to the finish.
- You said that yesterday.

- That is untrue, and the Leader of the Opposition knows that it is untrue. If he likes, I will get my answer and read it out to him; but he should be capable of reading it himself. I stated in the House yesterday that in the initial stage of the dispute relating to the foundry the company was willing to negotiate. It was willing to have the claim in respect of the foundry employees settled by negotiation and conciliation. I also pointed out to the House that arbitration was open on the overall claim for £3 a week. The unions have not availed themselves of arbitration. I leave my argument at that point. The course of arbitration is still open. If the unions agree to take their claim to arbitration, they are in a position to do so.

- I ask the Minister for the Army a question following the statement reported to have been made by the Prime Minister, when referring to the situation to the north of Australia, that Australia has never been at greater risk. What is the number of school cadets being trained in Australia, and is the number increasing? Have the military authorities kept the schools informed of the gravity of the situation to our north and are the school authorities co-operating as a result? Do school vocational advisers recommend to boys that they enter Duntroon and the Army?

- The honorable gentleman has asked quite a number of questions about the school cadet corps. The current strength of the corps is approximately 40,000. This is the ceiling imposed by Government policy, but I expect that it will be gradually lifted as personnel of the Regular Army become available and as the relative priorities for the use of Regular Army manpower permit the expansion of the corps. We have had the utmost co-operation from most school authorities in the establishment of the corps. The honorable gentleman also asked whether headmasters were encouraging pupils to enter Duntroon, the Officer Cadet School and so on. We have received co-operation from many headmasters. However, I think it true to say that there are still too many headmasters and career counsellors in general who have not yet appreciated that service in the Army is a very fine career.

- I ask the Minister for Labour and National Service a question. Is the inference to be drawn from his answers to questions yesterday about the dispute at General Motors-Holden's Pty. Ltd. that the Government wishes the company to make no concessions to the workers and certainly not to agree to the requests of the workers because to do so might set off another stage of inflation? Is he prepared to withdraw the statement he made yesterday that the dispute was engineered by the Communist Secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering Union and that the rest of the union leaders are following blindly behind him? Is it right to say that the employers are prepared to negotiate and the employees are not? Is it a fact that the employers are not prepared to negotiate without conditions but Mr. Monk, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has said that his body will negotiate provided no conditions are attached to the negotiations?
- The honorable gentleman asked me so many questions that it is difficult to answer all of them.
- I did not expect you to understand them.

- You asked so many questions that it is difficult to answer them all. The second question related to Mr. Carmichael of the Amalgamated Engineering Union. I did not say that he had initiated the strike. I said that he was now manipulating it or had been manipulating it up to the stage where it moved out of Victoria into South Australia. At that time the dispute became an interstate dispute and consequently came into the jurisdiction of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That is the point I made yesterday; I adhere to it and clarify it today. As to the first part of the honorable gentleman's question - would the honorable gentleman remind me what was the first part?
- Whether the company is prepared to negotiate without conditions - I think you said it was - and the union is prepared to negotiate without conditions?

- That was the last part, not the first part at all, so you have lost track of your own question. What the honorable gentleman implied in the first part of his question was: What is the position of General Motors-Holden's Pty. Ltd. in relation to these negotiations? The dispute is between the various unions involved and the company. At the present, it is up to those parties to decide what their respective courses of action should be. They are the parties immediately involved, and I do not think that this is a case in which direct government involvement should occur at the moment.
- My question was in these terms: Was the Minister's answer intended to convey the impression that the Government was backing G.M.H. in its refusal to negotiate with the workers?

- If the honorable gentleman now wishes that question to be answered, I reply to ft in the way in which I answered the previous question: This is a dispute between two parties - the unions on the one side and the company on the other. It involves the whole of the Australian community in the sense that the men concerned and their families - this is to be deeply regretted - are losing unnecessarily a great deal of pay and other moneys. I personally believe that the matter could be dealt with by the arbitration system. It is up to the unions to take what action is necessary, if they believe in arbitration. On this issue, the Government has not taken sides, as both the Deputy Prime Minister and I intimated yesterday.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Excise. Has the Minister's attention been directed to a recent article which appeared in the Hobart Press on the eve of the annual conference of Collectors of Customs and the transfer of Mr. Venning, the then Collector of Customs in Tasmania, and which suggested that Australia had a worldwide reputation as a clearing house for drug traffic and that, as a result of customs activity in mainland ports, drug smugglers are turning their attention to Tasmanian ports? Will the Minister assure the House that there has been no laxity in customs activities in Tasmanian ports, as suggested in this article, and also that Australia does not, in fact, have a worldwide reputation as a clearing house for drug traffic?

- I have seen the article mentioned by the honorable member and have discussed it with the Minister for Customs and Excise. There is no truth in the suggestion that there has been any laxity by the preventive service of the Department of Customs and Excise which functions efficiently in both Tasmania and the rest of Australia. That service is at present being re-organised to make it even more efficient. We know that the consumption of illegal narcotics in Australia is extremely small.

speech.para: Therefore, those quantities periodically seized are probably not intended for local consumption. However, Australian ports are not on the routes between the countries where drugs are illegally produced and the countries where they are illegally consumed in large quantities, and it is therefore most unlikely that Australia would be used as a clearing house for narcotics. In short, there is no evidence whatsoever of the truth of the suggestion made in the article.

talk.start.para: - I wish to direct a question to the Treasurer. Will he intimate whether it is intended to introduce legislation to amend the income tax laws in the manner suggested in the report of the Commonwealth Committee on Taxation presided over by Sir George Ligertwood, particularly with reference to leases, family partnerships and trusts, and superannuation funds? If the Government intends to legislate, will the amending measures be brought in this year?

- It is intended to legislate broadly in the field covered by the report of the Ligertwood committee. I am at present waiting for the draft legislation from the Attorney-General's Department. In other words, all the substantial decisions of the Government have been taken on this matter. I hope to receive the draft so that it may be considered by the legislative committee of the Cabinet within the next two or three weeks. We shall then produce a bill, certainly in this session and I hope before the House rises for its customary recess. The matter is now in the hands of the Parliamentary Draftsman.
- You mean before the next recess of one week?
- Yes. I hope to f produce the bill by the end of this month, f this is not possible, it will be produced as soon as possible thereafter.

- I address a question to the Minister for Primary Industry. Was a scheme for the stabilisation of the tobacco industry placed before the Commonwealth Ministers concerned on 13th August? Has the scheme been considered by the Government? If so, can the Minister say when it will be introduced?

- I think it was late in August when the growers' representatives met the three Commonwealth Ministers and submitted a proposal for stabilisation. It was at that stage that the three Ministers met the manufacturers and the growers in conference. It was considered essential that the growers and the manufacturers should determine a scale of grades and prices before we came to any conclusion or determined any policy. We sent the representatives away to have a look at that matter and they have never reported back. If they are complaining at the moment, as some of them are, that there is some delay, all I can say is that the ball is back in their court. However, the Government has not rested at that. As a result of action by the Commonwealth Government I met the three State Ministers concerned in Sydney last week, and we are looking at the matter further to determine how quickly we can agree on a basis on which we can again meet the growers and the manufacturers.

- Will the Minister for the Army confirm that the 10 Bofors antiaircraft guns recently sent to Darwin but at present unmanned are the only antiaircraft weapons protecting the coastline of northern Australia between Newcastle on the east coast and possibly Fremantle on the west coast? Will the Minister also confirm that the Bofors guns in question, while they were excellent weapons against low flying aircraft in World War II, would be about as useful against high flying modern aircraft attacking Australia as shovelnosed spears and boomerangs would be? Should not modern anti-aircraft rocket batteries be installed at strategic spots on our northern coastline to cope with attacks by such high flying modern aircraft or any other kind of air attack?

- Decisions on where to station anti-aircraft guns or any other defence equipment are matters of Government defence policy. It is true that a number of Bofors guns were recently sent to Darwin to provide equipment for the raising of a unit of the Citizen Military Forces in that town. I should have thought that the honorable member, coming as he does from that part of the world, would have been very glad that we are giving the citizens of Darwin an opportunity to provide eventually, perhaps, for their own defence. I hope we will have his assistance in forming this unit as rapidly as possible. As to a replacement for the Bofors guns, I think it is true to say that no country has yet developed a replacement to take over the particular role of the Bofors gun, which is to give protection against attacks by lowflying aircraft. Strenuous efforts are being made to do so. We are watching developments very carefully in that respect. Finally, whatever the honorable member may say about the Bofors gun, I have found from talking to Air Force pilots, both from Australia and other countries, that they still have a very healthy respect for it. Although the Bofors gun does have its disadvantages, undoubtedly it provides a very useful deterrent effect.

- I address a question to the Deputy Prime Minister. I refer to charges, imputing among other things disloyalty, made in this House and outside it concerning an organisation known as the Australian League of Rights. I ask: In view of the very serious nature of the charges will the Government say whether it has any information which would in any substantial way support these charges? If so, will the Government make the information available for public scrutiny? If the Government has not any information of an incriminatory nature will it say so and thereby give to those concerned an opportunity to vindicate their character and to clear their names?

- I am not familiar with the alleged charges that have been made nor with the facts in respect of this organisation. I will look at the matter, but I do not regard it as a function of the Government to issue character certificates.

- My question, which is directed to the Minister for the Navy, deals with that part of the Royal Commission's report on the " Voyager " disaster in which special reference is made to outstanding acts of heroism by certain members of the " Voyager's " crew. In view of the fact that, as I believe, acts of heroism and bravery such as were displayed are no less great in peace time than in war, will the Minister consider bringing this matter before members of the Naval Board with the object of the Board taking necessary action to bring about suitable recognition of these acts?

- The question of conferring awards of all sorts, whether civil, military or for any purpose whatever, is not normally discussed until the awards are announced. There are obvious reasons for that. However, I assure the honorable member that the Naval Board was not unmindful of the statements that were made during the Royal Commission in connection with this matter.

- Can the Minister for Housing tell the House why the War Service Homes Division has been unable to proceed with plans to construct homes for eligible ex-servicemen on land acquired three years ago for this purpose at Baulkham Hills? Is it a fact that the New South Wales Government has refused to approve the release of the land for homes for ex-servicemen, despite the fact that there is still a housing shortage in New South Wales and that the scheme has been approved by the local council and the National Trust of Australia (N.S.W.)?

- We did acquire about three years ago at Baulkham Hills 114 acres which had been released by the Army and which had formerly been used as a rifle range. This is a normal practice. A number of war service homes estates have been built on surplus Commonwealth lands. Accordingly, we drew up plans which involved developing most of that area as a housing estate with good class homes for ex-servicemen and the release of 39 acres of open space for recreation purposes. Although we are not bound by State government zoning regulations; it is the normal practice to apply to the local government authorities and to adhere to whatever the local government regulations may be. Accordingly, we made application and our plans were approved by the Baulkham Hills Shire Council, which passed a resolution in favour of them. The plans were examined also by the National Trust, which is particularly concerned with amenities around Sydney. The Trust expressed no disapproval. However, the New South Wales

speech.para: Minister for Local Government rejected the application, and that is the point at which the matter now stands.

talk.start.para: - Can the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation inform this chamber whether the Minister for Civil Aviation, Senator Henty, is representing Reg Ansett, or whether Reg Ansett is the Minister for Civil Aviation represented by Senator Henty?
- The question is such a futile one that I do not propose to answer it.

debate.para: Mr. SINCLAIR__My question is directed to the Minister for the Army. Has exercise Long Shot demonstrated the ability of the Australian Regular Army to maintain and sustain forces in the field at any point in South East Asia or to the north of Australia where they may be required, and forcibly displayed the effectiveness of the Australian Army to the limit of its present manpower, and also illustrated that early steps will be necessary to increase the number of Australian trained military personnel beyond the present announced quotas?

talk.start.para: - The overwhelming lesson of exercise Long Shot in the logistic sense was the demonstration of the Australian Army's capacity, training and equipment without doubt to mount and maintain a force on a far shore. This exercise also demonstrated that with more men the Army could do this more comfortably and with less disruption to the Australian support area.

- My question which is directed to the Minister for the Navy is supplementary to the question asked by the honorable member for Macarthur concerning the training of school cadets. I ask the Minister whether it would be possible for the Department of the Navy to provide Launceston sea cadets with equipment for training purposes a little more up to date than the piece of field artillery that they have at present, which was used in the Boer War.

- I should imagine that the sea cadets in Launceston have this piece of artillery purely as a museum piece, and not for any training that might stand them in good stead in the Navy. Concurrently, the question of sea cadets is under consideration by my Department in an attempt to improve the training methods available. I am quite certain that the unit mentioned by the honorable member will be one of those given consideration.

subdebateinfo.title: UNITED STATES INVESTMENT IN AUSTRALIAN MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY

talk.start.para: - My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. As the latest Directory of United States Investment in Australian Manufacturing Industry is dated 1962, would the right honorable gentleman arrange for his department to publish as early as possible an up to date directory so that members may be informed on the present extent of direct investment by United States companies in Australian manufacturing industry?

- I advise the honorable member that the publication of a revised edition of directories showing overseas investment in Australia is under consideration at the present time. There is a tremendous amount of work involved in assembling the information. I can tell the honorable member that the matter is under consideration, but I cannot promise him when the directories will be actually available.

- I ask the Minister for Housing a question concerning New South Wales legislation, and administration, and the War Service Homes Division. The honorable member for Phillip asked the Minister a question concerning 104 building blocks in that State. I want to ask him about some 600 advances which have been made possible for applicants to the Division under New South Wales legislation, the Conveyancing (Strata Titles) Act. I ask the Minister whether the Division has put it to the other five States that they also should pass legislation which would permit applicants for advances from the War Service Homes Division to secure advances for home units.

- The position is that the War Service Homes Act requires that the War Service Homes Division must be assured that there are satisfactory titles before loans can be made. The New South Wales Government has passed satisfactory strata title legislation, as has the Tasmanian Government. We have been discussing the matter with other authorities, particularly the Victorian authorities. I believe that they are now engaged in revising their strata title legislation. When this has been done, and when satisfactory titles can be got, we shall be able to make similar advances in other States.

- I address to the Minister for National Development a question relating to the Chowilla Dam. Has the Minister any up to date information relating to the progress of the work connected with the construction of this dam, which is so vital to the water requirements of South Australia?

- I understand that work is proceeding quite expeditiously on the site of the Chowilla Dam. The work being done at present is connected with designing the dam and testing foundations. I believe that the South Australian authorities who are to build the dam for the River Murray Commission will be in a position to call for tenders in about the middle of next year. The dam will take about three years to complete. It should be completed, therefore, in time for the spring flow in 1 969. This will be by a long way the largest water storage project in Australia. The dam will hold back about five million acre feet of water, which is about twice the amount held back by the Hume Weir. The estimated cost of the work is approximately £14 million, which is quite low.

- I address a question to the Minister for External Affairs. Several months have elapsed since the Minister announced that Australia would exchange diplomatic representatives with Ireland, but no Australian appointment has yet been made. On behalf of many thousands of Australian citizens of Irish extraction, I ask: What are the reasons for the delay in making the appointment? Is it a fact that Ireland appointed an Ambassador to Australia approximately three months ago and is disappointed at Australia's reluctance to exchange representatives by appointing an Australian Ambassador to Ireland? Is it the intention of the Minister to delay the Australian appointment until after the Senate election in order that the position may be offered to a defeated Liberal Party candidate?

- I assured the honorable member once before that there was no reluctance on our part to complete this appointment and that we are taking exceptional care to appoint a suitable man worthy of this high office.

- My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In view of the tremendous importance to the rural areas of Australia of the proposed rationalisation of petrol prices, particularly because of the rising costs that are facing many of the residents of those areas, has the Treasurer stressed the urgency of this matter to the other parties involved? Can he say what the present position is regarding finalisation of the proposal and the introduction into this Parliament of the appropriate legislation?

- Perhaps this matter comes more within my jurisdiction. Yesterday, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Attorney-General, the Minister for Customs and Excise and I had a meeting with representatives of the oil industry with a view to finalising the proposal. We are now starting to draft the required bills. The Prime Minister has written to the Premiers of the various States asking them to nominate representatives to come here for finalisation of the draft legislation, as legislation by the States as well as by the Commonwealth will be required. So far we have received replies from three of the States who have nominated the people who will be sent here. We intend to call a conference at Canberra as soon as the legislation is in draft form so that it can be shown to them, and discuss it on the spot with them.

- Does the Treasurer recall having said at the opening of the Technical Division of General MotorsHolden's Pty. Ltd., Fishermen's Bend, Port Melbourne, that an increase in prices was inevitable due to the £1 a week increase in the basic wage? Will the Treasurer inform the House whether the sentiments contained in that statement are the sentiments actuating the Government's stand on the General Motors-Holden's dispute in which the workers of General Motors-Holden's are seeking an increase in their weekly wage?

- The point I was trying to make when I included in a more general survey the statement to which the honorable gentleman has referred was that the size of the wage adjustment made, in my judgment, some increase in prices inevitable, not necessarily in the field of private industry where a high degree of competitiveness exists - and, indeed, I think that so far as the motor industry is concerned there has been no upward adjustment of prices following the basic wage increase. However, I did know that the government utilities, which have no opportunity to absorb a cost increase from the profits they make, because they render so far as practicable their services at cost to the community, would have to increase the cost of some of the services provided. From what I knew of the financial position of the State Governments I felt that they would not be able to absorb this increase within their budgets and that, in the case of several of them and of some of the utilities, increases in prices could be expected. This has taken place, and I do not think anyone should have been surprised by it. Indeed it is astonishing to me to find that those who speak for the trade unions in this country should have not anticipated this as a certain consequence of the decision to increase the basic wage. The objective of this Government has been to ensure as high a degree of competition in industry as can be maintained so that the public will secure commodities and services at the best cost available to them. The services provided by governments will continue to be operated at the most efficient level that governments can provide, but governments have no magic of their own which enables them to absorb cost increases without in turn passing those charges on to the public.
- I wish to ask the

speech.para: Minister for Supply a question about faulty gun ammunition. I understand that the Army has complained that a number of types of ammunition and explosives supplied to the Army by the Department of Supply were faulty. Can the Minister say what the reasons for these failures are and what steps are being taken to avoid premature explosions and to correct any faults in ammunition in the future?

talk.start.para: - I am afraid that a rundown on ammunition production would go well beyond the confines of question time, but I might be permitted to say that when you start to put together the most intricate mechanical, chemical and electronic processes to make a projectile which is intended to be at once completely lethal to the person in front and completely safe to the person in back, you are bound to run into mechanical trouble. In any line of production of this kind inevitably some defects will creep through. In the normal course of production you can test an item, judge its faults, correct them and put the item back into service, but in the case of explosives under test, if there is a malfunction the evidence is destroyed with the item under test. This situation leads to some most extraordinary difficulties. I know that is a masterpiece of understatement. The Army certainly appreciates my Department's difficulties.

speech.para: The difficulties reported arose principally from a small series - three in all - of premature explosions that occurred in one type of gun ammunition. When a premature explosion of this kind occurs in the small percentage of rounds under test it is necessary to red card or to take out of service the rest of that batch of production until you have isolated the cause of the premature explosion. As I pointed out, with ammunition that is faulty nothing is left on which to work and you must go through every process with the shell and upgrade every process of production hoping that thereby you will find the one causing the trouble.

In this case the Army and the Department of Supply sent a team of explosives experts abroad. We sought the best advice from ammunition production experts in the United Kingdom, Canada and America, all of whom had had experience with this particular type of explosive. The upshot of this exercise was to cause the overseas production agencies to have a second look at their production but it did not isolate the cause of our difficulty. This matter is under constant investigation. We believe that we have now produced a shell to upgraded Army specification and we are back in production in that line of endeavour.

Some reference has been made to shells marked " Not for Issue ". I think I should point out to the House that shells marked " Not for Issue " are not necessarily defective. That inscription simply means that if there is the slightest suspicion of a defect yet undisclosed in that ammunition it will be red carded for full examination. This is a safety precaution for the men using the ammunition. In addition where you have a series of shells using a common explosive, the entire batch will be red carded " under suspicion " until the cause of the difficulty has been isolated. I can tell the honorable gentleman that I believe we are about at the end of a quite serious run of difficulties with ammunition and we are back in production with most of it. I expect most of the difficulties to be cleared very shortly.

talk.start.para: - Will the Minister for Immigration explain why he toned down his reference in yesterday's "Hansard" to the "social peregrinations" of a Russian Orthodox Archbishop who wished to visit this country?
- Did the honorable gentleman say that I toned down my answer?
- Why did you delete a word?
- Why did you alter your answer in " Hansard "?

- I am not conscious that I made any vital alteration to the "Hansard" report. I altered the word " Communist " to " Communist controlled " in referring to an organisation. As far as the reference to social peregrinations is concerned, my conscience is clear. I do not remember making any alteration in that regard.
- You left out the word " social ".
- Let us be clear on this. I made no alteration to anything that I said about the man's social activities.

- I ask the Treasurer a question. As it is apparent that the Government has no detailed information about the amount of overseas investment controlling individual Australian industries - that statement was given in reply to a question placed on notice by the honorable member for Indi - will the Treasurer say whether information of this nature can be traced through the exchange control of the Reserve Bank of Australia when details of profit repatriations overseas are requested?

- I do not quite perceive the purpose of the honorable gentleman's question. It has been the policy of the Government to encourage investment from overseas in order to expand the industries of the Commonwealth and to provide work opportunities for Australia's growing population, including immigrants who come to this country. The Government has not felt cause for concern at the dimension of this investment. There are aspects of the investment which have been referred to as not being so desirable as some other aspects, but I have yet to learn that there is any Government concern at the dimension of overseas investment in Australia. Some honorable gentlemen opposite who talk about the Canadian situation might be interested to know that dollar investment in Australia is and has been over recent years about one-fifteenth of United States investment in Canada. The honorable member for Gippsland is shaking his head. What is he really getting at?
- A record of the types of investment.

- From our own knowledge of what is happening in the economy, I think we can have a pretty good idea of the kind of investment that has been occurring in this country. I believe that Australia, in the main, has been greatly benefited by it.
. - Pursuant to section 14 of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act, I present the following paper -

quote.para: Commonwealth Grants Commission Act - Commonwealth Grants Commission - Thirtyfirst Report (1964).

talk.start.para: - On what date was the report signed? How long have you been sitting on it?
- It is customary to table the report at the time when the relevant legislation is introduced.

debate.para: Bill - by leave - presented by Mr. Harold Holt, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The main purpose of this Bill is to authorise the payment in 1964-65 of special grants totalling £15,860,000 to the States of Western Australia and Tasmania. The payment of these grants has been recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in its Thirty-first Report which has already been tabled. The Bill also authorises the payment of advances to

Western Australia and Tasmania in the earlier months of 1965-66 until such time as Parliament authorises the payment of special grants for that year. A similar provision has been included for a number of years in the legislation authorising payments of special grants to the claimant States.

Under the procedures currently employed by the Commission, the special grants recommended for payment each year consist of two parts. One part is an advance payment based on the Commission's assessment of a claimant State's financial needs for the year in which the grant is to be paid. This part is subject to final adjustment two years later when the Commission has completed its examination of the audited results of the States for that year. The other part of the grant represents the final adjustment of the advance payment made two years earlier.

In accordance with its usual practice, the Commission has arrived at its recommendations by making a detailed comparison of the Budgets of each of the claimant States with those of the standard States, particular account being taken of differences in levels of expenditures and efforts to raise revenue. As in the three preceding years, the Commission has taken the States of New South Wales and Victoria as the standard States for the purpose of these comparisons. The special grants which the Commission has recommended for payment in 1964-65 and the special grants paid in 1963-64 are set out in a table which, with the permission of the House, I incorporate in " Hansard ".

In deciding the adjustments to the advance payments made to the claimant States in 1962-63, the Commission examined the Budget results of the standard States of New South Wales and Victoria and adopted an amount of 5s. 6d. per capita as the deficit Budget standard to be applied in respect of that year. After comparing the level of services and charges, the Commission has recommended grants which would have the effect of leaving Western Australia with a small deficit to fund and Tasmania with a balanced Budget result for 1962-63.

In arriving at its recommendations as to the amount of the advance payments which should be made to the claimant States in a financial year, the Commission makes a forecast of the amount of financial assistance likely to be justified for the year of payment. To estimate the likely Budget standard for that year, the Commission examined the Budget prospects for 1964-65 of the two standard States - New South Wales and Victoria - and concluded that, on the basis of existing policies, a deficit standard for 1964-65 would be appropriate. The advance payments recommended by the. Commission would, on the basis of preliminary estimates submitted by the claimant States, leave both of them with prospective Budget deficits for 1964-65.

In total, the special grants recommended for payment in 1964-65 are £4,140,000 greater than those paid in 1963-64. The effect of adopting the Commision's recommendations would be to increase by about £7,040,000 the total general revenue grants - that is, the financial assistance grants based on the Commonwealth Statistician's latest estimates plus the special grants - payable to the two claimant States this financial year. For Western Australia the increase would be approximately £4,484,000 and for Tasmania approximately £2,556,000.

The increase of £4,410,000 in the special grants recommended for payment to Western Australia and Tasmania in 1964-65 arises partly because, on the basis of its assessment of the Budget outlook for the two standard States, the Commission adopted a much lower deficit Budget standard for 1964-65 than that adopted for 1963-64. In addition, the Commission adopted a new method of comparing the levels of expenditure on social services in the claimant and standard States which has yielded a result considerably more favorable to the claimant States than the method previously employed.

The Grants Commission's recommendations have been adopted without amendment in every year since the Commission was established in 1933. The Government considers that the Commission's recommendations regarding special grants for Western Australia and Tasmania in 1964-65 should be adopted. I therefore commend the Bill to honorable members.

talk.start.para: .- I offer no physical opposition to the motion but I am anxious to make one or two comments. When a similar motion was last placed before the House the Opposition had given notice of a motion of censure and I did not seek on that occasion to intervene. 1 took the view that a motion of no confidence took precedence over all other matters. But on the previous occasion when a similar motion was proposed - that is to say, on 2nd September last - I had this to say -

quote.para: I do not intend to place an obstacle in tha path of this motion, but I do want my honorable friend the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Hasluck) to accept my assurance of my determination to press to a vote the matter standing in my name under Notices of Motion. I simply want to say that in regard to this notice of motion timing has become quite critical.

speech.para: That was on 2nd September. Before a week was out, the very proposal that was the subject of the motion in my name on the notice paper had been implemented. I interrupt myself, Mr. Speaker, to give you my assurance that in no way will I refer to that matter or to any collateral issue.. I am referring now to the timing and the manner in which the Government has treated private members of the Parliament and the rights of private members.

It is hardly credible that on 2nd September the matter I had referred to would not have been known to the Minister or to the Government. I do not suggest for one moment that a Minister or the Government is under any obligation whatever to take any notice of a private member's motion. There is no Standing Order to that effect; there is no parliamentary convention to that effect. But I do venture to say that there exists a powerful case on the count of common courtesy for the Minister on behalf of the Government to have come to me on 2nd September or one day subsequent to that date, or better still to have come to the House and made a statement informing the

House of what would happen. I am not complaining for having been tossed from a horse, as it were. I have been thrown from horses before. But I just want to say to the Government and to the Leader of the House (Mr. Harold Holt) that it has been my invariable practice when thrown from a horse to get back on the horse with a little stick in my hand.

This is the second occasion upon which this matter has been treated in what 1 would describe as a cavalier way. On the first occasion the House had before it a private member's motion, the motion was debated and the debate was adjourned. The next thing that happened on that matter about which honorable members, the Parliament and the country knew, was that a Press statement had been made outside the Parliament. That is not to be defended on any ground whatever. The proper place for such a statement to have been made was in the House and I propose to cite two authorities to show that this is so. The first authority I cite is the Governor-General, Sir Ronald Munro-Ferguson, in 1918, who, in writing to the Prime Minister, had this to say -

quote.para: I would strongly urge that the announcement be made in Parliament, and that for the following reasons. I have taken my stand on the absolute pre-eminence of Parliament, and on my inability to recognize party exigencies, or to have official cognizance of any happenings or utterances outside the parliamentary arena. Therefore, to allow Parliament to meet after a commission has been granted, and to allow it to remain in ignorance of this important fact until a party meeting has been given the information, is to ignore the principle on which I acted in granting you a commission. I would, therefore, strongly advise that you make the announcement in Parliament, whose supremacy it has been my object to vindicate.

talk.start.para: - Who said that?
- That was the Governor-General writing to the Prime Minister in 1918.

speech.para: I venture to say that the manner in which the Government had left the Parliament on the first occasion was absolutely scandalous. Standing Orders absolutely forbid any question being asked on a matter that is the subject of a motion. No honorable member could comment on the matter. I believe that the Government or the Minister could at least have moved for the discharge of the notice of motion from the notice paper. If the Government or the Minister takes the view that 1 may have been angry at their action, so be it, but I do give the assurance that, whereas I may have nibbled at the Minister a little, I think I could have controlled myself to the point of refraining from stark cannibalism.
The second authority I quote is the present Leader of the House, the right honorable member for Higgins. This is what he had to say, and I join with him completely -

quote.para: I have always felt as a member of the Commonwealth Parliament that the first responsibility of a member is to the Parliament, and through it to the people - not to the political party to which he belongs, or to the Government that he has helped to maintain in office. He has a primary responsibility to the Parliament as an institution, because it is the instrument of the democracy that elects him. He should adhere firmly to the principle that the Parliament should at all times control the Executive, which derives its authority from the Parliament.

speech.para: I say quite flatly that in the last Parliament the Government would not have dared to have behaved in the way it has treated a private member's motion on this occasion. It would not have dared at all. I want to renew my simple assurance to the Minister and to the Government that I will continue to press for a vote on the matter that rests in my name at the present moment.

The last comment I make is this: If Ministers are so captivated with the vision of the brave new world that they will sit down and allow the brave new world to arrive without any complaint at all, and if the state in its judgment decides that it will be beneficial for the whole of mankind to take oral contraceptives, I have no doubt that the Ministry will be uncomplaining about it and, looking at some members of the Ministry, I have no doubt in some cases it will work.

talk.start.para: . - by leave - In 1901 the Seat of Government Act, which established Canberra as the nation's capital, envisaged the city as the centre of Federal administration and the seat of Parliament. This in itself called for the early establishment of an administrative and cultural centre with the prospect of a more impressive one to come in line with the expected growth of Australia and the national economy.

speech.para: The idea of a National Capital crystallised in 1911 with the launching of an international competition for the design of the city. The successful design demanded development worthy of the Australian nation, which would compare favorably with other national capitals. The Canberra plan, despite initial difficulties, was accepted, and subsequently gazetted in 1925. An era of rapid development under the guidance of the Federal Capital Commission then followed, culminating with the opening of the interim Houses of Parliament in 1927. Shortly after, city development entered a period of relative stagnation created by, first, severe economic, and then wartime, conditions.

Dissatisfaction with the rate of progress towards the fulfilment of the capital led to the setting up of a Senate Select Committee in 1954 to inquire into the development of Canberra. The report of the Senate Committee stressed the need for unifying the main activities involved in the development of the national capital and recommended that these activities be the responsibility of a separate commission with statutory powers. The Government of the day acted on this advice and accordingly the National Capital Development Commission was set up by Act of Parliament in 1957.

This Parliament has, of course, always taken a direct interest in the growth of Canberra. The Commission, through its annual and special development reports, has kept the Parliament closely in touch with all aspects of the development of this city. Population growth has been particularly rapid in recent years. The plan for Canberra, prepared some fifty years ago, envisaged a city of 25,000 people with space for an ultimate 75,000 population.
Canberra has passed this mark, and the progress which has been made can be seen around us.

The Government sees the continuation of this recent development, the ordered growth of a modern National Capital, as a joint venture between Government and private enterprise. The 100,000 population mark should be passed in 1967 and it is confidently expected that the city will have reached 250,000 in 20 or 25 years time. The central offices of the administrative area of government will progressively be located in Canberra. Substantial developments will continue in tertiary education and research, commercial and professional activities and the tourist industry.

Growth to the 250,000 population appears as if it will go forward at a rate no greater than has been experienced to date. If anything the absolute annual growth rate will tend to drop. The city has now gathered an impetus of its own making. The kind of stimulation which the Government itself has provided in the past is now becoming less evident as the city develops a strong commercial momentum in parallel with any other Australian city of comparable size.

So the vision and foresight of our Parliamentary predecessors can now be seen expressed in physical terms and continuing dynamic growth is expected. This situation has obviously called for equivalent foresight for the future ahead of us of the present generation. The need for an expanded plan arose, one which would look forward in general terms for up to fifty years and examine in some detail the requirements of city growth to the 250,000 population level. The result of this work is in the report which has now been tabled before this Parliament and which sets out the basis for the future development of Canberra.

The report, " The Future Canberra ", is in two parts. The first deals with the character and qualities considered necessary to Canberra's identity as the National Capital, the land use arrangements proposed, the services required and the physical form the city might take. Part 2. of the report examines the growth factors affecting Canberra and contains references to the administrative arrangements related to planning and development.

In the particular situation that exists iq Canberra, with land in public ownership, the authorities responsible for planning and development on behalf of this Parliament are presented with a unique opportunity of guiding and fashioning growth in a manner which will achieve the highest measure of convenience and amenity for the residents within a framework of economic development, and which will guarantee achievement of the character and qualities required in areas of national significance. I believe this plan makes adequate provision for future needs both predictable and unpredictable but it is flexible to meet the unknown. We must in Canberra take every opportunity to avoid the problems that beset other cities when development is unplanned, haphazard and opportunist.

One final point relates to the pattern of city growth predicted in "The Future Canberra ". The plan proposes a series of new districts grouped around the national and major central city areas but separated from it by broad belts of open land and connected by major transport routes. The new districts will each be made up of ten or more suburbs and will have district centres which will supply most of the district needs and act as large employment centres. The choice of this pattern has been influenced by the requirements of a carreliant community, which Canberra, in line with national trends, will increasingly tend to be. The form proposed can satisfy the requirements of community convenience, safety and effective economic operation. The geographical spread of the city brings future growth close to the Australian Capital Territory-New South Wales boundary, and this in itself is a matter which must receive increasing attention, particularly the need for an effective regional plan.

Even the casual reader of this report might ask what financial commitments are involved in implementing this plan. Obviously the Federal Parliament has a close and continuing interest in the development of Canberra. This interest will continue to be effectively supported by private enterprise. But let me say that the development of a city under the orderly conditions set out in this report, enables the operation of a highly economical form of urban development. One must consider the growth returns that are accruing to the Commonwealth from Canberra's development and note the extent to which these are being used to the benefit of the Australian taxpayer and, indirectly, the Canberra community.

This report, placed before the House today, has further convinced me that Canberra will be a large city and that it will be a handsome city with all the qualities that one would expect to find in an Australian national capital reaching maturity in the second half of the twentieth century. In due course the city plan as now envisaged will require gazettal and this will bring it, I trust, before the informed scrutiny of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. I repeat that proposals are not so fixed that they cannot be amended in the light of informed criticism. The report serves to focus attention on this Parliamentary city and to remind each of us that the future is affected by today's preparations.
I now Sir, for the information of honorable members, present the following report -

quote.para: The Future Canberra - A long range plan for land use and civic design - Report by National Capital Development Commission- and move -
That the House take note of the paper.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr. J. R. Fraser) adjourned.

debate.para: Department of Labour and National Service.

talk.start.para: . - I propose to devote my attention to expenditure of the Department under the control of the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon). From the Department and through the Minister the Government draws its advice with respect to conciliation and arbitration in Australia, how the system is functioning and its needs. If the Department is up to date the Government learns also the result of any relevant legislation passed by this Parliament. It is rather appropriate that the Committee should be discussing the estimates for this Department and the ministerial responsibility for it at this stage, because I think it can be said that at this moment the nation is faced with a severe upturn of industrial unrest. After hearing the Minister's replies to questions asked yesterday and today I pose this question to the Committee: Why has this taken place? To answer this question, perhaps at the outset I should draw attention to what I believe to be the result either of very bad advice that the Minister is receiving from his Department or of the Minister's lack of appreciation of what is happening industrially in Australia at present. When I think in terms of the dispute at General Motors-Holden's Pty. Ltd. and the manner in which the Minister dealt with questions yesterday and again today - yesterday in particular - I say that either the Minister is out of touch with the basis of dispute, or the Department of Labour and National Service is not providing him with the type of information that he should be receiving. Yesterday the Minister said in reply to a question -

quote.para: This strike is being manipulated by Mr. Carmichael, a notorious member of the Communist Party in Victoria. . . .

speech.para: A little later he said -

quote.para: Carmichaels name should be mentioned because he is one of the most evil men in the trade union movement in Victoria.

speech.para: I say with the greatest respect that I believe the Minister said that on the advice of his Department, that it was a foolish statement, the kind of statement that the unionists, particularly those in an organisation like the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, find hard to believe of a department and a Minister at this point of time. It was the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation that took this dispute to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Nobody will convince me that the Minister, if properly advised by his Department, and if the Department is doing its job, is not fully aware of the impact of what is happening in industrial disputes, particularly disputes of the character I am now discussing.

If the Minister was receiving proper advice from his Department, surely at the time when the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation took the dispute to the A.C.T.U. he would have understood that there was no question of Carmichael or of Communist leadership, but that this was a case of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation and the A.C.T.U. versus G.M.H. Along with today's Press report of what the Minister said yesterday, in the same paper and under the same heading, there is a report of a statement by the president of the A.C.T.U.-

quote.para: We feel the strike should continue.

speech.para: This was said by Albert Monk - not Carmichael. Later in the report the leader of the A.C.T.U. is reported as having said that the strikers did not appreciate the attitude of G.M.H. in refusing to discuss the wage issue with the A.C.T.U. negotiating committee, which was ready to confer with the company at any time. This was said at the very time that the Minister in this place was referring to Carmichael as being the backbone of the dispute. I say to the Minister that if this is the kind of advice that he is getting from his Department it is time that he had a good look at it.

The real background to this whole problem is the present conciliation and arbitration legislation, which is a running sore in Australia. The fact is that the trade unions today are not going to arbitration for their wage increases; they are indulging in strike action because they find that it brings better results than they can get from arbitration. So the whole system of arbitration as we have it in Australia at present is disintegrating. Carmichael cannot be blamed for this. The disintegration started from the day that this Parliament put penal provisions into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. On the day that penal provisions were put into the Act conciliation cut out. It is as plain as the nose on one's face, if one were looking into the mirror, that what G.M.H. is doing at the moment is waiting to see what the result will be on Friday, which is the day on which the unions are summoned to appear before the Commonwealth Industrial Court. Each of the five unions will be fined £500. Some, including the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation have three charges against them, so they will be fined £1,500. Nobody- neither the Minister nor anybody else - will try to tell the

Committee, surely, that the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation is being led or pushed around by any set of Communists. The situation is that the trade unions today are finding that the penal provisions in the Act - I said this at the time the provisions were inserted into the legislation, I have repeated it in this chamber and now we have proof of it - have created a coward's castle for bad employers. Bad employers set a principle that the employers generally are following.

When the Minister said yesterday that Carmichael was now formulating the planning of this dispute, surely he understood that out of this the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation membership will increase. He should make no mistake about that. In today's Press there is a statement of the attitude of the leaders of G.M.H. The report says -

quote.para: Mr. Heglandsaid the company was always willing to meet the A.C.T.U., but there certainly could be no negotiations for an " across the board " increase.

speech.para: The A.C.T.U. quite rightly says at this stage: " If we are going to come in on the negotiations we are going to do it on a proper basis. We are not going to discuss this in circumscribed areas laid down by G.M.H." But the great damage done in respect of this is that when the Minister or anybody else here tries to tell us in 1964 that this kind of dispute is being run by Communists they are merely building up the Communists.

talk.start.para: - Nonsense. Do you deny that Carmichael controls it?

- Let me deal with it. I want now to refer the Minister to the actions of a Premier of his own political kidney, the Premier of Victoria. I want to show him, using Victoria as an example, what is happening to the industrial arbitration system under the laws as they are at present. Before the Victorian State election a stoppage of work in all public utilities occurred in Victoria. The Premier of Victoria promised the unions that if they were good boys until after the election he would meet them. The Premier did meet them, but at that meeting they did not get very far because the Premier asked the Trades and Labour Council to set out for him the information that they had as to the basis of the problem. The council set about putting the information before the Premier. Let me now remind the Committee of the type of information that the trade union movement put before the Premier of Victoria. It submitted three and a half pages listing over-award payments made by 160 different firms. Each over-award payment was decided upon outside conciliation and arbitration as founded in this Parliament under the rotten legislation that we now have. I shall not deal with all of the over-award payments in general industry to tradesmen fitters, but I shall take three at the top of the first page. The "Age" which is a Melbourne newspaper pays a fitter £30 15s. which represents an over-award payment of £10 2s. A.R.C. Engineering pays its tradesmen fitters an over-award amount of £5 7s. per week The Australian Synthetic Rubber Co. Ltd. makes an over-award payment of £3 per week. I do not want to go through the 160 firms which are listed. I turn to page 2, and find that Dunlop Aviation pays an over-award amount of £3 12s. The same amount is paid by Dunlop Industries. Daylesford Centenary Woollen and Worsted Mills makes an over-award payment of £2. The "Herald and Weekly Times" Ltd. pays to every tradesman fitter £9 7s. 6d. over and above the award, outside arbitration as defined by this Parliament. These are big companies. Looking at the third page, I find that Massey Ferguson (Aust.) Ltd. pays £4 6s. over the award rate. Malcolm Moore Industries Ltd. £3 17s. and Mindrill Ltd. make £3 16s. 6d. in over-award payments. Milford Distributors Pty. Ltd. pays £4 17s. over and above the margin prescribed.

speech.para: The point I want to make is that when the Premier of Victoria analysed the true position of the unions which have followed conciliation and arbitration - and this applies to my union, the Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen - inside Victorian services, he found that to do any kind of justice at all he had to increase the wages of his own employees by amounts between 9s. and 42s. per week. The employees never asked for such amounts in many respects, but this action was taken by the Premier to mete out some kind of industrial justice to the employees of the State. Because the Victorian Premier corrected the injustice, he completely disregarded the legislation of this department and its Minister, and he wrote the agreement with the Trades Hall Council. That throws aside completely the arbitration act as we have it, and forgets all about the provisions of section 31. That is where we are with conciliation and arbitration today. There are two groups of employers in this country. There is the bad employer who gets in under the cover of the penal provisions of the Act all the time, and then there is the other type of employer who can easily pass on over-award payments and, therefore, does not caTe what wages he pays.

talk.start.para: - Is the honorable member for or against.

- I will tell you what I am for. I am for a clean conciliation and arbitration act which will properly restore conciliation to the arbitration machinery of Australia, free of penalties. Both sides should have their cases considered equally and they should be free of penalty. As I am reminded, the dog collar should be taken off them. Both parties should get together free of penalty to discuss their problems. In that way conciliation will be arrived at. The stage has been reached in Australia today where conciliation and arbitration are being completely disregarded. I know the sad example provided by my own union which, on 31st August 1962, was refused marginal increases by the full bench of the present Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Now, at the end of two years, as the result of stoppages and information put before the Premier of Victoria, the members of my union have been granted increases of amounts up to 30s. a week. Increases had been denied to them by the Commission on 30th August 1962.

speech.para: What is the answer to this problem? What can trade union leaders say? This kind of thing will continue to happen until such time as employers and employees are put on an equal footing in respect of our conciliation and arbitration machinery. The conciliation commissioner would sit in with the parties to ensure that everyone was given a fair go and the employers would have to come to the meeting and take what was reasonable in respect of employees. Unless this is done, there will be a continuance of disputes such as the one involving General Motors-Holden's Pty. Ltd. Make no mistake about it; the unions will get some increase out of this dispute with that body.

A few minutes ago the honorable member for Higinbotham (Mr. Chipp) asked me where I stand on this question. The policy of the union I represent and for which I stand firmly is conciliation and arbitration. But we have reached the stage under our system where the Premier of a State, in order to try to give some degree of justice, grants an award quite outside our own award and quite outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Act passed by this Parliament. Justice has been denied by the conciliation and arbitration machinery. Our present machinery has put the trade union movement back in this country to where it was long before the Second World War.

Until such time as we overhaul the Department of Labour and National Service, and also our conciliation and arbitration machinery, we shall go from one bad spot to another in industrial relations, mainly because the Government has stuck to its view on penal provisions which, let me repeat, are the coward's castles for bad employers. In this way the present situation has arisen, and trade unions are taking the type of stand that is being taken with General Motors-Holden's Ltd. Trade unions cannot be pushed around. The dog collar cannot be put around them. You cannot get away with that. Until such time as those facts are realised, we will not obtain the type . of conciliation and arbitration in which we believe.

.- I wish to say something about the Department of Labour and National Service and particularly the national service section of that portfolio. The Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) has assured me on a number of occasions that he has kept on in his Department the key personnel who are necessary to enable him to amplify and build up at any time he is required to introduce a register for national service training. This is very wise and is the sort of thing which should be done. Unfortunately, this has not been done as far as the Department of the Army is concerned. The Department of the Army should have kept, in my opinion, the staff, instructors and officers necessary for a national service training scheme and have kept training them. These people should have been retained within the ranks of the Department when national service training was abolished in 1958. At that time, a measure was introduced which retrenched those personnel - got rid of them - and they were sent willy nilly to industry. The Department lost their ability to carry out national service training for the Army.

speech.para: This fact, to my mind, has been exemplified time and time again. The Minister for the Army (Dr. Forbes) stated in the House quite recently that national service training could not be introduced in the near future because the Army was short of sufficient officers and instructors to enable even an intake of very limited and moderate numbers. The position is that the ability of the Government to implement national service training has been catered for by the Department which will do the registration, but not by the Department which will train the people so registered.

The Minister for the Army has said that a national service training scheme will take a good number of officers and instructors. I think he mentioned that 1800 officers would be needed to cover all demands. It is true that we have a Regular Army of a certain strength but we know also that it requires to be built up to an effective divisional strength. This has not been achieved by the voluntary system of enlistment, because enlistments have not increased despite the expenditure of quite large sums of money on recruitment advertising. I think the amount budgeted for in this respect this year is £750,000. If we are not obtaining personnel for the Regular Army, we certainly are not getting them in the Citizen Military Forces either. Most units in respect of other ranks are only about 50 per cent, of full strength. Everybody knows or should know that if ever we are required to mobilise we can move these Citizen Military Forces units only at such time as they are fully manned and that the man in the street who volunteers, or is called up on mobilisation, has to be properly processed and trained. This processing takes months and months, and at the present time we might not have months and months to spare.

As far back as 1912, the late Andrew Fisher introduced a form of universal military training which was terminated in 1929 in favour of the voluntary system which has continued since then and which is the basis of our present C.M.F. Under this system, training was much the same as in the C.M.F. You had your night training periods, and you had your weekend and fortnight camps. Over a period of about two years we got fairly effectively trained people. The number of regular officers and instructors required was very small indeed. To each regiment would be attached one captain or lieutenant as an adjutant, one regimental sergeant-major and one regimental quarter-master sergeant from the Australian Instructional Corps. The Citizen Military Force unit supplied officers and non-commissioned officers - instructors and leaders - from its own ranks.

Something must be done about national service training. I feel that we should introduce a system of universal military training that would always be with us - not one dictated by the strategic considerations of the day - and under which young single men between the ages of 19 and 26 years are called up for at least three years' active service, thereafter going on the reserve list. Some great advantages would accrue from the introduction of such a scheme. Firstly, under such a system, all those between the ages of 19 and 26 years who were medically unfit would be weeded out. Secondly, all those engaged in reserved occupations would be registered and their call-ups deferred. Thirdly, all processing such as the preparation of record books and pay books, the listing of blood types and even the giving of vaccinations could be done early. When people were eventually called up, the particulars noted in the national service register would make it easy to allot them to units in which the experience gained in their civil occupations could be used to the best advantage. Many people do not realise the detailed work involved in mobilising a unit.

There is one difficulty that would be peculiar to Australia in the event of mobilisation. It relates to our large migrant population. Many of us do not realise the difficulties, due to language, to mention one factor, that would be experienced in any call-up or preparation of a manpower register. As a matter of fact, 19 per cent, of the 3.7 million births in Australia since 1945 were to migrant parents, and one in four of all the children under 21 years of age in this country today either was born overseas or has at least one migrant parent.

The Department of Labour and National Service is ready and able to expand its activities in order to provide us with a manpower register, but the Army, which would be taking the majority of the people, maintains that at the moment it is not able to provide enough officers and noncommissioned officers as instructors. I suggest that all that would be necessary to implement a scheme such as I have suggested for the training of young men between the ages of 19 and 26 years would be perhaps 100 officers and between 600 and 700 instructors and other ranks from the Australian Regular Army. In view of the amount of support there seems to be at the moment for national service training, I feel that a scheme such as the one I have suggested would appeal to the public. It would not involve any question of a selective draft. Every young man between the prescribed ages would be called up.

A further advantage of such a scheme would be that remote areas such as Darwin and Perth would have Citizen Military Forces units of greater strength than they have now. If we cannot have a major national service scheme, then at least let us have the scheme I suggest, because it would show our allies, especially the United States of America, that we were making some effort to shoulder our share of the burden. Under such a scheme, young men would be taken out of production in civil occupations for only 14 days in each year, compared with taking 15,000 men each year out of production under any other scheme. In these days of labour scarcity, I feel that my scheme would commend itself to the employer, the employee and to the general public. Another advantage would be that the young men called up and trained under it would provide a good source of recruitment for the Australian Regular Army.

I feel quite strongly that, irrespective of any limited form of national service training which might be required to meet the strategic difficulties of the moment, we should, as a matter of military policy, introduce a scheme such as the one I have outlined today. As I have pointed out, all our young men would then be registered. Everything would be known about them. The unfit would be weeded out, the call-up of those engaged in reserve occupations would be deferred and all general processing and administrative work would have been completed. These things should be done in this country today. The public are most uneasy about the situation. The Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) has said that we are living in a time of risk. There is tension abroad. If we are to give the general public of Australia a feeling of security, we must take some action. If we cannot have a full national service training scheme, then let us have the universal training scheme which I am advocating. If we adopt it, our manpower will be registered and all other preliminary work will be done. If it should become necessary to mobilise for any reason, we shall be able to do it quickly and effectively.

I recommend the scheme to the Government. I hope that the Government will consider it, remembering that it would have no adverse effect upon a call-up for general national service training should that ever become necessary. If it were found necessary to have a selective call-up for one year or two years, the Government could still do that without being inhibited by a shortage of instructors and officers. In fact, my proposal would ensure that ample officers and instructors were available to carry out an effective national service training scheme if the strategic demands of the day made that necessary.

talk.start.para: . - As we are now discussing the estimates for the Department of Labour and National Service, I should like to take the opportunity to say something further about the proposition put forward recently by the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) for an adult training scheme. This infamous scheme is designed to do nothing other than break down the wages and working conditions of the members of the various craft unions operating in our community. Despite the fact that the employers, especially those engaged in the metal trades and the building trades, are making fabulous profits, they are still deter- mined, with the connivance of the Minister for Labour and National Service, to make further savage and vicious assaults on living conditions generally. As I have pointed out before, the Minister's statement about the shortage of craftsmen is, to say the least, inaccurate. The shortage of craftsmen is due solely to the greed of the employers and the action of the judges of the Commonwealth Arbitration Commission in stubbornly refusing to grant further marginal increases.

speech.para: Some years ago, a similar scheme was operating in the metal trades industry under the title "The Structural Steel Workers Award ". As the result of vicious attacks by employers, with the connivance of a judge of the Commission who is now deceased, wages were cut to a degree which caused grave discontent in the industry. I myself was one of the victims of these savage assaults which lasted for many years until organised labour succeeded in securing a consolidation of the various awards and a general improvement in wages and conditions. Of course, the clouds of war were hovering over the world, but now, since the termination of World War II and after a period of peaceful existence, the avaricious employers, with the able assistance of the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon), are redoubling their efforts to destroy working conditions and standards of living which now exist for members of the craft unions. Recently the honorable member for Mallee (Mr. Turnbull) asked the Minister a question and in his reply the Minister said -

quote.para: I have frequently pointed out to the House that there is a serious deficiency of skilled workers in this country arid that in the critical industries there are 10 vacancies for each person registered for employment. That illustrates what the honorable member for Mallee said. There is an immense deficiency which must be cleared up if development is to proceed at the rate at which the Government wishes it to proceed.

speech.para: I give the lie direct to the Minister's statement, and I repeat what I have said before, that I have statistics from my own organisation - the Boilermakers Society of Australia - which has closely examined the proposal put forward by the Minister and closely examined its own accurate records, particularly over the period from 1954 to 1963. This period was analysed by the Department of Labour and National Service. The Boilermakers Society found that in that period no fewer than 8,853 people left the Society and the trade, and that considerable numbers of these - thousands in fact - were still members of the Australian community. Despite this tremendous drift from the trade the overall membership of the Society in that period increased by 9,074. It is still increasing by about 800 a year. I would like honorable members to take note of these figures.

In this period the Society, by relaxing its policy in connection with bona fide tradesmen, permitted no fewer than 7,315 workers to enter the Society as provisional members. These are people who have not served an apprenticeship in the trade but who have proved themselves capable of carrying out the work. They have come from lower-paid, unskilled or semi-skilled occupations to the more highly paid trade of boilermaker. However, the analysis shows that of these 7,315 workers no fewer than 5,634 have left the trade. The basic reason for this is that much higher wages can be obtained in other occupations. Another interesting point is that 60 per cent, of these people are in the 20 to 40 years age group.

The trade unions have consistently tried to have the wages and conditions of tradesmen improved. Even more consistently this Government and the employers have endeavoured to maintain wages at unreal low levels. I claim that the Government itself is one of the worst offenders, as shown by an advertisement in the Sydney "Sun" on 30th September 1964. The advertisement was as follows -

quote.para: Tradesmen required for Garden Island Dockyard. Applications are invited for the positions listed (several vacancies in each trade).

speech.para: Peanuts! I got those wages 20 odd years ago when I was working at the trade as a boilermaker, and I would refuse, like- many thousands of the members of my organisation have refused today, to work for such low rates of pay. I think it is an insult to the average tradesman to ask him to work for such wages, and it is an insult perpetrated by the leaders of our Arbitration Court in offering workers such poor rates of pay on which to keep their families and maintain their homes. If the Minister believes that he can induce skilled tradesmen to work for such rates of pay he has another think coming. I can tell the Minister from my knowledge of what goes on within my organisation that if he wants to secure the necessary workmen for the Garden Island dockyard he must increase the rates of pay to a decent level.

Much has been said in this chamber about the urgency of the adult training scheme so as to give employers the green light to help destroy the craft unions which are, in reality, the backbone of the trade union movement. Of course, we do not see the same enthusiasm, especially by gentlemen of the calibre of the member for the Mallee, for the extension of the scheme. Might I suggest that the Minister take steps to extend this scheme to cover other people - auctioneers, for instance?
