Everyone admits, and must admit, that we have some snide operators among auctioneers. Then, of course, there are estate agents. I think we should have an adult training scheme for estate agents. When we have due regard to the advice that the Government receives on economic matters, I think the adult training scheme could be extended to cover professors of economics. Our gaols are so full of criminals today that apparently our legal profession is very weak, so perhaps the adult training scheme could be extended to the legal profession. In this way we might provide more legal men. The scheme could be extended, too, to cover professional engineers and ' professional accountants. When one takes into consideration the number of companies which are going into liquidation one sees a need for a greater number of instant accountants and other professional men among the members on the other side of the House who are joining in the giant conspiracy to destroy the trade union movement generally.

Do honorable members opposite realise the blood and sweat behind the construction of the sleek diesel monsters that travel our railroads, behind the graceful lines of our luxury liners that sail the great oceans of the world making luxurious travel possible? Do they realise what is necessary to construct the great cargo carrying vessels which transport our produce to all parts of the world? Do they appreciate what is involved in the construction of our aircraft carriers, battleships, destroyers and submarines about which our Minister for the Navy (Mr. Chaney) talks so glibly? Do honorable members opposite realise the work that goes into constructing our steel military vehicles - tanks and so forth - which are essential for the defence of Australia? Is the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) too naive to realise that without its skilled craftsmen Australia will remain undefended, despite the size of its Army or Navy, or does he believe that the instant tradesman he is going to create will be able to fill the bill?

I would strongly suggest to the Minister that he direct his undoubted energies to inducing or directing the various captains of industry - despite the fact that they are great supporters of this Government - to engage their full quota of apprentices so that all sections of industry in Australia will be able to fulfil their obligations in the event of an emergency. If he directs his energies into that channel he may be sure that he will receive the full support of trade unions generally, which are most anxious at all times to forward the interests of our great nation. The Minister must remember that in the next six or eight weeks some 85,000 school leavers will be available for apprenticeship to the various trades. Let him bend his energies in this direction and see that the employers take their full quota of apprentices to ensure that Australia will at all times have sufficient craftsmen for her needs.

I would like to remind the Minister of the many features agreed upon at the national conferences held by the Amalgamated Engineering Union in October and November 1962 for alterations to the apprenticeship system. The Minister should make a further study of the action of the Arbitration Court in fixing apprenticeship rates of pay. The court seems to accept the idea that apprenticeship rates of pay should be tied to the current basic wage. The paucity of apprenticeship rates of pay should be noted. A first year apprentice gets 42 per cent, of the basic wage. A second year apprentice gets 54.1 peT cent, of the basic wage. A third year apprentice gets 63.1 per cent, of the basic wage. A fourth year apprentice gets 95 per cent, of the basic wage. A fifth year apprentice gets 100 per cent, of the basic wage plus 44s. 6d. I am at a loss to understand how the court arrives at the decision in respect of the fifth year apprentice. Does the Minister not think that the court should base apprenticeship rates of pay on the tradesman's wage? May I urge that he suggest this method of fixing apprenticeship rates of pay to the honorable gentleman of the court? Marginal increases granted to tradesmen should be enjoyed by apprentices, but we find that apprenticeship rates of pay are loaded against the apprentices in favour of the employer who is already making enormous profits.

The suggestions I have made would, if put into effect, help to increase the number of boys seeking apprenticeships in the various trades. The Minister should give some deep thought in the future to the conditions of employment and the wages of apprentices. He should have less concern for the avaricious employer who is making fabulous profits. Employers should not be allowed to make such large profits as they are making today.

If I had time I would let the Minister know what the New South Wales Apprenticeship Commissioner, Mr. E. Boland, has to say on this subject. Mr. Boland is the man selected by the New South Wales Government to look after the welfare of apprentices in that State. The New South Wales Minister for Labour and Industry has stated -

quote.para: Selection of leading prize winning apprentices in connection with Apprenticeship Week 1964 has proved a difficult task for members of the Apprenticeship Councils.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- I do not doubt for a moment the complete sincerity of the honorable member for Kingsford Smith (Mr. Curtin) but I challenge strongly the general line of his argument. It is not my purpose in the short time available to me this afternoon to try to traverse the various points put forward by the honorable member because I want to speak primarily on the estimates for the Department of Immigration. But first I must say one or two things generally about the points made by the honorable member.

speech.para: He said that we on this side of the chamber were joining in a general conspiracy to undermine the trade union movement. He must have been speaking with tongue in cheek when he said that because I am sure that he is aware that the Government, during its 15 years in office, has legislated in a number of ways to strengthen trade unions and the trade union movement. My mind goes back to the early 1950's. I recall that one of the first pieces of legislation introduced by the Menzies Government after the 1949 election had to do with trade unions and the introduction of secret ballots for the election of trade union officials. A glance at any page of any electoral roll will indicate, I suggest, that an overwhelming majority of electors are members of trade unions. Surely it stands to reason that a great many trade unionists support this side of politics. If this were not so we would never be able to form a government. I think the honorable member will have his work cut out in trying to persuade the vast majority of electors who support the Government that we are not the friends of the trade unionists.

I hope the day will never come when we will seek to interfere with arbitration, rates of pay, awards, working conditions and so on. I believe that these matters come strictly within the sphere of operations of those who are appointed for the purpose. I hope that rates of pay, awards, conditions of work and so on will never become a political football in this National Parliament. I will leave the subject there because I want to say something about immigration.

First I congratulate very warmly the Minister for Immigration (Mr. Opperman) and the officers of his Department on the result of the 1963-64 immigration programme. The result was magnificent - even spectacular. Those who are intimately concerned with the administration of our immigration programme deserve the nation's warm appreciation and thanks. The progress made in 1963-64 has been continued splendidly into the first quarter of the current financial year, which we are now considering, and I am absolutely convinced that the rate of progress will be maintained in the months ahead.

In the June and July recess I had the good fortune to make a trip overseas. While abroad I took the opportunity to visit as many as possible of our immigration posts, not only in Britain but also throughout Europe and as far as Cairo. Without exception I was tremendously impressed by the calibre of our officers serving overseas and their staffs. I was impressed by the complete dedication to duty that I observed everywhere. These people do not work by the clock; they work in the interests of Australia. As far as they were concerned, no effort was too great. They obviously were sparing no effort to get the best migrants available to help to build up Australia. They are doing a grand job. I pay a warm tribute to all of our immigration officers who are serving us so well overseas.

I am delighted to know that there has been a substantial overall increase in the appropriation for the Department of Immigration. I am particularly pleased to note the proposed increase in respect of migration officers in the various overseas countries from which we draw our migrants. On my visits to these offices I was very impressed with the efficiency not only of the Australian born staff but also of the locally recruited staff. As other honorable members who have had the opportunity to visit some of our overseas immigration posts will know, those posts recruit a number of personnel locally to assist, particularly with the difficult and intricate task of interviewing prospective migrants.

One particular case comes to mind of a successful migrant from Italy who came to Australia some years ago. He eventually became a naturalised Australian citizen and joined the Department of Immigration. He was so wrapped up in the work of the Department and was so keen to do something to serve Australia that he accepted a posting in Italy. He is now employed in the Rome office as an interviewing officer. I did not see at any other post an officer who was doing his work more efficiently, more pleasantly and more satisfactorily than this gentleman to whom I have referred. I was tremendously impressed with the job he was doing and with the jobs that locally recruited officers were doing everywhere.

The quality of prospective migrants deserves a special mention. I do not know whether I was especially fortunate, but I believe that the interviews that I witnessed were of the average kind. Without exception, the quality of prospective migrants to this country is uniformly high. This, I think, bodes well for the continuance of our very successful immigration programme. As one would expect, some of the posts have their difficulties. For instance, some of them have accommodation difficulties because the job has grown so quickly, the amount of paper work is so large and the staff has had to be increased proportionately. Naturally, those things bring in their wake some accommodation difficulties. But those difficulties are being overcome. Our migration officers certainly are .not allowing difficulties to stand in their way or to hinder them in the job that they are doing. I found uniformly great good will towards Australia. Although the Australian Government is not allowed to advertise for migrants in European countries, at least in most cases there is not active antagonism towards our drawing migrants from those countries. I believe there is plenty of scope for Australian companies and firms to advertise for migrants, skilled and otherwise, whom they may desire to attract.

On 16th August last the Minister for Immigration made a very interesting statement on the current year's immigration programme. In that statement he said that in the current financial year Australia hopes to receive 127,000 new settlers, 75,000 of whom are expected to be assisted migrants. As honorable members know, it is very important for us always to keep a proper balance between skilled, semi-skilled and unskilled migrants. This is no easy matter. It involves keeping a constant watch on the figures. I believe that that is being done very successfully. Until fairly recently, the main emphasis has been on attracting skilled migrants, particularly those who are needed to fill gaps in the metal, electrical and building trades. Of course, there has been a good deal of emphasis, too, on attracting professional men and women to Australia.

It must be recognised that our capacity for absorbing migrants is never constant. It changes from time to time - possibly from quarter to quarter and certainly from year to year. Nor is the availability of migrants from the various source countries always constant. Those facts create considerable adminis trative difficulties. But, as a philosopher once said, difficulties were made to be overcome. These difficulties are being overcome. In Australia, with a flourishing and expanding economy, at the present time we have an increasing demand for labour. The time is coming, if it is not here already, when we will be very short of even unskilled labour. It seems fairly clear that during the remainder of the current financial year there will be a substantial demand by Australian industry for more and more skilled workers, more and more semi-skilled workers and more and more unskilled workers. But, on present figures and present trends, so far as they can be judged, it seems that the flow of migrants in all categories, whom we need so urgently, will exceed last year's figure. I believe that during the months ahead we will need all the migrants whom we can possibly get, because our economy is moving forward so quickly.

One fact that struck me very forcibly was the continued high rate of applications in Great Britain. This is really remarkable. During the northern summer months of June and July, there is normally a falling off in the application rate in Great Britain. I was very interested to ascertain the reasons that lay behind the continued high rate. First and foremost, the reason appeared to be the prospective migrants' concern for their children. They are concerned about their children's economic future. They see in Australia a grand opportunity for their children. I am quite convinced that that is the chief reason for the continued high rate of applications in Great Britain. I believe that it bodes extremely well for Australia during the remainder of this financial year and virtually ensures the success of our immigration programme once again.

I was very interested recently to read a report of a statement by a very senior officer of Qantas Empire Airways Ltd. about a series of massive airlifts that is to take place between Great Britain and Australia during the balance of this calendar year. The statement, which was made by Mr. Angell, the Queensland manager of Qantas, was reported as follows -

quote.para: A total of 10,000 migrants will be flown to Australia between now and the end of the year.

speech.para: He made that statement at the beginning of this month. This is quite remarkable.

No doubt it involves a tremendous amount of organisation. The airways are playing a vital part, just as the shipping companies are, in bringing more and more migrants to Australia as quickly and as effectively as possible. The report of Mr. Angell's statement went on to say -

quote.para: Qantas and B.O.A.C. have joined to make the massive airlift.
Fifty-one of the special migrant flights will be operated by Britannias, which will leave London at the rate of about one every two days until the end of the year.
Twelve special flights will be made by Boeing 707s and four by Comets.
The special flights will bring about 8,000 migrants and a further 2,000 will travel on scheduled services.

speech.para: There seems to be no doubt that our net gain through migration during the current financial year once again will equal approximately one per cent, of our total population.

Let me say how pleased I am that the Minister has been able to express our 1964-65 immigration programme in terms of settler arrivals. I believe that this gives a much clearer picture than it was possible to give in earlier years when the programme was stated in terms of permanent and long term arrivals. I support the Minister's recent plea to migrants who are entitled to apply for naturalisation but who have not yet done so. A large number of migrants - 250,000 at the present time - are eligible for naturalisation, but have not yet applied for it. I am sure that honorable members on all sides of the chamber will join with the Minister in hoping that greater numbers of migrants who are entitled to apply for naturalisation will do so during the current financial year and so acquire the benefits and rights of full citizenship.

Finally, I pay a tribute to my colleagues on the Commonwealth Immigration Planning Council; to the honorable member for Sturt (Mr. Wilson) and the members of the Commonwealth Immigration Advisory Council; to the members of the Commonwealth Immigration Publicity Council; to the members of the Good Neighbour Councils; to Commonwealth Hostels Ltd.; in fact, to all the people who are contributing so splendidly to the success of our very important immigration programme.

talk.start.para: .- In the few minutes at my disposal, I desire to address a few remarks to the estimates for the Department of Immigration. We on this side of the chamber take more than a passing interest in this Department because it was during the term of office of a Labour government and under the present Leader of the Labour Party that our great immigration scheme was inaugurated. It could be termed one of the most successful postwar schemes of our country. I think I should say that the respective Ministers from all political parties and the staffs that have been engaged in the Department since it began have made a great contribution to the success of the scheme. We have been fortunate in having Ministers from various political parties who have always been an inspiration to the Department in the things that have been achieved.

speech.para: I am on common ground with the honorable member for Ryan (Mr. Drury) when I say that the officers of our overseas immigration posts have also made a big contribution to the success of the scheme. Their dedication to their task, the manner in which they have approached it and their general handling of the complicated administrative problems associated with the scheme, particularly overseas, are things in which they may take great pride. My commendation - I am certain that it is echoed by every other member of the Opposition - applies to the previous secretary of the Department, the present secretary, Mr. Heydon, and the officers at all levels in the Department, for the manner in which they have approached their tasks. They have to handle problems which present great administrative difficulties and in respect of which it is not possible to please everyone. I think we should give praise whenever we can to those in the various spheres at home and abroad, from the Minister for Immigration (Mr. Opperman) down, who in their way contribute to the success of the scheme on which we depend so much. I do not say that mistakes are not made, possibly at the ministerial or the departmental level, but I think it would be safe to say that they are genuine mistakes. They may be miscalculations, misjudments or individual opinions, but at no time could it be said that mistakes have been deliberately made in an effort to restrict the programme which was commenced by Labour and which has been continued by the Government.

I notice that the expenditure for this year will total £16,795,000. As the honorable member for Ryan said, substantial increases have been made in the expenditure on the immigration programme, lt is noticeable, for instance, that £10 million has been allocated for assisted migration this year. Perhaps the Minister will, in the course of the debate, give us an estimate of the various targets for the countries in which the £10 million will be spent. This information would be of interest to all honorable members. It would show the wide range of countries from which our immigrants come, and I intend to touch on this matter when I refer to naturalisation.

One or two problems that affect the success of the immigration scheme need to be solved if we are to continue to attract in large numbers the types of migrants we want, and in this regard I refer to both skilled and unskilled persons. One major problem is housing. With other members of an Opposition Immigration Committee I have visited migrant hostels and I am aware of the problem we face. It is a very grave problem and could have a material effect on our ability to attract suitable migrants. Having in mind all the circumstances, I think the hostels provide all that is necessary as a temporary measure. But we will reach the ideal when we can say to intending migrants that a home will be available for them, either for purchase or for rental, within a very short time of their arrival here. Of course, we must ensure that our own people have the same opportunity to obtain suitable housing. At present, housing is not readily available either for migrants or for our own people. We all know of the huge waiting lists for homes in the various States.

The position is aggravated by the fact that the Commonwealth evidently does not take full responsibility for the housing of immigrants. Some discontent is caused when people find that they may be in a hostel for longer than they expected or may not be able to get the type of house they would like. I suggest that the Commonwealth take full responsibility, by making additional grants to the States, for the housing of the people it brings into the country. At the same time, we must ensure that housing for those already living in Australia keeps pace with any immigrant housing scheme.

In this way we would avoid the discontent that must arise if immigrants were given homes while others in the country were not able to find adequate housing. The provision of a home or the guarantee of a home for those coming to Australia as well as for those already here is to my mind fundamental to the success of our immigration scheme.

I want to say a few words about naturalisation. The honorable member for Ryan said that 250,000 eligible immigrants had not been naturalised. That is the figure given to me by the Minister for Immigration in answer to a question on 3rd September. But included in this figure are some 50,000 children. It could be said, therefore, that in round figures we have 200,000 immigrants qualified for naturalisation who have not taken the opportunity to become naturalised. We could well ponder on the solution to this problem. I have a list of the countries of origin of the immigrants who have not become naturalised. It shows that included in the 200,000 are more than 29,000 Dutch people, 25,000 Germans, 29,000 Greeks, 87,000 Italians, 13,000 Polish and 15,000 Yugoslavs. These people are apparently qualified in every way to be citizens but have not taken advantage of the opportunity to become naturalised. What is the reason for this? I know that the Department has commenced inquiries, and the problem has been mentioned at Australian Citizenship Conventions held in Canberra.

The number of these people in Australia always stays at about 200,000. As politicians, we have more than a passing interest in the problem, because these people are not taken into account, for instance, in the assessment of electors when electoral noun? daries are fixed. As members of the Parliament we are called upon to provide them with all the services we can, but they neither vote for nor against us and they do not participate in the political life of the country. But they enjoy the advantages of living here. If the 200,000 immigrants who are not naturalised were added to the list of electors, roughly another four or five electoral divisions would be established throughout the Commonwealth. This is an important aspect of the problem and, of course, I do not wish to canvass it now. However, it does show that the provision that electoral boundaries shall be determined by the number of people on the roll is out of date and that electoral boundaries should be determined by the number of people of all ages living in the area. If this were done, these people who have not become naturalised would be included in the figures used to determine the electoral boundaries.

Apparently the Department of Immigration has not been able to find the solution to the problem of eligible immigrants not becoming naturalised. I do not suppose that we could insist on these people becoming naturalised. The voluntary approach apparently is preferred. But if we are to have constantly some 200,000 people not naturalised, though they are qualified, the voluntary approach will take a long time to be really effective. I think the Department is considering a possible solution to the problem, but I wonder whether it has ever considered sending a questionnaire to a cross-section of these people to ascertain why they have not become naturalised. If this were done we would have some understanding of their feelings on the subject. After all, naturalisation does not entail a great deal of trouble.

I do not know what can be done to improve naturalisation ceremonies, but they should be pepped up a bit. Some of the ceremonies are rather gloomy. I do not know whether it is possible to have a band play at the ceremonies or some other feature of this type. As they are at present conducted some of the naturalisation ceremonies are not exactly an exhilarating experience. One night I calculated that if everybody spoke at a ceremony I attended, about 20 of us would have made speeches. I think only eight or ten of those present took advantage of the opportunity to make a speech. I do not say that speech making at these ceremonies deters people from becoming naturalised, but it is a factor associated with the ceremonies that might be curtailed.

I want to say a word about a subject that is not exactly associated with European citizens. From time to time the Department faces problems that do not arise from our established immigration programme. Criticism is sometimes levelled at the Department for certain action it takes in regard to people who have overstayed a student's visa or a visitor's permit. It is sometimes said that the Department is acting harshly. I think that newspapers publish ing such criticism without knowing all the facts or caring to print all the facts of some of these cases do a great disservice to the country and are most unjust to the Department. I do not know all the circumstances of all these cases, but I have seen the Department and the Minister being unjustly criticised for asking some people to leave the country. In some instances I have known that the facts have been totally different from what has been published in the newspapers. I think the newspapers could well copy the American Press on matters of this nature. They would do better if they realised that those concerned are not trying to be unjust to these people but are trying to administer our laws in a reasonable way. Every honorable member knows, and every citizen should know, that anybody entering a country does so on certain conditions. When the time comes for such a person to leave the country he should not object if, he having broken the conditions of his entry, the Government accordingly takes action to see that the conditions are observed. Some years ago I was in Czechoslovakia. I had a permit to stay there for four days. It appeared .that I would not be able to get out of the country before my permit expired, because an aeroplane flight had been cancelled. I spent most of the fourth day trying to get a permit to stay longer; I had been told that I would have great difficulty staying in the country without such a permit.

Students who come to Australia from other countries and who fail in their examinations may be asked to leave. Students who have completed the courses for which they were admitted to this country may be asked to leave, although they wish to stay here instead of returning to their own countries to give expression there to the learning and knowledge that they gained by their studies in Australia. I do not consider that any government, whatever may be its political complexion, can be blamed for asking such people to leave this country and for taking appropriate action to ensure that they do leave.

Visitors to Australia have obligations to observe the terms and conditions laid down for the granting of entry permits, and they cannot be unduly critical of the Department of Immigration if it asks them to leave Australia because they have failed to fulfil their obligations. The Department, after all, is only discharging its responsibilities. I do not suggest that it necessarily is right in every instance in which it asks people to leave Australia, but I cannot agree with those who take the view that every person from overseas who is asked to leave Australia has a good case to remain here. All people from other countries who are admitted to Australia know, and should understand, the terms and conditions on which they are allowed to enter. I do not object to actions taken by the Department in trying to administer the immigration laws tactfully. The job is difficult and ticklish. I believe that the Department is at times subjected to unjust criticism by the Press as a result of actions that it has taken in endeavouring to discharge its responsibilities under the Migration Act 1958, which, I think, was passed by this Parliament unanimously.

Time will not allow me to elaborate the subject further, Mr. Temporary Chairman. I just express again my thanks to the Department of Immigration on behalf of members of the Opposition's Migration Committee for the co-operation that the Department has extended to the members of that Committee in their efforts to examine the immigration scheme and objectively study its ramifications. I record the appreciation of all Australians who have seen the growth of the immigration scheme of the efforts of those immigration officers who have contributed to the bringing to Australia of more than 1,750,000 migrants since the war. Their efforts are appreciated particularly by migrants who have been able to come to this free country and participate in all that goes with our way of life. 1 hope that the Minister for Immigration will be able to assure us that something can be done to solve the housing problems associated with the immigration scheme. We should also like a list of the various targets set under the assisted passage scheme for the ensuing year. I sincerely trust that a wider range of skilled immigrants will be brought to Australia, for they can make a marked contribution to our progress as a fast developing country.

talk.start.para: .- Mr. Temporary Chairman,like the two preceding speakers, I wish to congratulate the Minister for Immigration (Mr. Opperman) and his officers on the work that they have done and are continuing to do. Recently, I travelled from Western Australia to the eastern States on a migrant ship. In the course of the voyage, I came in contact with a number of migration officers on board. I wholeheartedly agree that wherever one comes in contact with officers of the Department of Immigration, whether in Canberra, in the various States or on board migrant ships, one finds that those officers are doing wonderful work and carrying their efforts far beyond what may reasonably be expected of them. This is particularly so on board migrant ships, where they are active early and late. I found that nothing was ever a trouble to them.

speech.para: Immigration has become big business in this country. The fact that the estimates for the Department this financial year total £16,795,000 is evidence of this. Throughout Europe, we have officers trying to recruit more migrants. The whole programme is tremendous, for it entails a great deal of planning, advertising, interviewing, selection, arranging of transport to Australia, education of the migrants for the conditions that they have to expect on arrival here, placing them in jobs when they reach this country and integrating them into the Australian community.

All sorts of problems crop up in the process of integration into our community. I have spoken to a considerable number of social welfare officers about these matters. They have told me that the children of migrant families quickly become absorbed into our way of life and rapidly become Australians. This often poses problems in the home, for the parents feel that they have lost their children and that the children will not learn what the parents regard as their mother tongue. As a consequence, all sorts of pressures build up in the home. If we are to keep the immigration programme functioning smoothly, we must continue follow up procedures after migrants arrive in this country and achieve better understanding between migrant parents and their children who, possibly, are the most valuable migrants of all in the long run.

The honorable member for Grayndler (Mr. Daly) said that housing of migrants presented problems. So it does. This is particularly so in New South Wales. The problems are not nearly so great in the other States, as far as I can ascertain. My inquiries suggest that not many migrants remain in migrant hostels or camps for any considerable time. The turnover is pretty rapid and very few families remain long. Where a man with a family is not quite certain that his job is suitable, there is a certain measure of inducement for him to remain in a migrant camp or hostel with his wife and family for a brief time until he feels settled in his work. This seems a sensible arrangement for there is provision for the schooling of the children and the training of the women in our way of life and methods of shopping. This is to the advantage of all concerned.

As honorable members have heard, the immigration programme was eminently successful last year, for about 127,000 migrants were brought to Australia. Approximately 50 per cent, of these were active workers and a large proportion of the workers were skilled. I believe that, on the whole, those who have had anything to do with the immigration programme will agree that we are now probably getting migrants of better type than ever before, lt is not easy to get the right sort of migrants now because Western Europe is enjoying a boom. Admittedly, in the last few months, the number of applications received from the United Kingdom has increased greatly, but even that country does not look with favour on our taking many of its best and most skilled workers as migrants. As a rather interesting sidelight, I was told recently that West Germany had just had a team of officials in China looking for unskilled and semi-skilled workers. This indicates the shortage of workers in Europe and the difficulty that we shall have in obtaining skilled migrants. In Switzerland, one in four workers is a foreigner. West Germany already is competing with us for skilled workers.

After I returned from my recent trip overseas, I spent several days at the Bonegilla migrant centre. I should like to pay a special tribute to Colonel Glynn, who is in charge of that centre, and who has made the job there his life's work. He is soon to retire and he expressed to me his great regret at having to leave the centre. He has done a wonderful job in trying to make the way of the migrant easier. He has done much to make the surroundings appear more welcoming and to make migrants more comfortable. Colonel Glynn has developed the centre as a lovely area on the banks of the Hume Reservoir, having planted thousands of trees and provided all sorts of amenities. He and the staff have gone out of their way to make conditions very much easier for migrants and to make them feel welcome while they are there.

I sat in with several officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service while they were interviewing migrants for jobs. Some of these officers speak several languages and others have an interpreter. On the occasion to which I refer, the officers interpreted to me the statements made by the migrants in outlining their various qualifications. The experience was extremely interesting to me. One of the most striking features of the employment situation is the fact that there are six or eight jobs available for every skilled migrant. At ' the Bonegilla migrant centre, there are good schools for the chil-den. The members of the school staff, obviously, are dedicated to their work. I saw children of many nationalities joining together in Australian games and very quickly developing the kind of outlook that will make them valuable Australian citizens. No effort is spared to make the women folk feel that they are capable of playing their part in providing for their families and becoming integrated into the Australian way of life. All kinds of social amenities are provided, such as canteens, recreation halls and libraries. There are social workers doing their best to make things easier for the migrants and to help them generally. I believe the Minister and his officers are doing a tremendous job, but I do not think that the job finishes with them. I think that we as old Australians, if you like to use that term, have to play our part.

Many problems crop up. One came to my notice recently in my own electorate. It is a matter I have discussed with a number of officers of the Department. I do not know the answer and the departmental officers do not yet know it. I refer to the problem posed by many single men who come here and take jobs, for instance with the Snowy

Mountains Authority. They consider this a wonderful country. They can earn good money. They work a six-day week in conditions of ice and snow which they have been used to in their homelands. After a few years, when a migrant has amassed a tidy bank balance, he becomes a little unsettled and starts to look for a wife so that he can settle down. But we all know that there are just not enough women available in the Snowy area. As I said, I do not know the answer. I know what happened some time ago when the immigration authorities brought out girls from Greece as prospective brides. I do not think they will try that again. However, this is a very human problem and it must be solved if we are going to make our immigration programme completely satisfactory. Until we settle these excellent young men and have them rearing families we will not have completely solved our immigration problems.

I have made suggestions about this matter from time to time. Some of them have not been too well received. I have thought that we might allow some of our naturalised men to go back to their original homelands and select brides. With some of them this might work quite well, but perhaps it would not be a satisfactory solution with others. But I still feel there is an answer to be found. I believe that some of the troubles that have arisen with certain political associations having overseas affiliations have resulted from the fact that young men cannot settle down. They drift to the cities and because they have nothing better to do they rejoin the old political organisations, some of which we do not welcome here. I believe we must give very serious thought to this problem.

In conclusion, I want to make an appeal for more of our own Australian born citizens to do something about extending the hand of friendship to these immigrants who, after all, have taken a very serious step in leaving the land of their birth and coming across the world to live in Australia. We need them desperately if we are to hold and develop our country. As the previous speaker suggested, something might be done in the naturalisation ceremonies. I have attended a number of these. I represented the Minister at a ceremony in Canberra recently. Only last week I attended a ceremony at Junee. This is just a little town, but many of the people there turned out and gave a wonderful welcome to those who were being naturalised, and a social evening followed. We who have lived here all our lives could hold out the hand of friendship in this fashion to the immigrants. This is particularly necessary in the case of the womenfolk who spend their time in the home and have not the same opportunities of muting with others as have the children and the men of the families.

Our great immigration programme is of vital importance to this nation. It is something that concerns all of us. I think we must all consider again our own parts in the programme. The immigration authorities and the Minister are doing an excellent job, but they cannot do it properly without our support. 1 commend the Minister and his officers for their excellent work.

talk.start.para: .- I shall deal with the estimates for the Department of Labour and National Service, with particular reference to the scheme proposed by the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) for the training of apprentices and to the supplementary adult training scheme that he has suggested and on which he has prepared a paper. The scheme envisages that the adult trainees will undergo a six months' technical training course, after which they will move into industry and from then on receive practical training. I have before me a copy of the curriculum prepared by the Broken Hill Pty. Co. Ltd. for the training of boilermaker apprentices in Newcastle. This course covers two years, and, of course, the apprentices during that time also spend four hours each week at the technical college.

speech.para: I have been critical of this company on many occasions. I have criticised its financial structure, the profits it has made and certain other aspects of the organisation, but I must admit that the company does a good job in training apprentices. It has a school in Newcastle for these lads. My colleague, the honorable member for Cunningham (Mr. Connor), will no doubt have some knowledge of what the company does along these lines at Port Kembla. However, I can tell the Committee that the company's school for apprentices in Newcastle is excellent. The curriculum covers two years for each apprentice, whether in the boiler-making trade, the fitting and turning trade or the electrical trade. This training is given to the boys at the time of life when they are most impressionable, just having left school. I challenge the Minister to convince the Conn t:ee that he can impart to adults in six months knowledge that the Broken Hill Pty. Co. Ltd. has decided takes two years for apprentices to acquire. If the Minister can do so then I will agree that he has a much better scheme than I think he has. A scheme involving only six months training will riot and cannot, in my opinion, be a success.

There are other aspects of the scheme with which I strongly disagree. There is the provision as to the trades in which adults are to be trained. Then there is the composition of the Committee that the Minister has forecast. It will comprise a chairman appointed by the Department of Labour and National Service, two representatives from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and two other members who will advise the Minister for Labour and National Service. The position is, therefore, that there will be two representatives from the union, two representatives of the employers and a chairman appointed by the Department of Labour and National Service. In my opinion the unions will not accept this proposition for one moment, because the voting will always be three to two against the unions. In this Parliament we continually see the Minister displaying an attitude antagonistic to the trade union movement. In my view the members of the Minister's Department are also anti-trade union. The trade union movement would not be right in the head if it accepted this proposition and co-operated with the Minister in this scheme because it is obvious that the voting would always be three to two against the unions. That is why the unions will not have any part of the scheme.

There are other aspects of this matter that I would like to refer to. This is a subject on which one could talk at great length. On page 4 of the publication circulated by the Minister on 9th May we find references to allowances for trainees. It is provided that trainees will receive, during the period of technical college training, a living allowance, supplemented if required to live away from home, and a fares allowance. They will also receive books and assistance in acquiring tools of trade. Why is it intended to give such preferential treatment to adult trainees when none of these advantages is enjoyed by the ordinary apprentice, who has to buy every technical book necessary for his training and has to buy every one of his tools? The Minister is prepared, in order to curry favour with somebody in connection with this scheme, to provide these things free of charge for adult trainees. Apprentices cannot even claim as a tax deduction the cost of purchasing books when they are attending technical college. On these figures it is obvious that the Minister is trying to make conditions as favorable as possible for adult trainees, while completely disregarding conditions which should be granted to apprentices while they are serving their apprenticeship and undertaking their training.

I refer now to the Commonwealth role in training apprentices. I have prepared, from information supplied to me by various Ministers, a table showing the number of apprentices in the building, electrical and metal trades, the Postmaster-General's Department, Commonwealth Railways, Department of Works, Department of Supply, Department of the Navy, Department of Air, Department of the Army and Department of Interior. With the concurrence of honorable members I shall incorporate the table in " Hansard ".

As the table has been incorporated in "Hansard" I shall not refer to all the figures. However, at page 6 of the publication that he circulated the Minister said that Commonwealth departments and authorities have taken more apprentices, so I shall cite some figures to show what the position is.

In the table I have shown figures for the last three years for the Postmaster-General's Department, Commonwealth Railways, Department of Works, Department of Supply and Department of the Navy. Unfortunately I have not the 1962 figures for the Department of the Navy, but I do have the figures for 1963 and 1964. Therefore, for the departments that I have mentioned I can give the figures accurately for 1963 and 1964 only. In 1963 the departments I have mentioned employed 8,980 tradesmen, whereas in 1964 they employed 8,875. In 1963 those departments employed 1,841 apprentices, and in 1964 they employed 1,839. On those figures alone, two apprentices fewer were employed by Commonwealth departments in 1964, so I fail to see how the Minister can honestly and conscientiously make the claim that Commonwealth departments and authorities are employing more apprentices. The Commonwealth is one of the worst offenders so far as the quota is concerned. It does not employ its quota of apprentices. In 1962, on figures I have before me, the quota of apprentices for the Commonwealth was 3,121, but the Commonwealth was employing 1,799 under its quota. In 1963, when the quota for the Commonwealth was 4,216, it was employing 2,435 under its quota. In 1964, with a quota of 4,214, it is 2,393 under its quota. From those figures honorable members will see that in reality in 1964 the Commonwealth departments to which I have referred - P.M.G., Railways, Works, Supply and Navy - should have been employing an additional 2,393 apprentices. If the Minister and the Government were genuinely trying to employ and train apprentices they would have provided for young people who have not had the opportunity of being trained. Therefore, I say that the Commonwealth Government is one of the worst offenders in employing and training apprentices. It is time something of a practical nature was done to provide employment for these young people instead of the Government trying to introduce a scheme for adult training.

In order to show the real position in industry today I should like to go quickly through some figures with regard to the Boilermakers Society of Australia which show the number of vacancies and the number of men who have left the trade. In 1963, for example, 2,380 joined the union and 1,229 left the union. It might be said that those who left the union were all old blokes who were getting out of the trade. I should like more time to enable me to go through this question in detail, but in the time available to me I shall give the Committee some idea of the ages of the people who left the union. In the September quarter of 1961, four people under 20 years of age left the union, 111 over 20 left the union, 97 over 30, 62 over 40, 12 over 50 and five over 60. In the September quarter of 1963, four under 20 left the union and 108 over 20, 77 over 30, 36 over 40, 8 over 50 and 6 over 60 left the union. Those figures show what is taking place. A young fellow completes his apprenticeship and says: "They have fooled me long enough. For five years I have been an apprentice. It is time I started looking about and got better employment with more money than I am getting at the moment." That brings me to the point that I want to make today. The real reason for the shortage of tradesmen in industry is that tradesmen are not paid enough money.

On 22nd October 1963, I received an answer from the Minister to a question I had asked about margins for tradesmen. The answer revealed that on 15th May 1935 a 3s. marginal increase was granted. This brought the tradesman's margin to 41 per cent, of the then basic wage, which was £3 6s. On 23rd February 1937, which was the date of the last marginal increase before the war, a further increase of 3s. brought the tradesman's margin to 44.1 per cent, of the basic wage. On 18th April, 1963, the tradesman received a marginal increase of 10s., which brought his margin to £5 6s. That represented 34.8 per cent, of the basic wage, which was then £14 8s. With the recent increase of £1 in the basic wage the tradesman's margin as a percentage of the basic wage is only 34.4 per cent, or about 10 per cent, less than it was before the war. That is one of the major reasons for our shortage of tradesmen. If the tradesman's margin were restored to the percentage of the basic wage that it had in 1937 it would now be about £6 15s. 6d.

Every time the unions make an approach to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for an increase in margins the employers, the Government and many other people are opposed to it If we want tradesmen and if we want to hold tradesmen and keep young fellows from leaving trades, as people have left the boilermaker's trade, the only way is to pay them more money. When it is realised that those young people can go out into unskilled occupations and in those unskilled occupations receive more money than they would receive as tradesmen, it must be appreciated that if we want tradesmen and want to hold them in industry and encourage the young fellows leaving school to accept an apprenticeship so that they will become tradesmen, the only way to do it is by paying them more money. I suggest that the present scheme for adult training proposed by the Minister will not work. The scheme is unacceptable to the trade union movement. I firmly and strongly support the opposition of the Electrical Trades Union of Australia, the Boilermakers Society of Australia, the Amalgamated Engineering Union, the building trade unions and all the other unions that are opposed to the Minister's scheme, because I believe for the reasons that I have outlined that the tradesman's margin must be increased. If the margin is increased we will get the men for industry.

I know that the Minister has said in this chamber that there are insufficient school leavers applying for apprenticeships. All I can say is that in Newcastle early this year, after all the boys had been placed in apprenticeships, I carried out a survey of the high schools in Newcastle and found that 70 boys who had passed their intermediate and had sought an apprenticeship were unsuccessful. As a result, they went back to school and are now in their fourth year. I referred the cases of five of those boys to the Minister.

talk.start.para: - Three.

- I referred the cases of five boys to the Minister and it took him three months to find employment for only two of them. If the position is that there are insufficient young men available for apprenticeships today I believe the time is not far distant when young girls leaving school will have to be encouraged to take apprenticeships. When I visited Russia some years ago I found that in many industries there were as many women as there were men following the trades of boiler-making, fitting and turning, electrical, carpentry and all the rest of them. In the war years in Britain and in Australia we employed women in the craft unions to do the same work as men. They were employed as welders, fitters and turners. If you go through industry today you will find many women doing the same class of work as the men. I believe that they should likewise be given opportunities in those crafts.
- Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

speech.para: Mr. CHIPP(Higinbotham) 15.351. - I would have thought that there are few departments of the Commonwealth and, indeed, few portfolios, which require more humane understanding, and more tact, and which contain more complex problems than the Department of Labour and National Service. I would have also thought that the records of the present permanent head of the Department, the present Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) and, indeed, his predecessor, in the field of human understanding and human relations are quite outstanding. Their doors are never closed to any approach, whether it be made by a union or by an employer. It disturbs me to hear the honorable member for Newcastle (Mr. Jones) stand in his place in this chamber and attack not only those gentlemen but also the Department in its entirety allegedly for adopting an inhuman attitude towards unions. The honorable member for Newcastle alleged that this Department which has several great public servants at its head - I am forgetting about the Minister for the moment - is always on the side of the employer. It is all very well for the honorable member to make such an allegation. It is a very different thing for the honorable member to produce one bit of evidence to support that allegaion, which, of course, he has neglected to do.

I wish to speak about the waterfront and the stevedoring industry in this country. I believe that here we find one of the most important problems facing the nation today. Why is it important? It is important because I believe that the events which take place at Port Melbourne, Fremantle, Pyrmont and the other waterfronts of Australia affect the lives of every family in this country.

Firstly, Australia is an island continent and we are dependent for most of our commerce and livelihood on what comes in and what goes out in ships. We are one of the ten great trading nations of the world and the manner in which cargoes are loaded and unloaded is vital to our way of life. Secondly, our rate of development as a nation depends on our overseas balances. The behaviour of men on the waterfront has a vital effect on the price of our exports. We are told by the Department of Trade and Industry, as I have said before, that we must increase our exports by £300 million per annum in the next ten years or so. All these exports must leave the country via the waterfronts of this nation. To sustain our present immigration programme, we must increase our exports to the figure that I have mentioned. The third, and certainly by no means the least important factor, is defence. When we are committed to an emergency, most of our men and supplies must be loaded on the waterfronts of Australia. Therefore, we arc virtually in the hands of the employers and the employees in the waterfront industry.

To give an example of the importance of this matter regarding defence, I wish to refer to a time a few months ago when a group of people, namely, the leaders of the Waterside Workers Federation of this country, made a political decision. The Federation believed that Australia as. a country should not send barbed wire to South Vietnam to protect the people in strategic hamlets. This union took upon itself to say: " We will not load this material for South Vietnam ". I remember vividly that in 1945 when I was a member of the Royal Australian Air Force as an aircrew trainee, I was pulled off my course in Western Australia and forced by the Government of the day to work on the Fremantle waterfront because so-called Australians at that time who were loading and unloading cargoes had struck in time of war.

talk.start.para: - You are one of those?

- Yes, I am one of those. If you have any name to call me - and I know the word that is in your mind - let me say that I am proud to be a man who would load cargoes during war time to send to men in our fighting lines which apparently the honorable member's friends on the Fremantle waterfront decided not to do.
- It is all right. We just want to know what you are proud of.

- Honorable members would have liked to know your real political beliefs. However, if the problems of this industry are so important, are we satisfied with the present conditions on the waterfront? I say as a member of this Parliament that I am not satisfied with those conditions. I am not satisfied with the performance of the labour force and, at the same time, I am not satisfied with the performance of the employers as far as the waterfront is concerned.

speech.para: On the question of the labour force, may I make some quotations from the report of the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority for the year ended 30th June 1964. This report was published only a few days ago. It; is littered with criticisms of the industry both from the labour force point of view and the employers point of view. On page 8, it says -

quote.para: Notwithstanding the improved loading rates for some cargoes, the lower handling rates for others, which include exports, is a matter of serious concern.

speech.para: At page 11, the report goes on to say - for the nine months ended 30th March last, although waterside workers represent 0.6 per cent, of all civilian and salary earners, the time lost by them for that period accounted for 7.1. per cent, of the working days lost by all industries in Australia.

I suggest that this paragraph alone is sufficient to cause us concern. In the month of August of this year, 114,000 man-hours were lost on the Australian waterfront. This compares with an August average over the last three years of 21,000 man-hours lost. Almost six times the number of man-hours were lost in August of this year compared with the normal monthly August man-hours lost. Why were these man-hours lost? One of the reasons why a great stoppage was held was that members of the Waterside Workers Federation of this country decided to go on strike because they objected to the apartheid issue in South Africa. This group of people, being responsible to no-one but themselves, decided to produce absolute chaos in at least five ports in Australia on an issue which is completely outside their jurisdiction. I visited the Sydney waterfront a few weeks ago together with members of the Government Members Industrial Relations Committee of which I have the honour to be chairman. I wonder when the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron) was last on the waterfront in this country. I sometimes wonder whether the response he would get there would be similar to the one he would get if he ever returns to New Guinea. However, when we were on the Sydney waterfront the number of ships tied up was six, but the average number of ships usually tied up is thirty. That morning, when I left my home in Melbourne, Port Phillip Bay was littered with ships which had been tied up by members of this Federation which, I say now, is dominated by members of the Communist Party.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member for Hindmarsh makes a facetious remark. lt is devastating to me to find a member of the front bench of the Labour Party who seems to find some amusement in the fact that the waterfront of this country is controlled by members of the Communist Party whose philosophy is dedicated to overthrow this Government by force. One would have expected the honorable member to set the lead to members of this union and not to encourage them by poohpoohing any criticism of them. I will give some figures about the Waterside Workers Federation. As far as I can gather, nine of the 28 members of the Federal council are card carrying members of the Communist Party.
- One-third.

- There are 15 members of the Australian Labour Party on that council, and the four other members of that body are not known. The honorable member for Hindmarsh says "one-third" as if it does not matter, but I wonder how those members of the Communist Party were elected to this council. I wonder whether any of them stood on unity tickets with members of the Australian Labour Party of whom 15 are members of this council. There are seven members of the Communist Party on the executive of the Sydney branch and six among the 15 members of the Melbourne branch executive. Are these men so badly treated that they should strike so much? Are they stood over by a 19th century boss who will sack them at a moment's notice? Do they live in constant fear of being dismissed by their employer and being unable to earn a just wage? I have not the time to read out some of the privileges that the members of the Waterside Workers Federation enjoy, but I say that the members of this union, man for man, enjoy more privileges than do the members of any other union in Australia. But, whilst they have the greatest number of privileges, their conduct is the most irresponsible of all unionists in this country.
- That is a great boost for their Communist officials.

- The honorable member for Hindmarsh can champion the Communist officials of the Waterside Workers Federation if he so chooses, but I say to the decent men in the Federation: "Despite the fact that some Communists may, by their militant action, have got you privileges better than those enjoyed by any other union, that is not everything, because we are playing for very big stakes in this matter ".

speech.para: What is the solution of this problem? A great deal of the fault lies with the shipowners and the stevedores. These people seem to be singularly reluctant to come forward with any concrete proposals as to how the Government can assist in cleaning up this industry. What action can be taken by the Government unilaterally? This is a difficult question. I ask the Government to examine the constitutional issues involved in writing into an act of this Parliament a provision making it unlawful for Communists to hold office in any union. I ask honorable members, both on this side of the chamber and on the Opposition side, to show some courage and to stand up against the Communist scourge which threatens to take us over. The tragic truth is that this nation is being held to ransom on its waterfront at this point of time by members of the Communist Party.
Let rae turn to the employers in the few minutes I have left. The Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority states in its report -

quote.para: During the year, delays in the performance of stevedoring operations due to the failure of registered employers to comply with their obligations numbered 75 and caused a loss of 3,611 man hours.

speech.para: That is not a record of which the employers can be proud. I say that too many stevedores try to stevedore the ships from plush offices five miles down the town, away from the job. I say to the stevedores: " For too long too many of you have been operating on a cost plus system, not caring a hoot about what the unloading of cargoes costs the community. " I say to them that there are several honorable members opposite who would dearly love to nationalise this industry. That idea is being punted around this place at the moment. I say to the stevedores that while they have a Government which champions free enterprise, while they have a Government which believes in free enterprise, they have the opportunity to do something to prove their bona fides.

I make a plea, not only to the stevedoring companies but to companies generally, to improve the management of their concerns. Too many companies are appointing to their boards of management outside directors who have no knowledge or experience of the industry concerned. There is a form of nepotism creeping into Australian industry today. If you are a retired senior Army officer, or if you know somebody else, it is easy to get a seat on a board at a lucrative fee. That is just not good enough in a developing country. It does not happen in the United States of America. If we are to increase our productivity then we - management, labour, members of Parliament and, indeed, all sections of the community - have a joint task constantly to examine ourselves, our efficiency and our sense of responsibility.

talk.start.para: .- I would have considered the remarks of the honorable member for Higinbotham (Mr. Chipp) to be facetious if I did not know the man, his antecedants and his proclivities. I would like the honorable member to come with me to Port Kembla, the sixth port of this nation. I would like him to accompany me on a tour of a major industrial port. I have the honour to represent nearly 800 waterside workers, all good workers, good citizens and loyal Australians. To a man, they are supporters of the party to which I have the honour to belong. I would like the honorable member for Higinbotham to come with me to, say, No. 3 Wharf at Port Kembla harbour, to cough, spit and do his best to work in the sulphuric acid fumes which come with every southerly wind from the fertiliser plant at Port Kembla.
- I have done it at Perth. Have you ever done it? I have.

- Yes. I would like the honorable member to come with me when the westerlies are blowing for six months of the year and the iron ore dust is cutting out the eyes of these men. I would like him to come with me when the north-easterlies are blowing and when men's lungs are being filled with coal dust from another plant. I would like him to come with me to the berth of Australian Iron and Steel Pty. Ltd. at the inner harbour, where men are paid special dirt rates because of the difficulty they experience in breathing owing to the iron ore dust with which the atmosphere is saturated.

speech.para: The waterside workers of my constituency have to their credit an act of patriotism which not even the ineffable remarks or sneers of the honorable member for Higinbotham can erase. They had sufficient political prescience and sufficient national consciousness to advocate the banning of the exportation of pig iron to Japan. They knew our enemies, and they knew our friends. These same men knew what was needed for Indonesia, and they advocated liberation for that country. These same loyal Australians are today advocating the equality of man - and they are quite correct - in their stand on apartheid. There is no industry in which the employees have a better knowledge of what is happening in other parts of the world than the waterfront industry, because the men working on the waterfront are in direct daily contact with the crews of ships of all the nations of the world. They know exactly what is happening, and all credit to them.

Lest the honorable member for Higinbotham should mislead the Committee, I should like honorable members to study the improvement in the loading rate of various cargoes at Port Kembla. These men on the waterfront see before them the menace of mechanisation. They can see what has happened in the sugar ports of Queensland with mechanisation. The days of lumping are gone, the days of bulk loading are in and the days of employment for hundreds of waterside workers have ended. These men can see the mechanised hatches; they can see the container methods of shipping cargoes today; they can see the roll-on roll-off ships that are now in operation; they can see today the menace of mechanisation in every phase of navigation. What is the alternative? Where will they turn? They are men who have been trained to do waterfront work and nothing else. It is difficult to absorb them in other fields of activity.

These men are loyal Australians. I fling back in the honorable member's teeth the base accusations he has made. Shame on him, shame on the party that he represents and shame on the principles that he advocates. Shame on an honorable member who will get up in this Parliament and sneer at, smear and traduce good, honest, decent Australians. Shame again.

The main subject of this discussion is not the waterfront. I fully appreciate the usual red herrings which the honorable member tried to introduce to save his Minister from embarrassment. The main issue today is the capacity of industry to pay increased wages, and a monumental struggle is being waged at General MotorsHolden's Pty. Ltd. It is a monumental struggle indeed, because this Government will be hoist with its own petard. It is a matter of common knowledge that the Australian Council of Trade Unions will be again applying to the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for an increase in the basic wage consequential on the price increases which have been proved in the two most recent quarters. When the application comes before the court the Government's advocates will be there stressing the inability of industry to pay, and opposing an increase accordingly. What company is there in Australia today better able to pay increased wages than General Motors-Holden's, a company whose profits are an affront to our collective social conscience? It is a foreign company, incidentally, which is reputed to get a gross profit of at least £200 to £250 from every unit it manufactures. This is the company which the honorable member for Higinbotham, the Minister and honorable members opposite collectively would have us believe cannot afford to pay. A new principle is certainly being evolved; and the pattern is very clear in the United States of America where the United Automobile Workers, led by Walter Reuther, have established the principle of collective bargaining. The days have ended when you can frustrate and hold up unions and delay indefinitely wage claims. Let them be brought to the bargaining table. Let the employers pay the worker his fair due. All credit to the Australian worker for what he has done in the way of production. The Holden car is something of which he can be proud. The establishment of the works is something of which we can be proud, but the profits and the distribution of the profits are a scandal and a shame.

talk.start.para: - Get your facts straight.

- I have my facts absolutely correct, and the honorable member knows it. You will have the opportunity, if you so choose, to rebut them. We hear much of conciliation and arbitration. We all pay lip service to what is alleged to be a wonderful principle. But, in point of fact, is there arbitration today? Arbitration means an agreement by two people on equal terms, of equal status, to forgo voluntarily the normal processes of law and to submit to a chosen umpire points of difference between them. What is the position with regard to our so-called arbitration system? It is a system of coercion. Australians can be led, but they can never be driven. The coercion that exists today is a shame and a scandal.

speech.para: I have met trade unionists from other parts of the world, including the United Kingdom, and they look with amazement at our system of arbitration with its penal provisions. They look with amazement at our system of penalties. The right to strike is a fundamental right. It is a right which will never be abandoned by the trade union movement. It is a right which will be exercised fairly, decently and with just cause. Today trade unionists do not strike unless they have an adequate cause and until after proper negotiation. Workers do not want to be met by an iron fisted refusal to negotiate. They do not want to be dragged into this coward's castle to which the honorable member for Blaxland (Mr. E. James Harrison) so ably referred - a place of delays, a place of frustration, a court of pains and penalties, a court presided over by jurists, eminent men in the legal profession undoubtedly, but what knowledge have they of economics or of the struggle in everyday life? What knowledge of that have honorable members opposite? How many of them even hold a ticket in a trade union? Let them stand up and be counted. There is not a single trade unionist in their ranks and yet they presume to tell us, the chosen spokesmen of the trade union movement, how the trade union movement should run its organisation.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: - To resume my comments on the appropriations now before the Committee, I would like to remind honorable members of the urgent need, as expressed by all responsible spokesmen in all sections of industry, for a complete overhaul of the system of conciliation and arbitration. The system of fixing wages and of settling disputes is, to say the least - to place the most charitable interpretation on it - antiquated in the extreme. As I said before the sitting was suspended, we have at present a system which is not one of arbitration at all. The word " arbitration " should be excised from the Act. The essence of arbitration is for equal parties with equal rights and status voluntarily to forgo the normal processes of litigation and submit their common issues in dispute to the arbitrament of an umpire duly appointed by them and whose awards they are prepared to accept. To put the matter in a nutshell, arbitrators do not impose sanctions. Yet sanctions are the very lifeblood of today's so-called system of arbitration.

speech.para: Before the suspension of the sittingI was referring to the types of jurists who are appointed to the arbitration court. I have a very great respect for the judiciary. Having had legal training I understand the requirements of the judiciary in the normal courts but when you are dealing with matters relating to wages, costs and profits you are in an entirely different sphere from that of deciding proprietary rights, of awarding damages for actionable wrongs, of determining breaches of the peace and of enforcing statutory and common law obligations upon individuals. I think the germ of the correct idea was incorporated in 1947 in the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act by the Chifley Government, which referred to the need for a special committee. Section 81aa. enacted in 1947 read- (1.) For the purposes of this Act there shall be an Office of Economic and Industrial Research. (2.) The functions of the Office shall be -

item.label: (a)
item.para: to collect and compile, in accordance with the directions of the Chief Judge, information which may be of assistance to the Court and to Conciliation Commissioners in the exercise of their powers and functions under this Act;

item.label: (b)
item.para: to keep information so collected and compiled up to date; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: to carry out research in respect of such matters as the Chief Judge directs.

speech.para: The point is this: Judges are not omniscient. In the complexities of modern society it is utterly impossible for judges, notwithstanding the breadth of their experience on the industrial commission, to adjudicate on the complexity and diversity of the problems associated with a modern, expanding and extremely diverse industrialised society. I think - this is only my opinion - that there is a strong case for special tribunals to consider special industries. That may be a solution to the problems of the automotive manufacturing industry.I cite as examples of the operation of such tribunals the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority and the Coal Industry Tribunal. In those cases special tribunals with special functions deal with the special problems of highly specialised industry.

It is impossible today for judges to be economists and more and more the work that is being referred to them is work of an economic nature. In every branch of law there is a tendency for some pre-trial assessment and definition of the issues with a view to streamlining procedures. Today the average working man is frustrated and disappointed. He realises that unfortunately a majority of employers are prepared to take advantage of the delays and procrastinations associated with formal proof in a formal court that has evolved a most complex and unnecessary system of industrial jurisprudence.

talk.start.para: - If I were asked what I considered to be the three most important decisions to be made by the people of Australia - decisions with the most far reaching results - I would say that they were, first, what is to be done about Australia's defence; secondly, what is to be done about Australia's shortage of skilled labour; and thirdly- this may be rather surprising - what is to be done about Australia's wool marketing system. The state of our overseas balances is vitally important to Australia and certainly our system of wool marketing affects those balances, but it is not appropriate in this debate to refer to wool marketing. However, the first two decisions to which I referred are very much appropriate to the estimates now before the Committee.

speech.para: Today we see great competing pressures at work in our rapidly expanding economy. Tremendous demands are being made for professional men, tradesmen and even for unskilled labour. Another section of our manpower is engaged in training at our universities, our technical colleges and our trade training centres. In addition many apprentices are iti training and there is room for many more to be trained. Further competing pressure on our resources of manpower comes from the Defence Forces. I refer here to our permanent Defence Forces.

The greatest single problem standing in the way of development and defence in this country is not lack of capital but of manpower. Having discussed this problem with some unions I think I am in a position to express disappointment that management, the Government and the trade union movement are not making more progress together than they are in expediting training in skilled trades, whether that training be by the traditional method of apprenticeship or by some new method yet to be devised. It is obvious that more planning is absolutely necessary. We know that to a . certain extent some planning is being done. I am not talking about drafting; I am talking about planning. Planning is necessary but how can we possibly plan unless the planners know exactly what personnel they have to work with? I do not mean only numbers of men, but the categories into which they fall. We must know who are skilled, who are professional, who are unskilled, who are in training, who are at universities and who intend to go to universities. This is the type of information that is required before anybody can give an accurate answer to the problem or produce a workable plan.
