In this regard I give praise to those responsible for the demographic surveys that have been taken out but I would like to see the surveys provide more information. At present they do not necessarily give the occupations of each group. They do not show the number of students who are in training at any particular time. They do not show how many students intend to continue with university studies. These are some of the problems with which we must contend at the moment.

Having made those remarks I think it is advisable to try to come up with a solution. I suggest that the Government should set up a national manpower register. In this regard I agree to an extent with the remarks of the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Stokes) but I extend my remarks over a sphere wider than he covered. As I saw it, he was dealing mainly with the military forces. But our manpower problem today goes right through from the time when young men and young women leave school, through their tertiary education, apprenticeship training and trade training and their work, whatever it may be. In view of the great demand for manpower, not only for defence but also for employment in this rapidly expanding economy, we must have more information, and more accurate information, about whom we have not to play with but to work with.

This scheme should be carried to the stage of the first registration of whatever age groups are decided upon by the Government to suit the conditions pertaining at the time. In many instances, the men in the right age group could go to the stage of a preliminary medical examination and blood test. That does nobody any harm. This registration would provide valuable information. For the moment, I am not suggesting that the Government should draft people all over the place. The information would be valuable to the people who are interested in education and the provision that has to be made for it in the future, to the people who are interested in filling the ranks of the Army, and to the people who are interested in skilled trade training. The registration would give the figures. It would sort out the medically unfit. As far as the Services are concerned, it would sort out the conscientious objectors. It would give the number of students, the number of apprentices and the number of people who are interested in military service. I emphasise that I am talking about a register and I am talking about a call-up. I am not talking about drafting anybody anywhere at this stage.

Having done that, the Government should arrive at a manpower policy for the whole Commonwealth. When I say " manpower ", I am referring to young men and young women throughout the Commonwealth. 1 am not referring only to military service. The policy need not necessarily be disclosed. Information about it could be kept for use by those who want to use it. As we develop our military strength and as further equipment comes into use, I believe that we will come to the time when we will have to start thinking in terms of a bit of security.

We should come to a decision on reserved occupations. The list of reserved occupations will have to be changed from time to time. It must be amended constantly to fit in with the circumstances as they exist or as they are predicted to exist. Otherwise we will end up with a lot of unskilled people in the Army. That is not fair to the Army and I suggest that it is not fair to the young people who have not been fortunate enough to have the opportunity, or have not taken advantage of the opportunity, to further their education. That would apply if there were any drafting into the Army. This would involve a very firm decision by the Government on the type of enlistment that will be adopted. I think we will hear more of that later, in the debate on the defence estimates. It would involve having a definite policy on the type of enlistment, and making definite decisions on the size of the Navy, the Army and the Air Force and the types of forces - the Regular Army, the Citizen Military Forces, the reserves and the school cadets. Until those decisions are made we will not get full value from this manpower register.

Having set up the register and adopted a policy, it will then be the task of the Government to go out and tell the people exactly what the position is and what is required of them. That should be done by means of a call to the nation. It has been my experience - I am sure that this has been the experience of all honorable members - that Australians have a reputation of always being able to stand up to the task when called upon. I believe strongly that if we convince Australians of the need to work in any direction - whether in the forces or in skilled occupations in the realm of secondary production - they will respond. If the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) were in the chamber and if he cared to speak, I know that he could assure honorable members and the Australian people that his Department is geared to carry out this work at relatively short notice.

In conclusion, I say that this work could be done at not a great cost to the Commonwealth. This national manpower register would be comparatively cheap insurance for the country. It would be to the national advantage in the military sense, for a start, and also in the industrial sense and the economic sense. It would give accurate figures to work on in the future. I believe that it would be an outstanding thing and good for the national morale.

talk.start.para: . - I refer to the estimates for the Department of Labour and National Service. Approximately two months ago, in the House, I addressed to the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) a question about the conditions of employment of managers of Commonwealth hostels in Canberra. The question, to say the least, was not well received. The answer given by the Minister was certainly not a reply to the question that I had posed. I propose to make some further remarks on that subject. I asked the Minister -

speech.para: Is it true that there is no industrial agreement covering conditions under which hostel managers are employed by Commonwealth Hostels Limited? Is it true that some hostel managers are required to work a minimum of 60 hours a week, and in many cases more, with no payment for overtime and with only one and a half days a week ofl! duty, and then provided only that a relieving manager is available? Is it true that hostel managers have been denied the opportunity to negotiate with the company on their conditions of employment? Is it also true that managers who have sought to form an organisation to negotiate with the company have been dealt with summarily by transfer to remote areas? Will the Minister inquire into the conditions of employment of hostel managers, and will he arrange for hostel managers to present evidence without fear of reprisal oi victimisation?

The Minister's answer was - it is the policy of this Government to give the power of management to Commonwealth Hostels Ltd. That has been done. Personally, I have complete confidence in the board of Commonwealth Hostels Ltd. to manage that organisation satisfactorily. If what the honorable member for the Australian Capital Territory says is true, what a regrettable fact it is that he has not personally come to me to explain the matter and to ask me whether I would write to Sir Tasman Heyes to let that gentleman know what has been said. These are very severe accusations and are of a type which should not be made if they are not true. I have the gravest doubts whether the statement made by the honorable member can be substantiated. If he would care to let me have a letter about it, I will send that letter immediately to Sir Tasman Heyes and, when Sir Tasman replies, his reply will be forwarded to the honorable member.

I did not write to the Minister because I have a feeling that it is appropriate to raise these matters in the House by way of a question addressed to the responsible Minister and to expect a reply thereto. I would think that if the Minister regarded these accusations as grave he would have initiated some inquiry and elicited some information about the conditions under which hostel managers are required to work. In fact, I believe that the Minister has been provided, from another source - a direct and reliable source - with evidence that what I said in the House was true and remains true.
I propose to refer to letters that I have received. A letter dated 20th August 1964 reads as follows -

quote.para: As ex-hostel management, my husband and I, feel very strongly, how true and accurate your statements regarding the managers of Commonwealth Hostels were, and I am therefore enclosing a copy of the letter which

speech.para: I have today sent to the Minister ' for Labour and National Service. I might add that I have never come across a concern more arbitrary or less co-operative with its employees than Commonwealth Hostels Limited, and because of this strong feeling I am prompted to add my small voice to the cause of the present managers.
The letter sent to the Minister for Labour and National Service I think can be read appropriately. It says -

quote.para: I refer to a question which I understand was asked in the House, by Mr.1. R. Fraser M.H.R., regarding the hours of duty of managers of Commonwealth Hostels Ltd., and feel that I cannot let this matter pass without my comments.

My husband and I were in joint management of a Canberra hostel . . . during a period which included the administration of the Department of the Interior and also Commonwealth Hostels Ltd., and can say without any fear of contradiction, that the hours of duty of hostel managers are a minimum of 60 hours per week. Added to this there is no time of night or day when a manager is not at the beck and call of guests, and as he fives on the premises, there is no way of avoiding this, apart from leaving the premises.
I therefore humbly submit, as a completely impartial onlooker, that some consideration be given to this matter of hours of duty.

speech.para: I received a telegram from Hotel Managers, New South Wales, which reads -

quote.para: Your continued action greatly appreciated.

speech.para: I received a letter from another manager of a Commonwealth hostel in which he said - . . there are one or two most important facts that escaped me at the time for your information.

He then referred to the hostels in Canberra and the increase of the number of beds in the hostels. He said that the number of beds had been increased over the past two years. The number at Hotel Acton had increased by 100, at Lawley House by 153, at Brassey House by 86, at Narellan House by 60 and at Gorman House by 6, making a total increase in beds of 405. The letter went on -

quote.para: Yet in spite of this increase managerial staff has not increased at all. Further it is understood that the company made a profit of over £70,000 last year. This was only possible by the efficiency of managers. We are supposed to qualify for annual increment of 12s. 6d. per annum. These have been handed out very sparingly. In my case after five years I have yet to receive one. Gorman House increased profit last year by £1,500. Further although in one man hostels we are on call 24 hours a day 51/2 days a week, in the two man hostels which cater in some instances for over 300 guests there is only one manager on duty for three days each week. So Sir it really makes one wonder how long this ridiculous situation can go on, but it is sure to get worse unless someone like yourself can do something to help.
Again Sir I can assure you that every Canberra manager is most grateful for your efforts on our behalf . . .

speech.para: I have read those letters to show that there is unsolicited evidence of the accuracy of the matter I raised with the Minister and I repeat that I understand the Minister has received other evidence confirming what I had to say. Some time ago I had occasion to speak about the management of hostels in Canberra and the conditions provided for guests in the hostels. I referred to a proposal to spend £100,000 or £150,000 on improvements at the Hotel Kurrajong, converting the hotel into something in the nature of luxury accommodation. That was the term used in the newspaper notices at that time. I had the temerity to suggest - I know my colleagues who stay at the Hotel Kurrajong will forgive me - that instead of spending £100,000 to £150,000 to provide quite lavish accommodation at Hotel Kurrajong, the Commonwealth Government might spend some money on improving conditions at what are regarded as the lower grade of hostels in Canberra, the hostels that accommodate the office staffs of the departments in Canberra.

talk.start.para: - Have you ever stayed at the Hotel Kurrajong?

- I have never stayed at the Hotel Kurrajong, but I was for seven and a half years at Reid House in a room nine feet by ten feet, with an 8 feet ceiling, with no washing facilities in the room, with no hot or cold water, with no form of heating other than that provided by the occupant and with a route march to the ablution block every time one wanted to wash one's hands. I understand that is slightly at variance with the conditions at the Hotel Kurrajong. I am speaking now for the young people and the people who are working in this city and who are living in what are regarded as B class hostels managed by Commonwealth Hostels Ltd.
- What does " B " stand for?

- The honorable member for Lang asks what " B " stands for. I know that he is quite capable of interpreting that for himself. When I suggested that conditions should be improved at these hostels, I was interviewed by Sh* Tasman Heyes, Mr. Bruce Brown, the General Manager of Commonwealth Hostels Ltd. and the local manager of the company. They had with them a prepared statement which was intended to rebut everything that I had said about the conditions in these second class or B class hostels. I do not know that that is an official term. I have not time to read the whole of the statement they had prepared, but one paragraph of it said -

quote.para: The Commonwealth docs not make profits out of any of the Canberra establishments. Where trading surpluses are made, the company is permitted to use such surpluses for effecting improvements in the establishments.

speech.para: Another paragraph said -

quote.para: The largest and least satisfactory of the lower tariff guest houses, namely Mulwala House and Reid House, are temporary buildings which it is proposed to replace. It would be wasteful to carry out any major improvements (e.g., the provision of hot water in rooms and central heating) in these establishments because it is hoped that they can be replaced at least within the next 3-5 years.

speech.para: A further paragraph said -

quote.para: It is hoped that it will be possible to offer the present guests in Reid House and Mulwala House the choice of transferring to these new hostels.

speech.para: This is a reference to the new 500 bed hostels, which are being built now and which will contain all the conveniences that modern science can provide. The statement continued -

quote.para: Whilst Mulwala House and Reid House remain, they can then be used for new arrivals who will qualify later for transfer to the more modern establishments-

speech.para: That is magnificent in this bureaucratic city- thus using the less satisfactory hostels largely as transit accommodation.
That is a term that could be more accurately applied, of course, to Hotel Kurrajong and some of the other A class establishments. The statement also said -

quote.para: With regard to the accommodation at Capital, Hill/Hillside for workers, the same policy has been adopted of effecting improvements gradually by the use of available funds.

These establishments are in the same position as Reid House and Mulwala House and are due for replacement within three to four years and, consequently, any major improvement work would not be justified.

speech.para: I again had the temerity to suggest to Sir Tasman Heyes that if improvements that were being contemplated at other hostels could not be provided at Mulwala House and Reid House, the equitable approach would be to reduce the tariffs at these hostels and so give the young people staying there a better chance to make ends meet in this rather costly city. Although the suggestion was received, I thought with some approbation, the tariffs have been increased, as they are increased every time there is a rise in the basic wage.

I refer to the statement that the hostels do not make profits. Managers and exmanagers of hostels in Canberra aver without any hesitation at all that the hostels are operating at substantial profits, but since Commonwealth Hostels Ltd. has taken over control the Parliament is no longer provided with dissections of figures, as were previously provided by the Auditor-General in his report. We have to go back to 1957-58 to get a dissection of the figures. It was revealed that for that financial year Reid House, the hostel it is not worth improving because it will be pulled down in four or five years, made a profit of fi 2,766. Havelock House made a profit of £4,458. The works hostel at Capital Hill- this is the hostel for workers not far from here - made a profit of £8,337. Ex-managers say that the profits of these, hostels are now running at the rate of £1,200 or £1,300 a month. If their statements are to be refuted, they can be refuted only by the provision of figures similar to those formerly provided for this Parliament by the Auditor-General. If Commonwealth Hostels Ltd. sees fit to answer the charge that it is making profits from these hostels, and particularly the charge that it is making excessive profits from the lower tariff hostels where the workers and the young people of this community are housed, it should publish the figures and let the Parliament know.

I suggest at this stage that the Minister for Labour and National Service may see fit to answer the detailed questions that I have asked. I ask him now, through the Minister for Immigration (Mr. Opperman), who is at the table, whether he will give an assurance that Commonwealth Hostels Ltd. will offer no objection to the forming of an organisation by hostel managers to negotiate with the company on the terms of their employment and their remuneration. I suggest that, if the Minister cannot make such a declaration on behalf of the Company, he should intimate clearly that the Commonwealth Government has . no objection to hostel managers forming an organisation to negotiate with their employers about their terms of employment and their remuneration. I leave the matter at that.

talk.start.para: .- Mr. Temporary Chairman,I wish to discuss the estimates for the Department of Labour and National Service which are now before the Committee. As we all know, this Department administers our system of conciliation and arbitration. For the edification of honorable members - I am certain that many of them require some edification - I point out that the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is composed of 16 members in all. These are the President, five Deputy Presidents, all of them have the qualification of judges, one Senior Com missioner and nine Commissioners. The Commissioners do not require legal qualifications. Assisting the Commission, but not represented on it, are three Conciliators. Any one who knows something of the conciliation and arbitration system is aware of the integrity of these members and their dedication to the task of maintaining industrial harmony. They have a sound knowledge of industrial law and long experience in dealing with industrial problems.

speech.para: The Australian system of conciliation and arbitration is elaborate and costly to the country. Those who administer the system have a very grave responsibility for ensuring that industrial conditions here are as good as possible so that proper decisions may be made and conciliatory methods may bc brought into play. 1 think it is beyond doubt and beyond question that industrial conditions in Australia are equal to the best in the world. The Australian system of conciliation and arbitration is unique. The honorable member for Cunningham (Mr. Connor), in what I regard as a shameful display of anti-Australianism, stated this evening that' our system was not good and that it left much to be desired. His attitude suggests to me that he has had little experience of the system of conciliation and arbitration that operates here. I for one have implicit faith in it, and I am certain that 99 per cent, of the Australian people have equal faith in it.

The industrial machinery and procedures certainly have changed over the years, but the functions and objectives remain the same. These are the settlement of industrial grievances, by either conciliation or arbitration. I state without equivocation, Mr. Temporary Chairman, that this system is backed not only by employers but also by employees. It is important to the rank and file workers that the system continues to exist, as the great majority of workers regard the arbitral tribunals as a protection against the lowering of living standards, particularly in times when labour is overabundant. I admit that the Australian system of conciliation and arbitration is not perfect. It is subject to human fallibility. But I claim that it has brought to Australia a high standard of living in circumstances in which dramatic development has taken place here.

Australians are noted for their sportsmanship and their obedience to the decisions of the umpire. When all is said and done, the system of conciliation and arbitration in our community surely occupies the position of an umpire. Yet, in this day and age, we find a staggering increase in strike action. According to figures that have been made available, one million man days have been lost over the last year. What a national scandal that is. It indicates that there is abroad a spirit of industrial lawlessness. This situation poses the questions: Is our system of conciliation and arbitration losing its effectiveness? Has not the militant and irresponsible attitude of the trade union movement, in large measure, made a sham, a mockery and almost a complete farce of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? A powerful section of the trade union movement is now resorting freely to strike action. We see brandished the strike weapon - the bludgeon of industrial intimidation - with industrial anarchy on the loose and irresponsible stoppages the order of the day. The resulting disruption of the defence programme and of national progress makes this serious situation unacceptable to good Australians. The community is virtually being held to ransom. One may well ask, and I repeat: Is our system of conciliation and arbitration losing its effectiveness in this troubled country?

I assert that there is not one iota of justification for the current wave of strikes. The arguments that I have heard from honorable members opposite about the reasons why the men are said to find it necessary to strike will not bear examination. Honorable members opposite say that the high earnings of General MotorsHolden's Pty. Ltd. and other employers give the men good reason for striking. Surely those earnings indicate to reasonable and moderate trade union leaders that the industries concerned are efficient. If they believe they have a proper case in favour of employees, they ought to take it to the courts. The grievances over wages and conditions that have led to recent and current strikes should properly be referred to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, hut, as I have pointed out, a number of unions would rather resort to industrial anarchy, and torpedo arbitration. They have become completely arrogant and irresponsible and their tactics amount to sheer industrial disruption. Industry and the nation are being subjected to industrial blackmail by powerful and important unions that find themselves at present in a strategic position industrially.

Has all this come about just by coincidence? Of course it has not. It has resulted from a combination of circumstances. These are, first, over-full employment and, secondly, our concern for national security. With very careful planning, the hierarchy of the Communist Party of Australia has taken advantage of this combination of circumstances.

talk.start.para: - Here he goes again.

- I am one who has a long experience of the way in which the Communist Party acts in the industrial sphere, and now, looking across the chamber, I realise that the majority of honorable members opposite would not have a clue as to the way in which the Communists operate. I have had a good deal of experience with the erstwhile union of the honorable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr. Curtin), the Boilermakers Society of Australia.
- They are not Communists.

- They are Communist led. What is happening in Australian industrial circles today is the result of Communist dictation. Do you mean to tell me, or do you mean to tell any reasonable person, that the Communist leaders, the agitators, are just looking after their bookshop in Sussex Street and doing things that are not calculated to cause disruption? Of course that is not the position. I say quite definitely that behind every major strike there is Communist influence, Communist" dictation of union leaders.
- What rot.

- I do not know whether honorable members opposite would know just what form such dictation takes. Let us not be misled about the way in which the Communists operate. They go along to a trade union leader who appears about to step out of line and break away from Communist influence, and they talk to him about tame cat unions and tame cat leadership. They use a kind of verbal intimidation. The trade union leader is then influenced in the same way as honorable members opposite have unfortunately been influenced. Honorable members of the Opposition have been so intimidated by Communists who wield power in the trade union movement that not one of them has got up in this chamber - at least not during my time in the Parliament - and denounced a strike of any kind. Surely you cannot all sit in your places on the other side of this chamber and seriously contend that you approve all strike action that is taken.
- Don't you think the master provokes strikes?

- The conditions . of employment in Australia are particularly good. I would say they are the best in the world. I would say that the master does not provoke strikes and that he would go out of his way - that all employers would go out of their way - to make conditions of employment as good as possible and to ensure that workers enjoy high standards of living.
- The master creates strikes.
- Order!
- The master creates a strike to get out .of his contract when he is losing money.

speech.para: Order! The honorable member for Kingsford Smith will come to order.

talk.start.para: - Everyone knows how the Communist leaders employ mob psychology to intimidate. They do it in such a way that not one man who goes to a stop work meeting would be game to get up and say: "I am opposed to this strike". Honorable members opposite know that just as well as anyone knows it who has some knowledge of the trade union situation. It is this intimidation that causes the mcn in the unions to agree with the strike resolutions that are put forward. They realise that their lives would not be worth living if they took action against the leaders.

speech.para: In these circumstances we find in this country today discord, disruption and industrial anarchy, which are part of the stockintrade of the Communist Party. The Communists are using a softening up process as part of their plan for the eventual takeover of this country. The Labour Party is in the course of a softening up process aimed ultimately at nationalisation. The time has arrived for honorable members opposite to take stock of the position and decide whether they want complete industrial chaos and to throw over the system of conciliation and arbitration which has stood the test of time and has done so much for the workers of Australia and the. community generally. I conclude by asking once again, because there is some doubt in my mind about this: Is the system of conciliation and arbitration proving effective in this day and age?

talk.start.para: .- I doubt that the committee will take the honorable member for Warringah (Mr. Cockle) seriously. While he has been referring to extreme sections of the trade union movement, we all recognise him as one of the most tyrannical representatives of the' employers. He has been well known as the representative of the shipowners on the Australian waterfront, and this evening he has given a fair expression of the unreasonable attitude which that section of employers has adopted towards its employees over the years. If his speech is an indication of the degree of commonsense that can be employed in a discussion of such an important subject, in circumstances in which there are strikes taking place in various parts of the country based on tremendously important social questions, and if the views expressed by the honorable member fairly represent those of the Government, we can easily appreciate that the Government is completely unable to deal with the problems on hand. However, I cannot spend time at the moment in discussing the honorable member's views, although I would like to do so on some future occasion.

speech.para: I wish to refer to a section of the estimates for the Department of Labour and National Service which has to do with the supplementary adult training scheme which has already been referred to by my colleagues, the honorable members for Newcastle (Mr. Jones) and Cunningham (Mr. Connor). As most honorable members know, the Government is at present trying to overcome difficulties created by its own misdemeanours and inefficiency which have resulted in a shortage of apprentices and tradesmen. The Government has now been in office for 15 years and the chickens are at last coming home to roost. The day of reckoning has arrived and a crisis has arisen in many of our heavy industries and other important industries.

For a long time the Government has refused to concede the status of tradesmen in the community. It must fairly take the blame for having depressed the living standards of tradesmen. It has filched away tradesmen's margins. It has even taken the trouble to put its views before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission when that authority has been hearing applications for increased margins. The actions taken by the Government have been tantamount to driving men out of trades. One of those actions that readily springs to mind was the adoption of stop-go economic policies which caused periodic unemployment of tradesmen in many industries. Then we know of the pin-pricking tactics in invoking the penal clauses of awards. When men have endeavoured to correct some glaring anomaly on a job or to improve conditions, the penal provisions of the Arbitration Act have been viciously invoked. In addition, the Government can be fairly indicted for having failed to plan for the necessary intake of apprentices.

There have been many other causes of the unsatisfactory situation that exists at the present time, and I can produce a good deal of evidence of them. Insufficient effort has been made to encourage private enterprise to accept a fair intake of indentured youths. As my colleague the honorable member for Newcastle pointed out earlier today, Commonwealth departments - be instanced figures in respect of several - have a pretty poor record in regard to apprenticeships. Now we have reached the stage where the Government has only one remedy. It seems to be intent on writing down still further the tradesman's status and the skill of the tradesman, which have been a matter of great pride in this country for a long time. This is to be undertaken by a new dilution scheme.

I want to make it clear that neither the Labour movement nor the trade union movement is opposed to rehabilitation schemes. We are not even opposed to intensified and accelerated processes of turning inexperienced people into experienced tradesmen. In fact, fair concessions have already been made towards this end. But the Labour movement and the trade union movement are devoted to the idea that, whatever dilution scheme is introduced, a fair result should accrue and good tradesmen's standards should follow. We have already been able to observe, from the paper circulated by the Department of Labour and National Service headed "A Note of the Commonwealth Supplementary Training Scheme " and dated 9th May 1964, that the trade union movement has made important concessions. Decisions taken include, among others, the acceptance of the principle of giving the greatest opportunities, the reduction of the term of apprenticeship for educational qualifications and experience, and shortened apprenticeships of three to three and one-half years in the engineering and electrical trades for older and better qualified lads. This is already operating and fair results are in sight.

At the present time, however, the Government is canvassing what seems to me to be a most unreasonable proposition. The proposal is that adults of 19 years of age and over will be enticed into apprenticeships and they are to be given six months technical training - a bare six months technical training - after which they are to undertake two years in an approved industry. Then, provided they measure up to an examination or a test, they are to be issued with a certificate under the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act. Employers in many parts of the country are already making the point that this proposition is completely incapable of providing skilled tradesmen who will have had the necessary environment to make their work effective. Indeed, only the other day, when I visited the Cronulla Tool and Engineering Co., an industry in my own electorate, the proprietor said: " We could not engage a person who had undertaken only six months training and two years in an approved industry and allow him to work one of these expensive machines, the capital cost of which could be in the vicinity of £25,000." He pointed to a die which was being processed on a milling machine and said that the product which was being processed had already increased in value many times as a consequence of the work that had been done on it. To get someone with this minimum amount of training and engage him on that type of work would be disastrous and far too risky for that employer and, he felt, for most others.

Already there has been, as I have said, a fair concession in this regard. As a result of a conference in November 1962 an arrangement has been in operation whereby there are three to three and one-half year apprenticeships for people in the 17 to 20 year age group with higher educational qualifications. They undertake 20 weeks continuous daylight training. The unions have already agreed to drop the minimum age from 17, I understand, and this indicates still further the degree of cooperation that they are prepared to render. It is fair to contend that this training scheme had not been given a fair trial up to this point, at which the Minister and his Department have come in with this more provocative arrangement which, in no circumstances, has the prospect of, producing good tradesmen of the type we have had up to date. Young men have been available for many years for apprenticeships, but there has been insufficient encouragement for them. In July 1963 there were no fewer than 80,000 registered unemployed in Australia. Of that number 20 per cent. - 16,000 in numbers - were under 21 years of age, according to the figures provided by the Department of. Labour and National Service. Here was a large number of young men who had been deprived of apprenticeship training- opportunities as a result of this Government's economic policies.

In March 1964 - not so long ago - there were no fewer than 2,372 male school leavers registered for employment in Australia. During the year ended July 1964 - I am not saying " at " July 1964, but during the year that ended in July - there were no fewer than 82,700 school leavers registered for employment with the Commonwealth Employment Service. A large number of these people had obviously been deprived of the opportunity to take apprenticeships. It is an appalling fact that the intake of apprentices is declining. I have been able to ascertain that in 1954 22.75 per cent. of school leavers were apprenticed. By 1959 the figure had fallen to 19.11 per cent. A number of trade unions which studied this problem predicted that in 1964 the figure would drop to 18 per cent, of school leavers.

Why are employers not seeking apprentices to the extent that they should? Many of them have contended that economic conditions are far too unstable to enable them to look five years ahead. I have only to refer to one report of an apprenticeship commission to illustrate this point. The report of the Apprenticeship Commission of Victoria makes no bones about the situation. At page 9 of the report the Commission' states -

quote.para: Over the years the apprenticeship system in Victoria has provided industry with skilled craftsmen who are not inferior in skill and adaptability to those of other countries. Unfortunately we are not training enough of them and we are not attracting enough of the better qualified youths to fill the future requirements for the technicians which technical progress demands.
All sections of the economy are competing for young labour and too many of our best brains are being diverted by the attractions of early rewards and so-called white collar occupations.

speech.para: The report continues -

quote.para: Too many employers are neglecting their obligation to train their own skilled people. They prefer to leave the expense and inconvenience of training to others. This is a selfish and irresponsible attitude. They must be convinced that not only should they meet their obligations to train craftsmen but that they cannot afford not to train them.

speech.para: There are many similar comments in this report of the Apprenticeship Commission of Victoria for the year ended 30th June 1964, and similar comments are being made by employers all over the country.

In the last edition of the publication "Automotive Topics" a similar comment is made under the heading "Employers Must Train More Apprentices". The publication says that the employers have been failing in that regard. It is very difficult to know why employers do not appreciate the surely apparent need to get on with the job. In the limited time at my disposal I want to make the point that 38 per cent, of the Australian population at the end of June 1963 were under 19 years of age. Indeed, it is fair to predict that the highest output of youths of apprenticeship age will take place from now on over the next 20 years to, say, 1984. There seems to be a tendency in Australia for us to become " over Messelised People seem to think th everyone should become a physicist, a chemist or a scientist of some sort. This is a consequence of the influence of Professor Messel. But nobody seems to realise the necessity to encourage the people who are the very salt of the earth in many respects, the people who put most things into operation. I think it fair to say that this Government has been lax in respect of the Martin Committee which is investigating the needs of secondary and technical education. The Government's attitude is, in itself, symptomatic of the low priority which is being given by the Government to the needs of technical education generally. I want to make the point that in many trades there has not been an overdose of work vacancies. As a member of the Amalgamated Engineering Union, I have been interested to obtain information from that union in regard to the excess of vacancies over tradesmen - that is, registered fitters - for the last four years when there has not been very much difference between the two figures at all. The excess of vacancies .over available tradesmen in 1960 was 559. There were insufficient vacancies in 1961, when 366 more vacancies were needed than were actually available. In 1962, 82 more vacancies were needed than were available. It is true in 1963 there were 410 such vacancies, but over a period these figures seemed to have averaged out .pretty well. There are many figures available to indicate that there is not a large surplus of vacancies in Australia at the present time. It seems to me that this Government has to lift its sights and make stronger endeavours than it has made hitherto to ensure that employers accept a fair intake of apprentices, because unless this is done, Australia will find itself in great difficulty in the not far distant future.

talk.start.para: . - I would not have intruded into this debate were it not for the fact that these are the first estimates of the Department of Immigration which have been before the Committee since I took over the portfolio. Therefore I feel it is fitting, and I do this with great sincerity, that I should pay a tribute to my predecessor, Mr. Downer, whose work I now have experienced and who, as honorable members know, is the United Kingdom High Commissioner elect. He was, as this Com mittee well knows, a most tolerant and capable Minister. Perhaps the best compliment that I can pay him is to say that in the experience that I have had already in my portfolio, my predecessor has left a Department with very high morale and keen and enthusiastic officers who never lose sight of the fact that they are dealing with human beings, all of whom have their own problems, difficulties and apprehensions. These officers know that they too have a tremendous and grave responsibility when they change so drastically and dramatically the way of life of others. The effect of this is reflected in the words of the honorable member for Ryan (Mr. Drury), the honorable member for Grayndler (Mr. Daly) and the honorable member for Hume (Mr. Pettitt), all of whom expressed such warm admiration for those engaged in the processing of prospective migrants for Australia.

speech.para: The migration programme over the years has been one which has been peculiarly non-political. In many ways one can almost say non-party. There is no reservation of appreciation, for example, from those on this side of the chamber when we remember that this plan was commenced so effectively by the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell), and no member on the Labour Party side of the committee has condemned with any caustic criticism the succession of Immigration Ministers of this Government. We may differ at times over matters of detail, but the overall immigration plan has had almost universal political approval. Therefore, the Department of Immigration has developed over the years into a vast and comprehensive organisation with an essential flexible operation to meet changing circumstances. Because of this fact, one could say, from knowledge of conventions which have come out here and from committees which have examined the position - not based merely on our own statements - that the Department has achieved the most satisfactory results known to any immigration plan in the world today.

The Department has to intrude into many different countries. It contacts many different nationalities with their contrasting temperaments and outlooks. For this reason, the Department requires representatives with particular talents and capacities for assessing people of another race and for gauging their potential when transplanted into a country some 10,000 miles away from their own country. With these facts in mind, I think it is worth mentioning that plans have been put into operation for our selection officers, prior to posting overseas in their important positions, to visit various parts of Australia to obtain an up to date knowledge of the needs and development of this country. This knowledge is regarded as absolutely necessary. This is an indication that the Department is just not resting on the results of the past. It is not complacent about its future, or the present satisfactory position with regard to immigration figures to which reference has been made by previous speakers.

I would say that the portrayal of Australia over a considerable period of time is now reaping a commensurate reward. Over the years, there have been from time to time various criticisms of Australian publicity abroad, according to the outlook and reaction of each particular critic. Australians who have been abroad, and people from other countries who come here, say that, perhaps too great an emphasis is placed on the illustration of our beaches, or too much attention is focussed on our outback, and too much, representation is made of our cities. But I feel that the very varied types of portrayal which have been given by the Department of Immigration and the Bureau of News and Information have built up overall what the advertising people call an image. In this case, it is a very favorable image of Australia, because we have now coming to Australia a record number of immigrants, despite the buoyant economic conditions of Europe, which have been referred to by the honorable member for Hume in pointing out that immigration is running at a record level.

It may be relevant at this point to say once again that the immigration target for 1964-65 has been established at 127,000 settlers, of whom 55,000 will be assisted migrants from Britain; 20,000 will be assisted migrants from other sources; and 52,000 will be unassisted settlers from all countries. The target of 55,000 assisted British migrants is the biggest target ever attempted in this country. I must say in connection with that matter that the target for British assisted migrants was established at this time last year at 45,000. Therefore, our target for this year provides for an additional 10,000 migrants. In the light of the growing demand for workers of all kind, and particularly because of the urgent need for certain categories of skilled workers, the programme was reviewed early in 1964 and the target for British assisted migrants for the financial year just completed was increased to 55,000. The actual arrivals for the financial year under that scheme were 54,630 Therefore, it can be understood why we approach with considerable confidence a target of 55,000 assisted migrants from the United Kingdom that has been set for this current financial year.

We have provided also for a greater degree of flexibility - and I referred earlier in my speech to the flexibility that the Department needs in order to meet changing circumstances - so that by 31st December some 32,600 persons of the target of. 55,000 British assisted migrants will either, already be in Australia or on their way here. This will enable us if necessary to increase the rate of intake during the second half of this financial year.

It is not easy to superimpose that number of migrants quickly upon a number for which a transport system has already been arranged despite the fact that the outsider may feel that there are sufficient ships and aircraft to meet any added demands of that nature. I want to assure the Committee that the integration of this extra number calls for a tremendous amount of organisation. It is worth noting here the important assistance that has been made available by Qantas Empire Airways Ltd. in providing from its own resources or by chartering on behalf of the Department from other companies sufficient aircraft to move 14,500 people during the first six months of this financial year. We feel now that the record number of 20,000 migrants moved from the United Kingdom to Australia by air last financial year will be increased substantially. The proposed level of assisted migration from the United Kingdom by no means provides for all those who wish to come here. In the financial year just ended, applications received at Australia House covered 117,500 people, and it is pleasing to be able to announce that the level of applications in the first three months of this financial year was approximately the same as that for the corresponding period last financial year.

During his speech this afternoon, the honorable member for Grayndler (Mr. Daly) asked for a break down of the figures relating to migrants from countries other than the United Kingdom. He will be interested to know that the figures disclose that of the assisted migrants from such countries 700 were Austrians, 300 were Belgians, 2,000 were Dutch, 3,000 were Germans, 3,500 were Greeks, 2,000 were Italians, 3,500 were Maltese and 1,000 were Spanish. There will be 1,500 refugees from Western Europe. Others, including British, French, Scandinavians, Swiss and Americans will be assisted. The 52,000 unassisted settlers included 12,000 British, 12,000 Greeks, 9,000 Italians, and 1,500 Maltese. Also some nationals from Communist countries will be travelling here under what is known as Operation Re-Union. No doubt honorable members have heard of that.

The honorable member for Grayndler and the honorable member for Hume (Mr. Pettitt) drew attention to the fact that 250,000 migrants, including children, who are residentially qualified to apply for naturalisation have not done so.. Perhaps it would be better if I were to state the position from the other side. I ask honorable members to remember that over 60 per cent, of eligible migrants have successfully sought Australian citizenship. It is interesting to note that this compares favorably with the experience of other countries which have built up their populations by large scale immigration. Therefore, the fact that 250,000 have not applied for naturalisation is no indication Australia does not suit migrants generally The 60 per cent, represents a good average figure. We would like every migrant to become naturalised who has settled here, who likes the country and who is likely to remain here. We share the concern expressed by honorable members with relation to the number who have not applied.
I should mention that we are taking steps to encourage more migrants to become naturalised. For instance, the application forms for naturalisation have been simplified.

talk.start.para: - Why do you not give them a bonus? That would attract them.

- We say they have a bonus in being in the country. All that an applicant is required to do is place his name and address on the application form. Immediately he does that, he is assisted by the Department to complete the remaining requirements. In addition, we no longer require the payment of a fee upon submitting an application for naturalisation.

speech.para: We are carrying out surveys to ascertain the reasons why a number of eligible migrants have not applied for naturalisation. When the results of these surveys have been scrutinised we shall know far more than we do now, and undoubtedly additional measures will be taken. Some experiments have been carried out in enlisting the cooperation of employers of migrants, with excellent results. We have found that, after having been addressed with the permission of employers, many migrants have come forward and sought naturalisation. We propose to extend this line of action. It must be remembered, of course, that the Australian himself is a casual type of person. He will just let things run along so perhaps it is understandable that, with life as good as it is in Australia and with the casual attitude of the Australians, the migrants are content and do not worry 'about naturalisation. They suffer no great penalties for not being naturalised and the environment in which they find themselves, surrounded as they are by casual Australians, perhaps encourages them to be casual about making application.

In the publicity field, a special effort has been made by the Department to bring to the notice of migrants the simple procedures to be followed in order to acquire citizenship. After a migrant has been here for four and a half years, he is notified that be will be eligible to receive naturalisation after having completed the essential five years' residence. He may make application six months before the expiration of the five years. It must be realised however, that we do not want migrants to feel that they are being subjected to any coercion. The honorable member for Grayndler mentioned that point. It is necessary that we place before them the advantages and concessions to be gained by being naturalised and becoming one of us; but, I repeat, this must be done without making migrants feel that pressure is being brought to bear upon them.
Naturalisation ceremonies have been mentioned. I think that if a migrant has made up his mind to become naturalised the ceremony itself will have no effect upon his decision.

talk.start.para: - That is a matter of opinion.

- He will not refrain from becoming naturalised because of the type of ceremony involved. Although a certain formula is laid down, the ceremonies vary according to the sensitivity and leadership qualities of the people connected with carrying them out. Some people have an outstanding aptitude for this work. As I have travelled through the various States I witnessed many ceremonies which have stood out as solemn and memorable occasions, but others could have been a little more appropriate to the occasion. However, it must be remembered that we are inclined to speak only of ceremonies taking place today. If we care to cast our minds back we will appreciate that the present ceremonies are a tremendous improvement on those of the early 1950's which were carried out in the austerity of legal chambers. Most ceremonies today have a local atmosphere and their own characteristics. We owe a tremendous debt to the municipalities which make these occasions possible. Overall, they are carried out very well.

speech.para: The question of housing was also mentioned by the honorable member for Grayndler. This, after all, is a matter of degree. Certainly we all would like to see migrants transferred to private houses immediately upon their arrival, but it might be as well if we were to reflect upon conditions as they applied in the early 1950's. One area that comes into my mind is Bell Post Hill in the Corio electorate. In the early 1950's, we had there the nearest parallel that I have seen to the gold rush scenes of a century before. In that area, tents, packing cases and garages were scattered everywhere, much to the despair of the shire councils, health inspectors and building authorities. Today, they have been replaced by attractive well built houses, many of them constructed by the migrants themselves. Compared with the early 1950's, the situation today is a very happy one indeed, and it is improving. The hostel turnover also has dropped to an average of about eight months, and there are fewer people in hostels. I was able to announce last night, for instance, that the Scheyville Hostel has now been closed.

In conclusion let me say that the success of our immigration programme is not due solely to any particular Minister or his Department. We have had a tremendous amount of voluntary co-operation from many sections of the public. We have the Immigration Planning Council under the chairmanship of the member for Ryan (Mr. Drury) which does excellent work in its capacity. Its members are drawn from leaders in all sections of the community, as is the membership of the Immigration Advisory Council which is presided over by the honorable member for Sturt (Mr. Wilson). Their deductions and advice, coming as they do from people who represent all sections of the community, have proved invaluable.

A very important link is the Good Neighbour Council which co-ordinates the work of so many community bodies which are also working for the benefit of the migration plan. Churches of all denominations have proved most co-operative as well. Also tens of thousands of individual Australians have played their part in assisting migrants to become a part of this country. I would say that that is the reason why in the debate on this particular section of the Estimates we have had constructive thinking and a constructive outlook from both sides of the chamber on immigration, which is playing a most important part in Australia's present and which will continue to play an important part in Australia's future.

talk.start.para: . - Tonight, and this afternoon, we have heard a lot of fairy tales told us by Government members about the Communists - blaming them for everything that has happened in Australia over the last 12 months anyway. In speaking to the Estimates I should like to make one or two observations. I do not want to take much time, because I know that the whips are out I think we are all aware that this country is passing through a stage of widespread industrial unrest. I feel that this is caused by a number of factors. In Queensland the average railway worker, and his equivalent in other States, is seething with discontent. We have the same feeling with the Mount Isa mines workers who work on contract normally but who at the moment are on wages. Recent events in Victoria show that that State has its troubles also, and that things are more or less the same there. Whilst I do not hold with irresponsible action by Communists in trade unions, or others outside - not Communist, but outside influences - I must say that the recent disturbances and the present feeling of discontent are not entirely the work of the Communist Party as some people would have us believe. I am not sticking up for the Communist Party, because the Communists like me as much as I like them.

speech.para: In this country we are too fond of engaging in a form of self deception by blaming these people for everything and not looking for what is often the real cause of the trouble. In my opinion this can only cause a delay in getting at the root of the trouble. The policies of governments in Australia, both State - with a couple of exceptions - and Commonwealth, are pandering to that section of the community which votes for them at the expense of those who do not. We have seen in America what the ultimate result of this will be - an under-privileged proportion of the community living in slums and poverty and an affluent section living in comparative luxury. Of course, they owe for everything they have got, and in most cases their wives are working, but they still feel that things are good and resist any effort to change them. Our country is going the same way, and we can compare the present pattern of strikes and industrial unrest with the riots in America where they have a definite section of poverty, strikes and slum dwellers. While we have not reached that stage here yet, eventually we will if the average worker is continually denied justice, as at the moment. If as a result of all this the Communist Party of Australia becomes stronger, then let those responsible for it take the blame. Members on this side of the chamber will not be responsible for it.

I should like now to mention the position at Townsville, particularly in respect of the working conditions of wharf labourers. That is my main reason for speaking, because I do not normally talk on the Estimates. What I am about to read is a report given to me by one of the workers on the wharf. The complaint would not apply to all ships entering the port, but it most certainly does apply to ships under cheap register. The port of Townsville handles close on 1,000,000 tons of cargo a year. It berths about 355 ships aggregating almost 2,000,000 tons. In my opinion, it should have a full time maritime surveyor. However, the following is a report by an officer of the Waterside Workers Federation regarding one particular incident, which is not uncommon but which is ample justification for the establishment of a full time maritime surveyor. The statement is by Mr. Jack Petrofski, the Vigilance Officer for the Townsville port, and is as follows -

quote.para: At 8.15 a.m. on the 17/8/64, during the course of my duties as Vigilance Officer of the Townsville branch of the Waterside Workers Federation, I proceeded to the vessel "Fast Wind", berthed at No. 1 berth, at the Townsville jetty wharf. On the day in question five gangs were listed to work this vessel, discharging bulk sulphate by means of grabs. As I arrived at the ship, I wa9 met by the delegate of the job, who was with the wharf supervisor, representing the O.G.S. Company. He requested me to inspect the gear of the ship as he was satisfied that the gear was not in a fit and proper condition for safe discharge of cargo.

I noticed a number of shackles that were rusted and in a deplorable condition also guys that were badly frayed. The wharf supervisor of the company stevedoring the ship advised me that he and' the company were not satisfied with the condition of the gear and had requested Mr. Wall, Harbour Master, who is acting as the marine surveyor to make an inspection of the ship to certify whether the gear was safe to work in its condition, and that in the meantime no discharge of cargo would take place. Whilst waiting the arrival of the Harbour Master some derricks were lowered for inspection and a number of faulty rope guys replaced. While this was being done the Harbour Master arrived on the job some time after 9 a.m. He viewed a derrick that had been lowered and stated that he considered the guys to be safe. I pointed out to him that these guys had just been replaced. I then suggested to him that other derricks be lowered so a proper inspection could be carried out. He stated that this was not necessary as he had seen the gear certificate and as far as he was concerned the ship could go ahead and work.
The employer had a derrick at another hatch lowered and it could be plainly seen that a guy commonly known as the lazy guy was worn and badly frayed.

speech.para: That sounds like a member of the Liberal Party - a " lazy guy ". The report continues -

quote.para: I drew the Harbour Master'9 attention to this, but he stated he had seen all he wanted to see and was satisfied that the ship's gear was safe to work. I then notified him that I was not satisfied that he had made a proper inspection and that members would not work under such unsafe conditions.

Present at this stage were Capt. M. Ingle of the O.G.S. Company and Mr. J. Dalby, local representative of the A.S.I.A. I pointed out to both these men that Capt. Wall had not made a proper inspection of the' gear and members had ' no alternative but to refuse to work with the gear as it was. Both these men stated that as Capt. Wall had passed the gear as being safe they could do nothing about it and that members would have to proceed to work.

speech.para: Whether they liked it or not. The report continues -

quote.para: I notified both Capt. Ingles and Mr. Dalby that 1 still considered the gear unsafe to use and would not allow members to subject themselves, to dangerous working conditions even if a Board of Reference was taken and a decision was given along the lines of Capt. Wall's decision. Capt. Ingles informed me that he had been placed in this very unfortunate position by Capt. Wall and he was not happy with the set up. He then agreed to cut out the badly frayed portion of the guy which Capt. Wall had passed as safe and to lower all remaining derricks for a proper inspection and replacement of any faulty gear. After a considerable amount of lost time and the replacement of a number of items of faulty gear, the ship commenced to discharge cargo, and continued until the completion of discharge. An inspection can be made if necessary of the out out portion of the guy and also two shackles which were passed by Capt. Wall as being safe for use.

speech.para: The report continues -

quote.para: I feel sure that such an inspection will bear out the farcical nature of the decision given by Capt. Wall in the first instance. I again wish to report the action of Capt. Wall who did not make any inspection of the gear but relied on the certificate carried by the ship and did not ascertain for himself if the state of the gear coincided with the certificate, merely stating that he was satisfied with the certificate and as far as he was concerned that was all that counted.

This statement was made in the presence of Captain Ingles and the A.S.I.A. local representative. Instances have been found in the past where faulty items of gear have been discovered, although the gear has been passed as safe for use according to the certificates. I feel sure that some action will have to be taken by the Federation to ensure that instances such as these are not allowed to continue whereby an accident could occur and members be maimed or suffer loss of life. The branch has previously reported the action of Captain Wall to the Federal office and once again I request that some action be taken in regard to this man's attitude.

speech.para: These matters may not affect many honorable members - perhaps they affect one or two who have ports in their electorates - but I mention them because whenever the wharfies of this country take action, which is quite often justified, everybody shouts " Corns " and in the ensuing smokescreen the wharfies are denied the wage and industrial justice to which they are entitled. In this way we continue our one-eyed policy at a time when our system is losing ground all the time.
