talk.start.para: .- In discussing the estimates for the Department of the Interior I shall relate my remarks to section 106 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, which reads -

quote.para: In printing the ballot papers to be used in the House of Representatives election the names of all candidates duly nominated shall be printed in alphabetical order according to their surnames.

speech.para: I raised this matter in the debate in May 1961 on the Commonwealth Electoral Bill. I shall make some remarks on the matter this evening because I contend that a candidate whose name occupies top position on the ballot paper undoubtedly has a marked advantage over other candidates. It is perfectly true that the Australian Labour Party took full advantage of the placement of names on the ballot paper in alphabetical order in Senate elections until the system was altered in 1939 by the Menzies Government. It is interesting to note the remarks of Mr. Perkins, Minister in Charge of External Territories at the time, who was in charge of the legislation. In his second reading speech he said -

quote.para: The Bill further provides that the order in which the respective groups are to be placed on the ballot papers shall be determined by a draw publicly conducted by the Commonwealth Electoral Officer immediately after the close of nominations. This, it is considered, will provide a much more equitable method of determining ballot paper placement than the existing system of arrangement by alphabetical calculation, inasmuch as the chances of each and every group will be fairly and squarely equalised. The adoption of this proposal will remove entirely any advantage or any handicap that may be derived merely from the possession of a particular name and, in consequence, will act as a restraint on any tendency that might develop in the selection of candidates of placing a premium on those nominees whose names happen to commence with an early letter of the alphabet.

speech.para: He further said -

quote.para: It is provided in the Bill that the system of determination of placement by draw shall apply also to the names of the candidates at House of Representatives elections. If this proposal is adopted the Divisional Returning Officer will, in each case, at the close of nominations, publicly make a draw, and the names of the candidates will appear on the ballot papers as so drawn. The justification for the proposed method lies, it is believed, in its strict fairness. Each candidate , will be given an equal chance as far as ballot paper position is concerned, irrespective of the name he bears. If his name commences with the letter A he will obtain no greater advantage or suffer no greater handicap than if it commenced with the letter Z.

speech.para: The proposal to abolish the alphabetical system for Senate elections was accepted by the Parliament but for some inexplicable reason the Government dropped the proposal in regard to House of Representatives elections, despite what the Minister had so adequately pointed out and emphasised about the unfairness of the alphabetical system.

In substantiating my case that the positions of candidates on the ballot paper should be determined by draw I shall give some statistics. In the 1958 Commonwealth elections the Australian Democratic Labour Party contested 40 electorates in New South Wales. In 15 of those electorates its candidates occupied top position on the ballot papers. Those electorates were Blaxland, Bradfield, Cowper, Eden-Monaro, Farrer, Hunter, Lawson, Lowe, Macquarie, Newcastle, New England, Paterson, Shortland, Werriwa and West Sydney. Of a total of 612.538 formal votes cast in those electorates the D.L.P. candidates gained 55,343 - an average of 9.03 per cent. The remaining 25 electorates in New South Wales contested by the D.L.P. in which its candidates did not occupy top position on the ballot paper were Banks, Barton, Bennelong, Cunningham, East Sydney, Evans, Grayndler, Hughes, Hume, Kingsford-Smith, Lang, Lyne, Mackellar, Mitchell, North Sydney, Parkes, Parramatta, Phillip, Reid, Riverina, Robertson, St. George, Warringah, Watson and Wentworth. Of a total of 1,063,749 formal votes cast in those 25 electorates the D.L.P. candidates gained 51,472 votes - an average of 4.83 per cent.

In the 1958 elections the Communist Party contested seven electorates in New South Wales. In three of those electorates - East Sydney, Grayndler and Mackellar - its candidates occupied top position on the ballot paper. Of a total of 118,585 formal votes cast in those electorates the Communist Party candidates gained 8,150 or 6.87 per cent. In the remaining- four electorates - Banks, Cunningham, Shortland and West Sydney - of a total of 171,363 formal votes cast the Communist Party gained 6,020 or 3.57 per cent. So in the electorates in which the D.L.P. occupied top position on the ballot paper its candidates polled an average of 9.03 per cent, of formal votes cast but where its candidates did not occupy top position they polled an average of 4.83 per cent, of formal votes cast - a difference of 4.2 per cent. Where the Communist Party candidate occupied top position on the ballot paper he polled 6.87 per cent, of formal votes cast. Where he was not in top position he polled 3.57 per cent. - a difference of 3.3 per cent.

Now I shall give some figures in relation to the 1963 Commonwealth elections, using results as printed in the newspapers on 2nd December 1963. The official figures have not yet been printed. In 1963 the D.L.P. contested 31 electorates in New South Wales. Its candidates occupied top position on the ballot paper in 20 of those electorates - Barton, Blaxland, Bradfield, Calare, Dalley, Eden-Monaro, Evans, Farrer, Hughes, Hunter, Newcastle, North Sydney, Parkes, Phillip, Reid, Riverina, Robertson, Shortland, Watson and West Sydney. Of a total of 770,454 formal votes cast in those electorates the D.L.P. candidates gained 58,414 or 7.58 per cent. In the remaining eleven electorates in which the D.L.P. candidate did not occupy top position - Bennelong, Hume, Lawson, Lowe, Macarthur, Mackellar, Mitchell, Parramatta, St. George, Warringah and Werriwa - of a total of 530,221 formal votes cast the D.L.P. candidates polled 23,213 or 4.37 per cent. So it may be readily seen that where the D.L.P. candidate held top position on the ballot paper he polled an average of 7.58 per cent, of formal votes cast compared with an average of 4.37 per cent, of formal votes cast when he did not occupy top position. The difference here is 3.21 per cent.

I shall give two other notable illustrations to make my point. First I will compare the votes recorded by P. M. Clancy, the Communist Party candidate in the electorate of Banks in the 1955 and 1958 general elections. In 1 955 Clancy occupied top position on the ballot paper. Of a total of 41,875 formal votes cast he polled 3,356 or 8.01 per cent. In 1958, when Clancy's name was not in the top position, of a total of 48,701 formal votes he gained 1,634 or 3.35 per cent. The difference was 4.66 per cent. The second illustration concerns my own electorate of Watson. In the 1961 election the D.LP. candidate was a Miss Mary Nappa, whose name did not occupy the top position on the ballot paper. Of a total of 36,294 formal votes, she gained 1,081 or 2.97 per cent. It is interesting to note that this lady has resided in the Mascot sub-division of the Watson electorate for many years and is widely known in that area. In addition, she was widely advertised by propaganda and posters as well as by workers at the main polling booth.

In the 1963 elections the D.L.P. candidate was a chap named Atkinson. He was a resident of Manly, in the electorate of Mackellar. He was completely unknown in the Watson electorate. He was not advertised by any propaganda or posters and had not one solitary worker at any polling booth. Yet, simply because his name occupied the top position on the ballot paper, he polled 2,136 votes compared with the 1,081 votes polled by Miss Nappa in 1961.

A very conservative estimate of the advantage gained from the top position on the ballot paper is from 2± to 3 per cent., or from 1,000 to 1,200 votes in 40,000. It is quite obvious that the D.L.P. is selecting as candidates as many people as possible whose names will occupy the top position, for the purpose of obtaining what is known as the donkey vote and no doubt with the object of endeavouring to hoodwink the people of New South Wales into believing that it is not a dwindling political party.

We are all well aware that many people, especially those who are in a hurry and absentee voters, merely vote across the Senate ballot paper and down the House of Representatives ballot paper. Although we appreciate that such a vote is not an intelligent one, I submit that it is agreed that all candidates in a Commonwealth election should have an equal right to benefit from that kind of vote. That equality applies in Senate elections, but not in House of Representatives elections. Will any honorable member say that drawing for positions on the ballot paper is not fair and just?

In conclusion, let me remind honorable members that a system similar to the one I have proposed was introduced in 1939 by the Menzies Government for the purpose of destroying the advantage that was being gained by the Australian Labour Party in the Senate. The system was also to be introduced in House of Representatives elections. Positions on the ballot paper were to be determined by drawing out of a hat. But, as I said before, for some inexplicable reason, the matter was dropped when it was going through the Senate. Consequently, we still have an antiquated method of placing names on the House of Representatives ballot paper. 1 have nothing to cavil about in respect of my own name. I have had the top position at practically every election that I have contested. But I believe it is completely unfair that any person should be at a disadadvantage simply because the initial letter of his name is low in the alphabet. Despite the fact that some parties might gain from the present system, I submit to the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Anthony) and the Government that not one honorable member believes that a draw out of a hat is not a fair and just way of determining positions on the ballot paper.

talk.start.para: .- I direct my remarks to the estimates for the Department of the Interior and the Australian News and Information Bureau in particular. I notice that last year the expenditure was £713,725 and that this year it is expected to rise to £844,000- an increase of about £131,000. Since I returned from the United States of America I have made some inquiries about the activities and functions of the Bureau. I became very interested in the reasons for the lack of knowledge of Australia in the United States. That lack of knowledge was offset slightly by a seemingly inbuilt admiration for Australia and Australians which ran right across the American nation among people in all walks of life. But what struck mc very forcibly was the lack of real knowledge of Australia.

speech.para: In fact, I specifically asked practically everyone I met - whether he was a businessman, a government employee, a taxi driver or a hotel porter - what the name "Australia" conjured up in his mind. In 99 cases out of 100, the first answer I received was: "Kangaroos". The second answer was: "It is a place that is mostly desert ". The third answer was: " We understand that you have a lot of Aborigines down there ". That is dead true. I believe - the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Anthony) almost certainly agrees with me - that the appropriation for the News and Information
Bureau is out of all proportion to its importance.
I asked the Bureau what its functions were. I will quote the first paragraph of this document which sets out the functions and operations of the Bureau. It states -

quote.para: To produce as required publicity and information material for dissemination abroad with the object of making Australia as a whole more widely and more favorably known; of helping the people of other countries to understand Australia's outlook, endeavours and potentialities; and of helping to foster good relationships in all Australia's dealings with other countries.

speech.para: Particularly at this stage of the development of Australia, with a terrific shortage of skilled labour - in fact, a terrific shortage of labour and desirable migrants of all kinds - surely the News and Information Bureau is a vital adjunct to our immigration programme in alerting people and giving them a knowledge of what is in Australia and what its potentialities are.

My statement that the American people think that almost the only things in Australia are kangaroos, desert and Aborigines is borne out by two articles that I have cut from the Melbourne " Herald ". One article described the experiences of Lady Nathan, who is the wife of a former Lord Mayor of Melbourne. On her return to Australia in August this year she said that it was not surprising that Americans knew little about Australia, as she saw only one news item about Australia in the newspapers while she was in the United States. I must confess that, although I did not read every newspaper from cover to cover, which is impossible when we realise that the Sunday issue of the " New York Times " has about 357 pages, this fact impressed itself on my mind: Very little news about Australia was available or reached the columns of the American newspapers. Another person who made a statement on her return to Australia from the United States was the Moomba Queen, Ria Luyben. She returned on 8th September of this year. She had been in the United States for two months. She said -

quote.para: The Americans are wonderful people, but simply have no idea of what Australia is like. . . .
Why, they even asked me if we had showers and baths. . . .
In Florida people asked "Do you have supermarket'!, and cars like ours? "

speech.para: That is very true. Attorneys and other well educated people in the United States asked me: " Where do you get most of your motor cars? Do you import them from the United States or from the United Kingdom? " When I told them that we make most of the motor cars we use, they were very interested but quite dumbfounded.

The News and Information Bureau not only has a vital role to play in our immigration programme, but its activities also contribute to the number of tourists who visit Australia. My colleague the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. King) and others who have been in the United States would no doubt agree with me. I was there for only a short time, but I constantly heard the same comments. I have already mentioned the lack of knowledge about Australia and the obvious liking for Australia and Australians. Whether the people in the United States know anything about Australia, there is no doubt our reputation with them is very good. Right across America, people in various occupations expressed a tremendous interest in coming to Australia either as tourists or as migrants. I think we could increase the number of people interested in Australia or help those already thinking about Australia to make up their minds if we increased the efforts of the News and Information Bureau in the United States.

I met our representatives in New York. They are Mr. Hamilton, who had just been posted there, and Mr. Eric Spark. They were obviously dedicated to their job, but they were only two people working on a limited budget. I see that the amount provided this year for the officers in the United States is £73,000, made up of salaries of £34,000 and operating expenditure of £39,000. This would not even scratch the surface of the work to be done in a city like New York and would mean nothing when related to the area that these people must cover. The only other office in the United States is in San Francisco, which is on the other side of the continent. There is no thought in my mind to reflect on the ability of the officers or on the job they are doing, but it is obvious that their budget is too small for their task. Expenditure of £39.000 on publicity may be all right in Australia, but we must lake a different view of the scale of the task in the United States, which has a population of 190 million.

talk.start.para: - The cost structure there is double ours, too.

- That is right. The £39,000, which is approximately 80,000 dollars, is really worth only about £20,000 in Australian currency. As I said earlier, I do not know whether the honorable member for Wimmera, when he was there, found that the Americans have an intense interest in Australia, but I certainly did.

speech.para: We are now looking for skilled labour and for desirable migrants. I am aware that we would have some difficulties in America, but we oan overcome them. I would like to see a trial of a concentrated publicity campaign in, say, two cities on the west coast of America. I was not able to speak during the debate on the estimates for the Department of Immigration, but I had intended to make this proposal when referring to the immigration programme. However, I make it now when referring to the News and Information Bureau. Instead of trying to spread the available funds on publicity across the whole of the United States, I suggest we concentrate our efforts on Los Angeles and San Francisco. These are the two biggest of the American cities in closer proximity to Australia. If people in this area want to come to Australia, either as tourists or as migrants, obviously the fares from these two cities will be lower than the fares from cities in the middle or on the east coast of the United States. I heard numerous complaints about the smog in Los Angeles, but nevertheless the population there is increasing rapidly. I am certain we could attract many people from the west coast of the United States, if we could give them a realistic picture of Australia, and they would be desirable migrants. I heard comments on several films about Australia that were shown in America. The films seemed to deal only with the outback parts of Australia. Everyone respects the pioneering efforts of the people who developed the outback and are still developing it, but I think it fair to say that a film of our outback does not really give a true picture of our great industrial development or. for that matter, of many other primary producing areas.

I intend my remarks to be thoughtprovoking and to support the representations that the Minister has doubtless made to appropriate quarters for a bigger allocation of finance for the purpose of publicising Australia overseas. There is not much more I want to say on this subject. The scale of operations in the United States of America of our News and Information Bureau is not realistic. I repeat that there is tremendous potential there and I hope that a more realistic approach will be made by the Government in the near future to the provision of finance for the Bureau.

Mr. DUTHIE(Wilmot) 19.581. - I wish to refer to the Department of the Interior and to the Australian Capital Territory. The Department of the Interior is responsible for our vast electoral system and I want to make a plea for a pay increase for the electoral officers throughout Australia. I make ho apology for doing so. The Commonwealth electoral officers have been working very hard. In the last 18 years we have had eight Federal elections. Many of the electoral officers also conduct State elections from the same polling booths. I appeal to the Government to examine the salaries of these very devoted servants of the Department of the Interior. They have a tremendous task to perform and they are devoted to their duties, which are repetitive and detailed. They must be very accurate, especially when recording names on the rolls.

The geography of the electorates and the number of polling booths have to be taken into account also. Some country electorates are large in area and polling booths are widely scattered. Electoral officers have to travel hundreds of miles, ensuring that all the necessary electoral apparatus is provided at isolated polling booths before polling day and supervising polling on the day. The electorate of Wilmot covers almost half Tasmania and has an area of 13,000 square miles. It has about 175 polling booths. Only three other electorates in Australia have more. This large area and the great number of polling booths involve a great deal of work for the electoral officers in the conduct of elections. Halls and schools have to be booked and assistance has to bc engaged. Some of those who helped in the previous election may have passed away and others may not be able to take on the job again. Some refuse to take it on again because they consider that the pay is not high enough. However, I am not for the moment discussing the remuneration paid to those who assist on polling day. I direct my remarks particularly to the pay of permanent electoral officers who supervise the elections in the various electorates. This is another matter entirely.

These men bear the responsibility for conducting elections accurately, conscientiously and dispassionately. We all agree, I am sure, that they have been well selected for the job. In the light of my experience of the conduct of elections in my electorate and other constituencies in Tasmania, I cannot speak too highly of the generosity of the electoral officers in giving advice, of their impartiality and of their firmness in refusing to become involved in politics - something that is very difficult in this age of high pressure politics. Often, because of short notice, considerable speed is required in making preparations for an election. At all times, care and accuracy must be maintained. Today, electoral officers bear greater responsibilities than ever before because the number of voters in each electorate throughout Australia continually increases. I urge the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Anthony) to ensure that the pay of these officers is increased in proportion to the growing complexity, difficulty and responsibility of their work. I ask him to consider the matter carefully and particularly to take note of the length of time that has elapsed since the pay of these officers was last increased. The Minister may well be shocked when he learns what has been happening in recent years. Our electoral officers are usually the last persons to be thought of when conditions and pay are being improved. But they are the first to be thought of when work has to be done at election time.

At this juncture, I feel compelled to criticise the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) for his childishness in refusing to announce the date of the forthcoming Senate election. We are led to believe that some bodies in Australia have virtually been told unofficially by him that the date of the election will be 5th December, but no official announcement has been made. Not one electoral officer throughout Australia yet knows when the polling day will be. Let us consider what these officers have to do to prepare for a poll. Once the date is announced, they have to declare a date for the closing of the rolls. That may be three weeks ahead and rolls have to be printed. If the polling date for the Senate election is to be 5th December, the Prime Minister is imposing on electoral officers an almost impossible task in requiring them to have all the arrangements ready for that date since the official announcement has been so long delayed. Even now, on 14th October, we do not know when the Senate election will be held. The refusal to announce the polling date, in my view, constitutes a downright discourtesy to the electoral officers throughout the Commonwealth who are faced with the task of booking halls and schools for use as polling booths. I point out that if the polling date is to be 5th December, the schools will not have been cleared for the school holidays. Furthermore, at that time of the year, many halls are booked for various end of year functions and electoral officers may have to make sudden changes of the locations of booths. The imposition on these devoted men of this tremendous task by the withholding of the announcement of the polling date owing to the fantastic childishness of the Prime Minister is not fair, Mr. Temporary Chairman. The right honorable gentleman has virtually said: " I shall withhold the announcement of the date of the Senate election until the last possible moment."

talk.start.para: - What does Mr. Renshaw think?
- What has that to do with the matter?
- We should like to know when the State election in New South Wales will be held.

- That will be held next year, not within the next two months. The Prime Minister is supposed to have told a Liberal organisation that the date of the Senate election will be 5th December. His whole attitude constitutes sheer humbug. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell) guessed the date of the last Federal general election and announced it long before the Prime Minister officially announced the date. Perhaps this will happen again. One of these days, honorable members opposite will grow up in these matters.

speech.para: I now wish to discuss a matter relating to Canberra, which I regard as Tasmania's front door city. In my view, Canberra is Australia's show place and one of the great show places of the world. Those honorable members who have told us in recent weeks of what they have seen in other countries throughout the world in their travels during the recess surely agree with me that no capital city in any other country is the equal of Canberra. I have never been to Brasilia, the new capital of Brazil, which is hidden in the jungles, but I am certain that for sheer beauty and perfection of planning Canberra beats all the rest of the world's capitals. I congratulate the National Capital Development Commission on the magnificent work it has done throughout the years in planning this city so that industry is located in areas apart from residential development and shopping centres, which have their own particular locations elsewhere. This is a city without slums. It is characterised by beautiful, wide streets and a multitude of flower beds and plantations. A total of 15 million pine trees are planted on the hills about Canberra for the benefit of future generations.

I pay tribute especially to the honorable member for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr. J. R. Fraser) for what he has done in having this city developed to the present stage. While he has represented the city, many a Minister has been forced by the sheer pressure of his representations to improve numerous aspects of the city's development.

talk.start.para: - He is able to concentrate on the task for 365 days of the year.

- That is true. The present Minister for the Interior has brought tremendous energy to his task. He does not belong to the party to which I belong, but I shall be fair and say that he is trying hard to master the various complex problems that he encounters in his job of administering this city. He is discharging his task in a way that I regard as very commendable, though I do not say mat a Labour occupant of the same position would not do the job better. I pay tribute to the Minister for what he has done so far. He certainly merits a tribute for the way he has hurried ahead the extensions to the present Parliament House. If only the Government would exhibit a similar sense of urgency about the construction of the new Parliament House, we might get somewhere. Even now, the National Capital Development Commission has not been given the green light to go ahead with the planning of the new Parliament House for this lovely city. This delay is outrageous.

speech.para: I now make another plea for the honouring of King O'Malley in this city, Mr. Temporary Chairman. I heard an honorable member say: " Oh ". It is all very well to say that. I point out that King O'Malley was the man who was most directly responsible for the establishment of this city. Yet he has not so far been honoured officially here. In my view, this is scandalous. He was born overseas and represented the Tasmanian electorate of Darwin in this Parliament for about 17 years, holding the office of Minister for Home Affairs in the Fisher Government at the time when the planning of this city was begun. His name is commemorated here only on a slab of stone situated on Capital Hill. This is part of a structure more reminiscent of a tomb than a national monument. Not one street in this city, not one cul de sac, not one post office has been named after him. He is commemorated by virtually nothing and has been completely ignored. I want to know why. The names of all sorts of individuals have been com,memorated in the suburbs of this city, though they were men not nearly so important as King O'Malley was in the political sense. This capital city would not have existed if he had not set to work on the task of planning and establishing it. If honorable members read the story of his life, they will realise how true this is. In the first place, King O'Malley did not want the National Capital established here. He was opposed to the construction of a capital city in this area. However, once he became Minister for Home Affairs, about 1910, to his great credit, he forgot or ignored his earlier objections to this site and fought like a tiger for the initial development of this city. He deserves to be honoured in this city. I have been fighting in this Parliament for six years to have his name honoured, but his name is not yet even on a street.

It is a scandalous, disgraceful and disrespectful thing to treat in this way the memory of a man who did so much to get this city started. I know about his flam.boyancy and I certainly do not agree with all the manifestations of it. I do not agree with many of the statements that he made. But 1 think he should be honoured for what he did as a Federal Minister to get this great city started. I appeal to the present Minister for the Interior to forget all the prejudice displayed by his predecessors. It has been only prejudice that has prevented this man's memory from being honoured by naming a street or suburb after him. I appeal to the Minister to ensure, during his term of office, that the name of King ©'Malley is honoured by being bestowed on a suburb. We have a suburb called O'Connor, so why should we not have one called O'Malley?

I make this appeal earnestly and sincerely to the Minister. This is the first time I have spoken to him about it since he has accepted the responsibility of his office. Other suburbs have been named for people who were less notable than King O'Malley, and I cannot understand the prejudice displayed by the Liberal Government through the years in not naming a suburb after this man. He was a figure of great stature in Tasmania and took a stand on the conscription issue. He showed tremendous courage in doing so. In fact, like many other people, he signed his political death warrant over the issue of conscription. His story is a fascinating one. It is the story of a man from another country rising to great heights in Australia by his own efforts. He pulled himself up by his own boot straps, with no help at all from anyone. These are matters that should he taken into account, and I appeal to the Minister to give the late King O'Malley a go in this great city of Canberra which we all admire so much.

talk.start.para: .- Every year I have spoken in the debate on the estimates for the Department of the Interior and now and again I have made some comments about the Australian Capital Territory. Tonight, I would like to speak about a matter that is administered by the Department of the Interior. First, I. want to compliment the honorable member for Watson (Mr. Cope), as I have done on a previous occasion, for the stand he has adopted in the matter of the procedure to be followed in deciding where the names of candidates should appear on ballot sheets at federal elections. Although the honorable member's name starts with " C ", he has said that he believes a draw should be made to determine positions on ballot sheets. Candidates with names start ing with " A ", " B " or " C " are sure of having their names at the top of the ballot sheet in that order. My name starts with "T" and I usually find it at the bottom. On only one occasion, when there were three candidates, was my name not at the bottom. It was then the middle of the three names. Probably it is of more advantage to be at either the top or the bottom than in the middle, because the name is less conspicuous when in the middle. The honorable member for Watson made out a good case. I thought he was very fair, because he would not benefit in any way from the adoption of his suggestion. I want to compliment him. 1 believe that a draw such as he suggests should be made, and I put that proposition to the Minister. I believe he should investigate the possibility of adopting this practice.

speech.para: I desire to speak also of the hours of polling. A move has been made to have the hours shortened, so that polling will still commence at 8 a.m. but will conclude at 6 p.m. I can hear a Queenslander interjecting. All I can say is that probably those shortened hours would be of advantage in certain areas, but we must have times to suit everybody in Australia because we are speaking of federal elections. If an election is held about December or the end of November, the people in the area that I represent are engaged in bringing in the harvest. Everybody who has been engaged in primary production knows that a farmer stripping oats or wheat must stay in the field as long as possible to get the job finished. No one can be certain that a storm will not arrive unexpectedly, leaving a good deal of wheat or oats on the ground, in which event the farmers will lose much of their harvest. For this reason I ask the Minister not to take any notice of this suggestion of shortened polling hours and to continue with the hours that operate at present, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. These hours have proved very suitable for the whole of Australia.

talk.start.para: - No.

- The honorable member for Scullin says: "No". He lives in a city. What does he know about conditions in the country? I do not want to engage in an argument with him about this matter. I merely say that he and his constituents can walk to the polling booth on Saturday afternoon when all the shops are closed and cast their votes. This is not the case with voters in the country, who have to go miles in many cases to cast their votes. It is true that people have motor cars to take them to the polling centres, but I remind the Committee that many of the men in my electorate and other rural electorates find it necessary to work long hours in the fields, and it is of great advantage to them to be able to come in and cast their votes between 7.30 and 8 p.m.

speech.para: There is another matter about which I have always spoken when the estimates for the Department of the Interior have been debated. The Commonwealth Electoral Act provides that when the Distribution Commissioners have decided on a quota of voters, that quota may be varied by as much as 20 per cent, up or down in electorates. I have always advocated that in country electorates the quota should be reduced wherever possible so that sizes of electorates may be similarly reduced. I represent an electorate covering 18,500 square miles. There is an electorate in Victoria with an area of less than five square miles. If every electorate in Victoria was of the same area as the one I represent, there would be only five members in this chamber from the whole State. At present there are 33.

Members of the Labour Party have always said that they believe in one vote one value, but of course they are inconsistent, because the State of Tasmania has as many representatives in the Senate as has New South Wales or Victoria. Members of the Opposition carry their advocacy of one vote one value only as far as its suits them. Of course it does not suit them to have decentralised districts in the country with smaller areas and fewer voters, although the limitation provided by the Electoral Act would still leave country representatives, even if my suggestion were adopted, with quite large areas to look after. Members representing country electorates, however, would have a much better chance to get around those electorates, and the problem of decentralisation would be much easier to solve.

When I spoke on this subject on a previous occasion a Labour member said: " Surely the honorable member for Mallee is not of the opinion that more people would go to live in country electorates simply because there were smaller electorates and more members ". He suggested that there were many reasons, not associated with electoral matters, why decentralisation was not being achieved. He referred to problems such as high freight charges. The answer is that if we could achieve decentralisation in the field of political representation, the greater numbers of members would soon deal, at both the Federal and State levels, for instance, with freight rates and have them reduced. This would induce more people to go to the country areas.

I also want to compliment the honorable member for Indi (Mr. Holten) who spoke about the News and Information Bureau. I do not know exactly how this Bureau operates in the United States of America, but I believe that it should operate there to full capacity. It is a potent information and publicity medium that could be used to greater advantage in the United States of America and in other parts of the world to advertise Australia. If I may digress a little for a moment, let me say that it is surprising how many people in Australia itself are ignorant of their own country. Many people in the capital cities have no idea where certain towns in Victoria are situated. If I go to Western Australia, for instance, I have quite a job to get news from Victoria. The news is very sparsely presented in the newspapers. You do not get much news from other parts of Australia. Therefore, it is understandable that if you go right across to the United States pf America, where they are concerned with their own affairs, it is very hard to get information there to let you know what is happening in Victoria. There was a joke about the Mallee electorate. People like to make jokes about the Mallee, for some reason that I do not know. Somebody said in reference to the Mallee: "That is away up in the decentralised areas. Why, some people in the Mallee have never been to Melbourne." The man from the Mallee replied straight away: "Yes, perhaps that is so, but there are many people in Melbourne who have never been to the Mallee ". That illustrates the point that I am trying to make about publicity.

The honorable member for Indi put forward a good case. I should like the Minister to take note of it and if by spending a few more thousands of pounds we can get better publicity in the United States than we have at present the suggestion advanced by the honorable member for Indi should be adopted. I am not suggesting that the Minister should undertake this scheme or seek a greater allocation immediately, but he should make investigations. Trips overseas, such as those taken by the honorable member for Indi, the honorable member for 'Wimmera (Mr. King) and other members, enable them to obtain information overseas that they can bring back to Australia for the benefit of this country. For that reason the more members who go overseas and come back to speak in this chamber of their experiences in other countries and make suggestions like those made tonight, the better it should be for this country.

talk.start.para: . - The honorable member for Indi (Mr. Holten) and the , honorable member for Mallee (Mr. Turnbull) both referred to the need for an expansion of the activities of the News and Information bureau within the Department of the Interior. I quite agree that that expansion should be provided for and that the Department should be provided with funds to engage journalists of the calibre required to produce the documents that are required properly to publicise this country overseas. But it is worth recalling that the Chifley Government maintained a Department of Information under the control of the then Minister for Immigration. The publicity obtained by that Department, not only for our migration programme but for other aspects of our development, was extremely valuable indeed.

speech.para: It must be remembered that it was the present Government that destroyed the Department of Information - destroyed the whole organisation of that Department and deprived Australia of the benefits of established sources of publicity which had been well nurtured and well maintained by the officers of the Department. First, the Govvernment cut out some of the publications that the Department had been producing and distributing to various centres throughout the world. So when the honorable member for Indi, who has not been here long enough to realise the value of the Department of Information, and the honorable member for Mallee, who remembers its value, make these suggestions they might just give a thought to the fact that it was their own Government which destroyed the Department of Information, which did so much valuable work for this country, and relegated this important service to a small part of the Department of the Interior. Admittedly, the clerical staff of that section is probably greater than the strength of the Department of Information as it existed, but the officers of the News and Information Bureau are dispersed among the various Commonwealth departments where they are providing the publicity for the Commonwealth departments and agencies within Australia. I believe that the vote for this essential service should be increased so that it will be able to provide a greater cover of publicity overseas to the great benefit of Australia. I hope that the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Anthony) will be able to take the advice given by the honorable members for Indi and Mallee and see that that is done.

I want to refer to some aspects of development within the Australian Capital Territory. This afternoon the Minister for the Interior tabled a document headed " The Future Canberra ". In introducing the document the Minister made a statement to the House. I have not had an opportunity, of course, to study the document in detail, and I do not doubt that a close study of it will be valuable, but I want to refer to some of the Minister's comments when he presented this document to the House, because it does have a bearing on the question of the development and the growth of this National Capital. The Minister said this afternoon -

quote.para: The city has now gathered an impetus of its own making. The kind of stimulation which the Government itself has provided in the past is now becoming less evident as the city develops strong commercial momentum in parallel with any other Australian city of comparable size.

speech.para: That is true, but it is true to an extent only. It repeats a concept that has been expressed by the National Capital Development Commission. However, I think it remains completely true that if you took government out of this city the city would just fall apart like a pack of cards. There is nothing to maintain the city other than government activity. The commercial activity and the business activity has been attracted to this centre only because of the establishment of this place as the seat of government and the fact that governmental activity to an increasing degree is concentrated in this city. But take government out of it and there would be nothing left. The people would disappear and we would have the 14-story monuments to private enterprise in the insurance field marking the limestone plain. The Minister said also -

quote.para: In the particular situation that exists in Canberra, with land in public ownership, the authorities responsible for planning and development on behalf of this Parliament are presented with a unique opportunity of guiding and fashioning growth in a manner which will achieve the highest measure of convenience and amenity for the residents within a framework of economic development, and which will guarantee achievement of the character and qualities required in areas of national significance.

speech.para: The Minister said also -

quote.para: One must consider the growth returns that arc accruing to the Commonwealth from Canberra's development and note the extent to which these are being used to the benefit of the Australian taxpayer and indirectly the Canberra community.

speech.para: Of course the document which was tabled has references of a similar kind. There will, presumably, be some debate on this document, and, as I have said, I hope to have an opportunity to study it more closely. It has a grandiose title - "The Future Canberra ". Certainly the sub-title is " A Long Range Plan for Land Use and City Design " but from a cursory examination it seems that the document gives no picture of what the future Canberra will be. It uses a great number of words to say really very little, because it does not say the essential things. It talks of the population increasing to 250,000 in the next 20 years. We have a population now of 80,000, and we will have a population of 100,000 in 1967. In 1984- the Commission now hedges slightly on that date, but, generally speaking, in 1984 - the population will be 250,000. But the Commission does not say where those people will live. It does not say in particular terms where they will work, where they will receive their education, where they will worship and so on. But, essentially, it does not say where they will live.

I cannot follow the Government's reasoning in this aspect of Canberra's development. We are not providing adequately for the housing of the people of Canberra today. Our planning is completely inadequate for the housing of the people of Canberra tomorrow and in the next decade and, indeed, in the next generation. I cannot understand why the Government does not see what must be done and ensure that it is done. It is no good talking and it is no good using picturesque language and most beautiful illustrations of the future Canberra if you are not going to provide the places in which the people will live.

It is worth recalling figures which I have quoted to this House previously and which show that in the years of Canberra's greatest population increase the Commonwealth has built year by year fewer and fewer family housing units - fewer and fewer homes for families. It is true that the Commonwealth Government claims it is building Canberra in partnership with private enterprise. It is true that the Government is trying to shuck off as much as it can of its responsibility to build homes in Canberra on to private enterprise. Private enterprise cannot meet the needs of the many thousands who come here and who must be provided with rental houses. Those people cannot afford to buy a house built by private enterprise; nor can they afford the rentals that private enterprise must demand.

The record of the Commonwealth Government in regard to housing over recent years has shown this continual reduction in the number of homes being built. In the financial year 1958-59, the Commonwealth Government built in Canberra 1,235 family housing units. They consisted of houses an two or three bedroom flats, all premises that will accommodate families. The population of Canberra then was 44,000. In the financial year 1959-60, the Commonwealth Government built in Canberra 1,151 Commonwealth housing units. The population of Canberra then was 50,200. In 1960-61, the total number of various housing units constructed by the Commonwealth fell to 868. In 1961-62, the figure rose slightly to 960. in 1962-63 the total number of family housing units built by the Commonwealth was 721. In the financial year just completed the total was only 736. In the "Civil Works Programme " which accompanies the Budget papers, provision has been made for the construction of 800 houses and no family flats in the financial year with which we are now dealing.

I say to the Minister and, through him, to the Government that unless you are seised of the urgent necessity for planning for the future housing needs of the people of this city you will come up against the problem that this city has experienced far too often. After delay and procrastination take place, there is suddenly a realisation that the increase in population demands increased housing and we have this panic exigent type of construction that too frequently has marred this city and which will blot it in the future unless we act now and plan for the future needs of the people.

This has happened in past years. Our own Labour Government was not free of guilt in this respect, but it might have had more excuse for its failure because of the difficulties of the post-war years and the need to attract the initial work force to this city. I make no criticism of the establishment of the Narrabundah pre-fab. area which was built to house the British tradesmen brought here to build Canberra. But I do criticise the regimented .construction of pre-fab. houses in the O'Connor and Turner areas. 1 criticise the subsequent action of this Government in continuing the construction of monocrete houses which have proved quite unsatisfactory in this climate. If we go through suburb after suburb we oan pick the signs of this panic home construction which is, in most aspects, sub-standard.

In the financial year 1963-64, the Commonwealth Government constructed 736 family housing units. They were all houses, by the way; there were no family flats in that total figure. But if honorable members look at the housing statistics issued by the Department of the Interior, and particularly at the housing grants, it will be found that of that total of 736 houses, only 328 were allocated to people on the ordinary waiting list in Canberra. In the September quarter of 1963 - the first quarter of that financial year - the Commonwealth Government completed the construction of 243 homes, but only 149 of them were allocated to people on the ordinary waiting list in Canberra. In the December quarter of the year, 201 houses were constructed, but only 115 of those were allocated to people on the ordinary waiting list in Canberra. In the March quarter of this year only 47 of the 126 houses which were constructed were allocated to people on the ordinary waiting list in Canberra. In the final quarter of the financial year - that is, the quarter ended 30th June 1964 - the Commonwealth Government completed the construction of 164 houses in Canberra of which only 17 were allocated to families which were in Canberra and waiting for housing. The other homes had to be held for departmental personnel transferred from Melbourne to Canberra. In the same period, the number of people on the waiting list for housing in Canberra grew from a. total of 2,601 at 30th September 1963 to 3,361 at the end of June 1964.

There is great need not only for an increased number of houses and an increased construction programme, but also for the Commission to review the design of its houses and to realise that the homes being built today are far too small for the family needs of the people of Canberra. This is a city in which it is now recognised that there is some need to provide additional housing and larger areas for the larger families. In another context earlier this evening, I suggested that it might not be a bad idea to appoint a committee of Mums who could have a look at the houses being designed for use in Canberra and advise the Commission and the Government on what is really needed in the housing position here. I think the Minister can take my assurance, although he does not really need it because he knows this himself, that the houses being built by the Commission today are far too small for the needs of proper family living. This is a factor in the housing situation that the Minister should study very closely indeed. I think that if he seeks the advice of women's organisations or even obtains the opinions of ordinary housewives in this city, he and the Commission will gain valuable assistance.

talk.start.para: . - This debate on the estimates of the Department of the Interior has been very constructive. All honorable members who have spoken have put forward useful points of view. The honorable member for Watson (Mr. Cope) and the honorable member for Mallee (Mr. Turnbull) brought up the point that at election time candidates' names should be placed in position on a ballot paper as determined by draw rather than in alphabetical order. All I want to say is that a number of amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act will be introduced, and all these matters will be considered before those amendments are presented to the House. That would be an appropriate occasion, I think, for the House to debate such proposals. Whilst it seems to stagger some honorable members to learn that there has never been a draw for positions on a ballot paper -
- You would not want one.

- I do not speak from a personal point of view. It is quite interesting to note that whenever there is preferential voting, or a single candidate has to be selected, the alphabetical system seems to be maintained in the Federal, State, and local government spheres and in respect of many of our organisations such as farm marketing boards. So there seems to be every justification for having this system maintained.

speech.para: The honorable member for Watson produced a lot of figures in order to show that the candidate whose name appeared at the top of a ballot paper had a definite advantage over his rivals. I want to assure the honorable member that I have seen a lot of figures which prove that there is no advantage. When you start to argue with figures you can argue as you like to produce the result you want. But I am not speaking in this debate to raise any controversial matter. What I am saying is that when I bring before this House various amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, this matter will be looked at.

talk.start.para: - What about the arguments used by Mr. Perkins in 1939 when he sought to introduce such a proposal?
- The honorable member makes reference to a case submitted 25 years ago. AH I want to say is that in the period when the Labour Party was in office it maintained the alphabetical system.
- We were winning then.

- You must have had a lot of members whose names began with " A " in those days. I would like to pay a tribute to the honorable member for Indi (Mr. Holten) and also the other honorable members who spoke about the News and Information Bureau. I have been a member of this Parliament for a number of years, and this is the first time I have heard the estimates for this section of the Depart ment of the Interior discussed. I am very pleased about that because I consider the News and Information Bureau to be very important. The object of the Bureau is to try to project an image of Australia to other countries. It is not established for the purpose of disseminating news in Australia, although some of its publications such as " Facts and Figures " and " The Australian Handbook " have a much wider circulation in Australia than overseas.

speech.para: The Bureau has representatives in London, New York, Karachi, Delhi, Djakarta, Ottawa, Bonn, Paris, Kuala Lumpur and San Francisco. I hope that in the near future it will have an office in Japan also. The publication of information about Australia overseas is a very difficult task. When I was on a tour of India and Pakistan recently I heard people connected with the Press there refer to Australia as being a dead news country. Because we do not have revolutions, and because" we do not have many changes of government, Australia does not stir up much excitement in journalists overseas. Our sporting activities, however, do get a great share of publicity overseas. I know that in India and Pakistan the test matches between Australia and England are given as much space in the newspapers there as in Australia. Our hockey and athletics activities also command a great deal of attention. In America, Australian tennis receives great publicity.

The material disseminated by the News and Information Bureau includes weekly circulars to our representatives in various countries. Those circulars contain information relating to political affairs, religious affairs, sporting activities, cultural activities, economic trends in Australia, and so on. Our representatives overseas circulate that information to the Press in the various countries. But, as all members of Parliament know, it is not always easy to have published in newspapers the news that you want to have published. It is certainly very difficult to have published in other countries the news that we want to have published about Australia.

In projecting the image of Australia overseas, the Bureau adopts a special method for each country. For instance, in Europe, where we are promoting our immigration policy, we try to project an image of Australia as a very good country to which to come to live, a country with a good standard of living and a country in which immigrants will be welcomed. In South East Asia, we try to project the image that we wish to extend goodwill and friendliness, that we want to extend aid under the Colombo Plan by educating their young people at our universities and colleges. In America and Britain, we seek to project an image calculated to attract tourists to Australia. In other cases, we seek to attract foreign investment to Australia. It will be seen, therefore, that the Bureau has a difficult task to perform with the limited amount of finance available for its operations. As I have said, I welcome the suggestions that have been put forward and I am very grateful to the honorable member for Indi for bringing the subject up tonight.

The honorable member for Wilmot (Mr. Duthie) mentioned the salaries of electoral officers. I agree with him that our electoral officers have a full-time and difficult job. I believe that they should be paid a good salary. The electoral officers are responsible for the successful working of our electoral system, which is the very basis of our democratic system, and it is most important that we have well qualified men doing this work. I point out, however, that the question of increases in salaries for electoral officers is one for the Public Service Board. The fact that the honorable member for Wilmot has mentioned the matter in this Parliament must filter through to the Public Service Board and no doubt it will do these officers some good when they are submitting their case for an increase.

I did not take kindly to the remark by the honorable member for Wilmot that the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) should be censured for not announcing the date of the Senate election. It is not easy to announce the date of a Senate election, because the system is different from that Which applies to an election for the House of Representatives. As the honorable member for Wilmot may be aware, the Governors of the various States issue the writs for a Senate election. Section 12 of the Constitution gives them that right. When there is to be a Senate election, the Prime Minister has to write to the various Premiers seeking their approval of the date proposed. Until he receives word from the various States that the State Governors have approved of the date, the Prime Minister cannot make any announcement. In some States, especially South Australia, the position is somewhat complicated. For instance, in South Australia the announcement of the issue of a writ must be published in the South Australian " Government Gazette" nine days before the writ is issued. The announcement of a date for a Senate election is not as simple as it looks on the surface. There has been a good deal of talk about an election date. No doubt this is because information has leaked out from various State sources, indicating that there could be an election this year.

The honorable member for Wilmot also mentioned the question of a nom de guerre in Canberra for King O'Malley. I have heard him speak about this in the Parliament on two occasions now, so that his sentiments are not unfamiliar to me. We have in Canberra the National Memorials Committee, consisting of the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and certain other people. Proposals for memorials are submitted to this Committee, which has the right to accept or reject them. The acceptance of names for major Canberra projects depends upon the recommendation of that Committee.

The honorable member for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr. J. R. Fraser), in addition to giving credit to the News and Information Bureau - which I acknowledge - spoke about a document, "The Future Canberra", which I presented today. I do not think it necessary to debate that document tonight, because I hope it will be looked at by the Parliament and debated fully here and in another place. It is an important document. In it, the Department is presenting to the Parliament a blueprint for the future development of Canberra to the stage when the population of the city is 250,000. At the present rate of growth, we expect that to be in 20 or 25 years' time. The honorable member for the Australian Capital Territory says that the document contains many words. I prefer to say that it represents a tremendous amount of work. It contains a blueprint for the development of three new major suburban areas for Canberra - the Woden district, the Belconnen area and the Majura area The plans have been drawn up after having obtained the best town planning advice available throughout the world. They make allowances for increases in traffic .population. During their preparation, due consideration was given to where employment will be available in the various areas and to the movement of people to the shopping centres of each district.

I think it is awfully important if we are to have orderly development and to maintain the high standard of Canberra to have a plan to go to. As I said in my statement this afternoon, this is not a fixed plan. We are seeking informed criticism of it so that changes can be made. I hope that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory will look at this closely and will make recommendations concerning it and criticisms of it. It is only by people looking at it that we can get the best possible plan.

The honorable member for the Australian Capital Territory said that the plan does not provide for houses and so on. This is only a blueprint. When Burley Griffin made his plan of Canberra he did not say how the houses were going to get there or where the shops or anything else would be, but in the course of time they came about. But the honorable member for the Australian Capital Territory did stress the housing position in Canberra. 1 will confess that the housing position in Canberra is difficult. We have a rapidly growing city, in fact the most rapidly growing city in Australia. Canberra is growing at the rate of 10 per cent, to 12i per cent, a year, and it is frightfully hard to meet all the demands of a city which has such growing pains. We are building houses; of course, not as many as everybody would like. We are limited by the finance available, but the number of houses we are building is somewhat in excess of the figure quoted by the honorable member.

talk.start.para: - I quoted the census figure.

- I refer to the document which was presented in the House a few weeks ago. It is the report of the National Capital Development Commission for the last year. It said that the residential accommodation completed and handed over to the Department was 823 houses and 36 bachelor flats. As well, 153 hostel beds were provided for Commonwealth Hostels Ltd.
- Is the Bureau of Census and Statistics wrong? Its figures are here.
- I am only going on what the Commission says. This is the authority which actually built the houses. This report had to be audited, so this figure' is probably the correct one.
- The Commonwealth Bureau of Census and Statistics gives a figure of 736.
- For what date?
- This is for the June quarter of this year.
- Completed housesGovernment houses?
