talk.start.para: .- I desire to raise a matter tonight which I do not think will meet with any opposition from any member of this House. I want to refer to a young lady whose name has been blazoned across almost every newspaper throughout the world - Dawn Fraser. I think we are all aware that her achievements will probably never be equalled by any woman swimmer in the' years to come. She has won three Olympic gold medals.

speech.para: She won Olympic medals before some of the swimmers who have been competing against her in Tokyo had learned to swim. I would say that she has probably done more than any other amateur athlete to put Australia on the map. I agree with the remark which I read in the Press tonight; that it may be truly said that Dawn Fraser has won Olympic immortality. Many other athletes have been honoured for the deeds they have performed in the particular sports in which they have been interested. I think it would be fitting for this House, through the courtesy of the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies), to send a letter of congratulation to this young woman as a tribute to her courage, ability and the wonderful service that she has rendered to Australia and the cause of amateur swimming. But I go further and with all due respect suggest that the Prime Minister initiate action to recommend her for recognition in the New Year honours list. A distinction of that kind would be a fitting reward to this fine ambassador for Australia.

I have been associated with Miss Fraser's swimming career for a number of years. I know of her courage. I know of the difficulties, frustrations and disappointments that she has faced at times. Anybody with less courage than she has could not have overcome the handicaps that she has overcome. I am sure that you, Mr. Speaker, will support my endeavours to see that we do the right thing by Miss Fraser. Her fight back after the dreadful accident in which she was injured and her mother killed in the car in which Dawn was driving should be rewarded. To face up to an arduous training programme and compete in the Olympic Games with the determination to win another gold medal and set a new Olympic record is something that should be rewarded. I ask you, Sir, to lend your support to the appeal that I make for a letter of congratulation to be sent to Miss Fraser and for recognition of her achievements by the bestowal of a royal honour upon her.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to refer briefly to the Yugoslav Settlers Association. It will be remembered that on other occasions I have referred to this organisation's Communist connections. Recently Mr. Jurjevic, President of the Association, had Communist connections.

speech.para: He said that his Association " did not admit either Communist or Ustashi sympathisers ". He implied that he regarded Communists as disgraceful and was opposed to them.

I think, since I have been in communication with Mr. Jurjevic about these matters, that I should place on record some of the public - not private - facts which would allow me the conclusions that I have drawn. There are some Communist associations in this body. First I refer to the Melbourne "Sun" of 10th September last in which Mr. Jurjevic is reported to have said that a picture of Marshal Tito which had been placed in the position of honour in his Association's rooms had been damaged. Now, Marshal Tito is a Communist. Here is an association which, on the admission of its President, places a picture of a Communist in a position of honour. Yet the Association states that it abhors Communism. This does not add up. Then we see that the Association has shown continuous concern for the interests of the present Yugoslav Communist regime. It may be said that these people are Yugoslavs. This is something that must be kept in mind, but they are supporting a Communist regime in Yugoslavia against other Yugoslavs who wish to change the regime.

In November last, shortly after the Association adopted its present name, it sent a representative to interview the Eureka Youth League. Now, the Eureka Youth League is a 100 per cent. Communist organisation. That is a matter of public record. Next we have the evidence attested in this House that when the Association was having a public meeting it issued an official invitation to the Communist Party to be present. If the Association regarded the Communist Party as something abominable, as it seemed to imply in the newspaper statement to which I have referred, why did it issue a public invitation to this abominable party to come to its meeting?

Finally, there is the fact that there is a continuous parallelism between Communist Party propaganda and the propaganda issued by the Association and by Mr. Jurjevic. I do not need to rely on any private information to establish the truth of the statement I made. This is something that goes deeper and the House may wish to look at what seems to have happened on the major scale. The campaign which the Yugoslav Settlers Association is at present mounting against anybody who organises against Communism had its origin in a conference which was held in New York in September 1962. It will be recalled that the Croats in Yugoslavia believe, rightly or wrongly, that they are being oppressed by the ruling Communist Titoist clique and they are organising for some kind of self determination. This is something which honorable members opposite have supported in regard to other people who have organised in Communist interests in the past.

These people organised the meeting in New York. The meeting was important to Marshal Tito for two reasons. First, he felt that his own regime in Yugoslavia could be disrupted. Secondly, he felt that exposure of what he was doing to oppressed minorities might reduce the monetary aid that he was receiving from the United States of America. It was important for him to counter this movement. So, under the prompting of Marshal Tito and his organisation, a campaign against all anti-Communists was started throughout the world. What happened in Australia is only one part of a world wide picture. The move started in Australia just a few months later with the formation of the Dalmatian Settlers Association under the chairmanship of the same Mr. Jurjevic, with considerable Titoist promptings. It was an association, based on the idea of attacking the people who wanted self determination for the Yugoslav minorities.

But then something much more sinister happened. It will be recalled that although Tito was a Communist he was not in full communion with Moscow. Moscow wanted to bring him into full communion. What did Moscow do? It said that the Communist Party throughout the world, controlled by Moscow, had a very big propaganda organisation. It said that the Yugoslavs had only a small propaganda organisation. Moscow offered to put its Communist propaganda organisation throughout the world at the service of the Yugoslavs so that the Yugoslavs might defame all anti-Communists and at the same time try to defame any body endeavouring to obtain self determination for Yugolsav minorities. It seems fairly well established now, on the facts, that this was a bargain struck between Tito and Moscow.

That is Communist diplomacy working at the highest level of subversion. Moscow needed to bring Tito onside. The House will realise that in the last few months Tito, in point of fact, has moved onside. He has been paid by Moscow and the payment has taken the form of putting at the service of Yugoslav organisations throughout the world the much more extensive network of Communist subversion and propaganda. I ask honorable members only to look at the Communist Press articles on this matter over the last two or three years to sec how true that statement is. They will find the evidence of what I have said in the columns of the Communist Press.

It may well be that Mr. Jurievic is not a party to what is happening. He may be simply the pawn that is used, and he may not know what it is all about. I think that is perfectly possible. But, whatever the position is, the Communists are combining with the Titoists in an organised campaign throughout the world to defame anybody who wants self determination for Yugoslav minorities.

The House will remember that from time to time the honorable member for Yarra (Dr. J. F. Cairns) has had something to say about this matter. Some of his statements - one in particular - I have described in the House as false in fact. The Chair did not allow me to persevere with the presentation of proof of my statement, so I have taken the only course open to me. I have written down the proof and tonight I have circulated copies of the document to all honorable members so that they may read it. If the House will give me permission, I will be only too happy to lay on the table of the House a copy of what I have written. I ask for leave to do that'.

talk.start.para: - Is leave granted?
- Yes.
- Leave is granted.
- I present the following paper -

quote.para: Pamphlet entitled "True or False? Evidence in connection wilh statements made by Dr. Cairns".

speech.para: I can only say that that is a factual document. It proves the truth of what I have been saying, namely, that the statements made by the honorable member for Yarra, in point of fact, were false.

talk.start.para: . - The honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) once more has regaled the House with some of his strange views on Communism and other things. I just remind the House that, according to the Melbourne "Age" of 10th June 1963, the honorable gentleman addressed members of the Victorian Young Liberal and Country Movement at their annual political science conference at Cowes. The newspaper report says -

quote.para: Public naming of Communist party members in Australia was necessary to preserve our democratic way of life, Mr. Wentworth, M.H.R., said today.

speech.para: He goes to the security service often enough. I do not know why he is not able to name members of the Communist Party himself, instead of asking the Government to name them. According to the press report - I have not heard it contradicted at any time by the honorable member or anybody else - in the course of that speech, which was a rather remarkable one, he said -

quote.para: We cannot destroy the Communist party in Australia without going beyond the normal democratic processes, which in the past have tended to help rather than hinder their subversive activities.

speech.para: What does that mean? Does it mean that the honorable gentleman does not believe in democracy and wants to use Fascist methods or something that would be repugnant to the average person? He is sensitive to that feeling, because he did use the words " without going beyond the normal democratic processes". Does he mean that he wants to abolish trial by jury, that he wants to imprison people without trial, that he wants to name a person as a Communist . . .

talk.start.para: - And have preventive detention.
- Yes. Does he mean that he wants to have preventive detention following that? In the spirit of the organisation whose meeting he was addressing, he said -

quote.para: There is a tendency in Australia to use Communism as an election issue only, but this is not a good reason in itself to oppose Communism.

speech.para: I cannot follow exactly the logic of that argument. Apparently he does not want to use Communism as an election issue only, in the interests of the Liberal Party, he wants to use it at all times for the purpose of frightening people, smearing people and destroying people's reputations, and he does not want any person whom he attacks to have any resort to law. He does not want any protection by the normal use of democratic processes.

talk.start.para: - He probably calls himself a Christian.

- He probably offends even more grievously by calling himself a democrat. Then he went on to say - tt is most important to maintain an effective and unrelenting fight against Communism in Australia until it is completely wiped out.

speech.para: Nobody on this side of the House and nobody in any part of either House of this Parliament favours the Communist philosophy. We all regard it as evil. We all oppose it. But we will not destroy Communism by legislating against it, by smearing people and by abandoning democratic processes. The way to get rid of Communism is to remove the evil out of which it grows, to remove the soil in which it takes root. I have never heard the honorable member for Mackellar say anything against monopoly capitalism. I have never heard him say that there is anything wrong with monopolies, cartels, trusts, combines or any similar things which today are holding Australia to ransom and are impoverishing many people.
Industries are being destroyed and small businesses are being destroyed as a result of the excesses and inherent rotteness of monopoly capitalism.

If the honorable member for Mackellar would attack the cause of Communism or the sources from which it develops, he might be doing something to wipe out Communism in this country, but he rants about it night after night and day after day, and worse than that, wastes money that he ought to be spending on his wife and family in printing stupid documents and circulating them around the Commonwealth, that shows the extent to which the honorable gentleman is around the bend. I leave it at that.

talk.start.para: - Mr. Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation. I have been entirely misrepresented by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell). He said that I wanted to abolish trial by jury and things like that. The statement that he read meant exactly what it said, namely, that we should name Communists. That I regard as being perhaps, rather outside the democratic processes. In this House and elsewhere 1 have said that we should do that, subject to proper safeguards and proper protection. I have said no more than that and I say no less than that. The Leader of the Opposition entirely and deliberately misrepresented what I said. Now, Sir, there is another point
- Order! The honorable member must not debate the matter. He can only point out where he has been misrepresented.

- There was another point of misrepresentation. The Leader of the Opposition said that I said that Commu.nism should not be used as an election issue only. He went on to put a gloss on that by saying that I would use Communism for certain other purposes. I meant what 1 said. Opposition to Communism should be used not only as an election issue but as something substantial - something which all Australians should express at all times.

.- I wish to buy in, only briefly, to this discussion. What the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) said has been answered very effectively by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell). I point out to the honorable member only that the naming of Communists is a very dangerous procedure unless you have proof. I recollect sitting in this chamber one night many years ago when the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) listed a number of people who he said were prominent Communists, and the next night he had to publish personally an apology to five of those people because he had been mistaken. Untold damage is done to the prestige of certain people by the dangerous procedure of, without proof, calling them names or saying that they were affiliated with certain organisations. Like other honorable members, I am a little sick and tired of listening to Schmidt der Spy, as he might be called, night after night in this Parliament bringing forward proposals such as he has tonight. Therefore, while he was speaking tonight I took note of those who were sitting in the chamber and who were supposed to be listening to him. There were 34 members of the Government parties in the House when he started to speak. Several of them were asleep, including two Ministers. Some of them were showing no interest at all in what he said, but the vast majority, to their credit, wore expressions of disgust. That is why we on this side of the chamber see no reason to take much notice of the constant statements of the honorable member at a late hour at night, when they are of interest to no-one but himself.

speech.para: I rose tonight to place on record a very great tribute that has been paid to the New South Wales Labour Government. The New South Wales Government is constantly under attack in this Parliament, mainly by members of the Australian Country Party and, of course, some misguided members of the Liberal Party. The New South Wales Government has been in office for 24 years. It has a remarkable record of achievement and no doubt its record will be endorsed at the election to be held next year, particularly in view of certain events that are now occurring in the State. I had in mind some of the attacks made by the honorable member for Cowper (Mr. Robinson) and others when I read an article in the "Daily Mirror " on 1st October. It is headed " Ours is the Best-run Australian State " and says -

quote.para: The Federal Government regards N.S.W. as the best-managed State, according to a confidential letter to business executives.
The letter was circulated by an Australian-wide firm of research specialists.
Quoting sources "close to the Commonwealth Government" it says that Victoria is regarded as perhaps the worst managed State.

speech.para: Of course, Victoria is run by the Liberal Party. The article continues -

quote.para: It says that Queensland and Western Australia are given fairly high marks on a score card based on financial stability and financial responsibility.
The letter critically analyses the suggestion by the Victorian Premier, Mr. Bolte, that he might introduce a special State income tax next year.

speech.para: I think that theory has been exploded. The article goes on -

quote.para: The firm describes Mr. Bolte's move as repetition of his 1959 "pressure tactics" which, it said, gained Victoria an advantage over N.S.W.
At this year's Premiers' conference, the letter says, N.S.W. made it clear to the Commonwealth that any further special treatment for Victoria would lead to grave trouble.
The Commonwealth had subsequently refused to help Victoria out of its financial difficulties.
From then on, Mr. Bolte was facing grave difficulties in restoring order to Victorian finances.
The letter says few responsible people in the Federal Government believe Mr. Bolte will go ahead with his State income tax plan.
They believe he is using the scheme to put more pressure on the Commonwealth to find money for Victoria.
The big worry now is that the Commonwealth will again give In to pressure and make another special deal to help Mr. Bolte, the letter says.

speech.para: I read the last part of the article for the information of honorable members. It is good to see a tribute being paid by the Federal Government to the Labour Administration in New South Wales. It may not please the members of the Australian Country Party who constantly decry the achievements of the New South Wales Government, but it must be a source of satisfaction to those few members of the Country Party who are fair minded. The State run by a Labour government is said to be the best governed in the Commonwealth. Having in mind the comments in the article about Mr. Bolte, the time is probably appropriate for me to congratulate the Country Party on withdrawing its support for the Liberal Party in Victoria. I feel a little measure of regret at the breaking up of this happy family. In Western Australia the children are squabbling; there is an upheaval in the family in Tasmania; the members of the family have just been sorted out in Queensland, in some way, with one or two annihilated, a few others dead and some other minor happenings of that character. In this Parliament, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. McEwen) recently reacted very violently to suggestions of disloyalty to the present Government. These squabbles are so apparent that Opposition members cannot be blamed for thinking that there may be some substance in rumours that the coalition is breaking up.

I think it is quite appropriate that we should record that the members of the Australian Country Party, with due respect to them, have always shown a fair amount of political wisdom. They are at last aware of the nature of the Liberal Party, and the people of Australia can rejoice at this fact. I would like to congratulate the intelligent members of the Australian Country Party on what is happening south of the border. This is an indication that no matter how long it takes to sink in, the members of the Australian Country Party will at last realise that some of the people with whom they associate on their side of the Parliament are hardly worthy of their support. I mention these factors because I think they are worth recalling. After all, we hear many gibes at the differences of opinion that occur on our side of the fence. But we are told that all is well on the other side of the Parliament, that all is rosy, that there is absolute unity and that they walk forward as one. Mr. Bolte does not think so and, as I said, the parties in other States apparently do not agree.

talk.start.para: - What about Mr. Chaffey?

- Yes, and there is Mr. Chaffey in New South Wales. I wonder whether the Deputy Leader of the Country Party in New South Wales has the support of the Leader of the Country Party in this Parliament when he expresses his views on the actions of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. in that State. I wonder whether the views of the State Country Party are endorsed by the Country Party in this Parliament. When ail is said and done we want unity and stability in government. This is a matter of concern to me. I sorrow to see a long association breaking on the rocks. It is depressing to those of us who have watched the unity of spirit amongst honorable members opposite. We cannot help but feel sad when we realise that, after all these years, the association of the Government parties is about to be shattered. We on this side of the Parliament have always thought that this was a shot-gun wedding, and we know that such weddings end in strange ways. But the parties on the opposite side have stuck together quite commendably.

speech.para: In a way, the members of the Country Party are enjoying what I am saying. They know that there is substance in my remarks. I do not blame them for being here and listening so attentively to me. Mine is the type of speech that they would like to make, but I realise that they have certain loyalties that they must show, at least in public.

They cannot get up and make these remarks from their side of the fence and 1 do not mind obliging them by making this speech. I see the Ministers sitting on the treasury bench. They are very silent on the issues I have raised. One of the most significant features of the proceedings in this Parliament in recent times has been the silence of members of the Liberal Party and Country Party on what is happening about preferences and so on in the States. Surely we are entitled to know whether there is any truth In the vile rumours that have been circulating about the selection of candidates for the election. We would like to be reassured that all is well on the other side of the Parliament, because after all it is very depressing for us to see this disharmony when the country needs that forthright leadership that comes from unity and solidarity.

At this late hour of the night I place these few sentiments on record. 1 again record my pleasure on learning that the best run State is a Labour State. That is not a bad slogan, in a way. I commend the Country Party for waking up to the Liberal Party in the States. While I do not exactly like to see a revolution, it would not be so bad for the country, possibly, if the Country Party in the Federal sphere acted towards the Liberal Party as the State branches have been acting.

talk.start.para: .- In view of the remarks made by the honorable member for Grayndler (Mr. Daly), in which he said that New South Wales is the best run State in the Commonwealth, it would be a pity if we were not to place on record some of the information that was recently issued by the Commonwealth Statistician. I have in mind the information relating to retail sales recorded in each State in 1963- 64. These figures are very interesting. They disclose that New South Wales has the poorest record of any State in the field of retail spending. This surely must have some bearing on which is the best run State. Let me come to the point and give the figures. First, there was a rise of only 3.6 per cent, in retail sales in New South Wales in the last financial year. This was the smallest increase in the Commonwealth and compares with an average increase throughout the whole of Australia of 5.6 per cent.
- Work out the figures for the other States.

- I shall be very glad indeed to work out the increases for the other States. In South Australia, the increase was 8 per cent. In Queensland - a State that is very well managed, if I may just intrude that comment - the increase was 6.4 per cent. In Victoria, which is not badly run either, the increase was 6.2 per cent. In Western Australia, the increase was 4.1 per cent. These figures reflect very clearly the difference between a State administration that is concerned about the welfare of the residents of the State and administrations that are concerned only about political ambitions and a desire to drive the economy further and further away from a basis of stability founded on the fundamental principle of giving the people the greatest possible opportunity to improve their lot. The lot of the individual in New South Wales, according to this record, is worse than the lot of the individual in any other State. I hope that the Australian Labour Party will take this to heart and that its friends in this House will heed the facts of the situation, give good advice to their colleagues in New South Wales and tell them what they can do to help directly the electors in that State.

speech.para: May I turn briefly to motor car sales. I believe that they reflect the prosperity of a community. The increase in motor car sales last financial year compared to the preceding one was less in New South Wales than in any other State, being only 4.1 per cent., in contrast to a national increase of 11 per cent. These records are indisputable. The facts are very telling indeed. It is sheer humbug for the honorable member for Grayndler to rise in this chamber and extol the virtues of a State administration without submitting any facts, figures or other information to back his assertions.

I conclude by saying that the record of the present Commonwealth Government, in the last few months in particular, has demonstrated very clearly what can be done by an administration that tackles the task of looking after the welfare of the individual. We have full employment today despite the economic difficulties that have been encountered. This full employment provides better opportunities for all sections of the community. Thanks to the policies of this Government, as opposed to those of the Australian Labour Party, we are able to show this excellent record of good government.

talk.start.para: n asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: Are Australian passenger or freight carrying commercial aircraft required to carry lighter loads when using wet or slippery runways?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Civil Aviation has supplied the following information -

item.para: Australian practice follows- world-wide rules and makes no variation to the take-off and landing distances required for operations from wet or dry runways. An aircraft load is planned well in advance of the time of landing so that it would be impracticable to operate aircraft to standards which would vary the load it could carry dependent on whether the runways for take-off and landing were wet or dry.

talk.start.para: t.- On 3rd September, the honorable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr. Collard) asked the Prime Minister a question without notice on gold. The following information is additional to that given by the Prime Minister in his answer -

quote.para: As forecast in the Prime Minister's interim reply of 3rd September, I spoke strongly at the recent Annual Meeting of the International Monetary Fund on the price and production of gold. I said: " I do wish, however, to dwell on one topic which, having regard to its importance, has been given inadequate attention in the reports both of the Fund and of the Ten. That is the question of gold. Perhaps it is thought that its relationship to the International Monetary System is so well known as to require little elaboration. But the Fund Report covers the first thorough-going review of the functioning of the International Monetary System made after twenty years of operation. This review remains incomplete without a full analysis of the place of gold in the system. In any discussion on international liquidity, the place of gold, the price of gold and the adequacy of supply of gold should all receive attention appropriate to their importance.

The present International Monetary System is largely based on gold. Gold makes up the major part of total international reserves. It is significant in this context that the major industrialised countries, particularly those of Europe, firmly and persistently retain the largest portion of their reserves in gold, and there is apparently an undiminishing demand for the metal for this purpose. The Fund requires each of us to supply a substantial proportion of its assets in gold. Yet in our studies of the problem of international liquidity and possible means of ensuring that it will increase sufficiently in the years ahead, it seems to be assumed far too readily that the supply of gold will prove adequate to needs and that the price of this metal, fixed at 35 dollars to the ounce 30 years ago, should be held at that value. There has been no discussion whether steps should be taken to increase the supply of metal that provides the foundation as well as the greater part, of international liquidity at present. On page 102 of the Fund Report for 1964 there is a table of the value of world gold production, gravely disturbing in its implications. It illustrates the dramatic decline in gold production in almost every country of the world since 1940. If we leave South African production out of the table, we find that the value of free world production of gold has slumped from U.S. 772 million dollars in 1940 to U.S. 399 million dollars in 1963. Some may take comfort from the fact that the total value of free world production has moved from 1,264 million dollars in 1940 to 1,360 million dollars in 1963. An increase of this dimension in the production value of any commodity would be regarded as modest enough over an interval of 23 years, but detailed examination reveals that, wilh the notable exception of South Africa, whose value of production increased spectacularly over that period from 492 million dollars to 961 million dollars, of the remaining ten major producing countries listed, only one, Ghana, has shown an increase, and this only a marginal movement from 31 million dollars to 32 million dollars. The combined value of all the others has shown a sharp decrease. Of the countries not listed individually but grouped under the heading " Other ", the value of production has declined from 157 million dollars to 65 million dollars.

We would have been discussing this question of international liquidity much earlier if gold reserves had not been propped up by South African production, which has more than doubled in value over the past ten years. But even in relation to that source of supply, the Fund Report has a sombre comment. It says on page 103 that 'South African production will have nearly reached its peak in 1964 or 1965. Thereafter it may level ofl for a few years, and subsequently decline.'

It must be assumed from their reports that neither the Fund nor the Group of Tcn contemplate any change in the price of gold. lt remains to be seen how long this commodity can be held at a price fixed 30 years ago. It is against nature to hold it there unchanged indefinitely, regardless of general cost and price movements, and for my own part, I think we merely increase the difficulties of adjustment, the longer an adjustment is delayed. However whatever views we may hold on that aspect, we clearly need a compre hensive and up-to-date study by the Fund of the causes of the decline in gold production in so many countries, and an examination of methods whereby the supply of a metal fundamental to the liquidity of the International Monetary System can be substantially augmented. I would hope that by the time of our next meeting, such studies would not only have been put in hand, but their results made available to us early enough for a more searching discussion then."

As to gold subsidies, certain forms of subsidy - particularly those that involve a uniform payment per ounce for all or part of the gold produced in a Member country - constitute, in effect, an increase in the price of gold. For this reason, each Member proposing to subsidise gold production is under an obligation to consult with the Fund on the specific measures which it proposes to introduce. The Fund attitude towards gold subsidies stems from the view that the official price of gold should be kept stable. As long as the major Members remain determined to keep the official price fixed, it follows that there is no possibility of amending the Fund rulings on subsidies.
The Commonwealth Government has consulted with the Fund on its own gold subsidy legislation and the Fund has approved it as consistent with ils policy on gold subsidies.
